. I was put-boy to Mr. Pink. I found two pistols in my box, and showed them to the servant, who told mistress;
James Pink
offered to give me a watch, a box of colours, and some money, if I would say they were mine: Stapleton used to come every morning, about seven o'clock, for half a quartern of gin in a bottle - his friends lived close by; he was a very good boy.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Were you always in the bar? A. Yes, or about the bar; I had to clean the shoes and the tap-room - I was there eleven months, and he came every morning.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
NOT GUILTY .

1715.
JOHN WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of May , 1 half-crown , the money of
John Clements Pink
.

JAMES PINK
. The prisoner used to come in the morning about three months before the letter was sent - he said he knew I had given other boys money, and he would have some, or he would tell my father; I had seen him in Thomas's company - he said he must have a shilling, which I gave him; he had half a crown about the 26th of May, as he said he would tell my father if I did not give it to him; I got it from the cash-box up stairs - he did not see me take it.
COURT. Q.What did you think of your own conduct at the time? A. I thought I was doing very wrong, but it was done through fear.
Prisoner. Q.Where was I when you gave me the first shilling? A. In the bar.

Prisoner. You said, "Will you have a shilling?" I said, "I will thank any body to give me one;" you went into the bar, brought one out, and gave me 1s. 6d. to buy you some ballads. Witness. No, I did not; he gave me a good many songs once - he gave me a seal once; he received from 25s. to 30s. in all - the seal is worth about 6d.; I never gave him money without his demanding it, and never employed him to bring me things in.

JOHN CLEMENTS PINK
gave the same evidence as in the former case.
NOT GUILTY .
The Jury stated that if they had been aware of the facts of this case they should not have convicted Thomas.

1716.
JAMES ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 sack, value 3s., and 2 bushels of potatoes, value 4s. , the goods of
Fordham Ellis
, his master.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

RICHARD WATKIN
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 7th of September I went with Mead to the William the Fourth beer-house, at Enfield; the prisoner came there about a quarter-past one o'clock in the morning, with a horse and cart - he stopped opposite the house, came up to the door which leads into the yard, jumped up, put his hand over, and unbolted the door; he then went back to the cart, and brought out a sack of potatoes- when he had got to the passage leading to the road, we showed ourselves, and he put the potatoes down; I asked him what he was going to do with them - he said to leave them for the ostler, who was to give him a 1s. for them; I secured him - he begged forgiveness, and said it was the first time he ever robbed his master; after some time I allowed him to go on to London with his cart, and when he returned I took him.
Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. How many horses were there in the cart? A. Two; he did not say it was so loaded he was forced to leave some - he said he lodged at that house.

JOHN MEAD
. I was in company with Watkin - what he has stated is correct; the cart he was driving was Mr. Ellis' - the sack was turned inside out, and upon turning it I found the name of Fordham Ellis, Edmonton, upon it.

BENJAMIN MEERES
. I am bailliff to Mr. Fordham Ellis, of Edmonton. The prisoner was in his service, and the sack is his property.
MR. FORDHAM ELLIS. The prisoner has been in my employ about two years; I employed him to carry the potatoes to London, and on his return I met him at the station-house, and took him.

Prisoner's Defence When I put them off my back the officer told me to take them into the stable, which I did; I said I was going to leave them there - he asked what I could get for them if I was going to sell them; I said I might get 1s. for them, but I did not mean to sell them.

RICHARD WATKIN
. I am quite positive he told me the ostler was to have them, and give him 1s. for them.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

1717.
CHARLES PRIEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 1 copper lid, value 4s. , the goods of
John Lockington
.
The prosecutor's name being Cockerton, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1718.
JOHN POTTER
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 7th of September , 1 sack, value 18d., and 1 bushel of potatoes, value 18d., the goods of
Richard Palmer
, well knowing the same to have been stolen .
MR. CLARKSON declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1719.
JOHN POTTER
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 7th of September , 4 sacks, value 3s.; 2 bushels of potatoes, value 1s., and 6 bushels of chaff, value 3s., the goods of
Richard Walker
, the younger, well knowing the same to have been stolen .

No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1720.
ARTHUR TURNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 8 pennyweights of silver solder, value 2s.; 2 pennyweights of gold solder, value 18d., and 1 pennyweight of gold and silver solder, value 6d. , the goods of
John Sandon
, his master.

THOMAS CLARK
. I am a Police-officer. On the evening of the 30th of August, about half-past eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner at the watch-house in Rosamon-street; I found in his pocket a quantity of gold and silver - he said it was gold and silver dust, and that he worked for himself; I knew that he had worked for Mr. Sandon, and took him there.

JOHN SANDON
. I am a goldsmith , and live in Great Sutton-street. The prisoner was in my employ five or six years; I did not miss this property till it was found on him - he worked on the the day he was apprehended; I can swear to a mark on one piece of the solder produced - the prisoner had it to work on my premises; he left me about seven o'clock in the evening - he did no work at home; he could not have carried it away accidentally.

GEORGE SANDON
. I am foreman to my brother. I gave the prisoner some solder for his work, and in two or three hours he asked for more, for he had finished what I gave him; when the men leave at night I take the gold and silver - I saw there was very little in the prisoner's can.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Months .

1721.
GEORGE WRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 2 books, value 3s. , the goods of
Richard Kimpton
.

RICHARD KIMPTON
. I am a bookseller , in High Holborn
. In the forenoon of the 5th of July I saw the prisoner at my show-board; he took two books, and walked away with them - I secured him; he had the books under his jacket.
THOMAS MAPP. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. It was the greatest distress which drove me to it.

GUILTY . Aged 63. -
Confined Three Months .

1722.
MARY GODMAN
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 29th of August , 28 yards of cotton, value 15s. , the goods of
Isaac Welchman
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1723.
JOHN CHARLES FREDERICK HUNTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 compass, value 5s., the goods of
John Bartholomew Cowmeadow
; and 1 pair of gloves, value 1s. , the goods of
John Edward Cowmeadow
.

ANN COWMEADOW
. I am the wife of John Edward Cowmeadow, a coal-merchant , at Notting-hill grove, Kensington
. The prisoner came to our house one Sunday, about three weeks ago, to see my son, John Bartholomew Cowmeadow; this compass was in a work-box on the back parlour mantel-piece when he came - I saw it there the night before; he stopped about an hour - when he was gone we missed the compass and a pair of gloves from a drawer in the bed-room, which belonged to Ann Esther Cowmeadow; it was under my care.

EDWARD JAMES LEVY
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner between five and six o'clock the same evening - he had left the prosecutor's about ten in the morning; this pair of gloves was in his waistcoat pocket, and this bundle was at the Swan, at Kensington Gravel-pits, where he was stopped; I found 2l. 19s. on him - he said he knew nothing of any part of the property; he told me what he had done with the compass.

HUGH MCGANEY
. On Sunday, the 21st of August, between three and four o'clock, I was in Praed-street, Edgware-road; I saw the prisoner standing, with some persons round, who said it was a shame he should be treated so - upon inquiry I found he had been into a shop for a pennyworth of curds and whey - that he said it was sour, and that the man of the shop had kicked him in the mud; he said he was going to Bayswater - I asked him to come to my house and have his clothes brushed; while he was there he seemed to take a great fancy to an opera-glass on my mantel-piece, and he offered me this compass in exchange for it - I gave him the opera-glass and a penknife for the compass; I gave the same compass to the officer.

JOHN BARTHOLOMEW COWMEADOW
. The prisoner called that Sunday morning at our house - this compass was in the back parlour; it is mine - I did not see him go into that room, but I saw him in the room where the gloves were.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1724.
CHARLES JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 2 waistcoats, value 9s , the goods of
Robert Schofield
.

SARAH SCHOFIELD
. I am the wife of Robert Schofield - he is a salesman . On the 26th of July I went out, and on my return saw the prisoner at my street door; he asked about a black coat, which had laid in our window - I told him it was sold, and he went away; when I got into the shop I missed a waistcoat off the drawers, and another out of the drawers - he came next morning, between nine and ten o'clock, and asked if I had a white waistcoat to sell; I said No, and told him I had missed two waistcoats - he said if I called where he lived, at William-street, I should have his character - I went there with an officer, and found him; he denied the charge - I found the property at the pawnbroker's.

JAMES WATSON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Strutton-ground, Westminster. These two waistcoats were pawned by the prisoner, in the afternoon of the 26th of July.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received an excellent character.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Fourteen Days .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1725.
THOMAS SMITH
and
JOHN JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 56 lbs. of lead, value 4s. 10d., the goods of
James Rhodes
, and fixed to a building .

BENJAMIN COLLINS
. I am an officer. On the 27th of August, about half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, I met the prisoners in the City-road, near the bridge - Smith had this parcel on his shoulder, and Jones was a little behind him; I followed them some distance, and Smith gave Jones the parcel - they went to Mr. Pearces' shop, a plumber, in Plumber's-row, and Jones threw the lead into the scale; Mr. Pearce came into the shop - I told him I suspected it was stolen; Jones said it was not, that he had brought it from his own house in Golden-lane, and it was his own - I said I had seen them come in a very contrary direction, and asked if they had not brought it from the back of Mr. Rhodes'; they denied it- I asked Mr. Pearce to assist me in taking them to the station; in going along Smith struck Mr. Pearce, pushed him down, and attempted to escape, but we secured them- at the station-house Jones said they had picked the lead up, but they thought it was no harm; I found some lead had been taken from a gutter in one of the houses at the back of Mr. Rhodes', and I found the lead which the prisoners had, fitted the gutter exactly - the nail holes all matched, and it exactly corresponded where it was cut.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What did Jones say when he got to the shop? A. He said he had brought some lead, and that he wanted some glass for it; the lead had been taken from the top of a kitchen adjoining a house - Jones said they picked it up in a field; a boy, who came and swore he saw the prisoners pick up the lead in a field, is not here - he gave evidence at the office against the prisoners.

GEORGE PEARCE
. I am a lead-merchant and glasscutter - I live in Plumbers'-row, The prisoners brought this lead to my house on the 27th of August; one of them put it into the scale - my son was in the shop; when I came out the officer asked me to assist in taking the prisoners - I was knocked down in going along, and a staff, which I carry in my pocket, as a warrant-officer to the Commissioners of Sewers, was bruised; I was dragged in the mud for a considerable distance.

THOMAS PEARSON
. I know Mr. James Rhodes. The officer called, and showed me some lead; I went to one of Mr. Rhodes' houses, and the lead fitted the gutter exactly.
Cross-examined. Q.When had you seen it safe? A. Not since it was put up, which is three years ago.

COURT. Q. Are the houses inhabited? A. No - this lead was on a kitchen which leans against the house; thelead being off would have let the rain in - I had been in the house three days before, and there was not any appearance of rain coming in.
Smith's Defence. We went down by the side of the New-river, and saw this lead laying among the grass, in a field - I took it up, and we went to a shop; a boy saw us find it.
NOT GUILTY .

1726.
MICHAEL NEESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 1 book, value 2s. , the goods of
Benjamin Galpin
.

JOHN ARKLEY
. I was shopman to Mr. Benjamin Galpin, who keeps a shop in Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square
. I saw the prisoner at his window on the 2nd of July - he took up the Pilgrim's Progress, and put it at the end of a book, he came a second time, looked at it, and put it down; he came a third time, looked at it again, and pretended to put it down, but did not - he ran across the street; we followed, and took it from his hand.

GUILTY . Aged 36 -
Confined Six Weeks .

1727.
JOHN HOLMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 silk dress, value 3l.; 1 basket, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d., and 1 pair of gloves, value 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Biss
.
The prosecutor's name being Samuel Benjamin Biss, the prisoner was ACQUITTED .

1728.
GEORGE NEWBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 7 yards of printed cotton, value 5s. , the goods of
Dickenson Sowerby
.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am shopman to Mr. Dickenson Sowerby, a pawnbroker , in Booth-street
. On the 16th of July, between ten and eleven o'clock in the evening, Wall said a man had stolen a piece of cotton from the shop - I went to the door; an officer had the prisoner, and asked if this was my master's property - I said it was; it had hung about the middle of the shop, and had been covered over - I had seen it about six or seven o'clock.

GEORGE WALL
. I was standing close by the prisoner in the shop; I saw him take this cotton from a partition in the middle of the shop - he went out; I followed him till I saw an officer, and he was taken; I had seen him throw the cotton into an area.

JAMES DENNIS
. I am an officer. Wall pointed out the prisoner to me - he was running, and I took him; I had not seen him throw the cotton away, but a female at the house gave it to me.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Three Months .

1729.
THOMAS OAKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 saw, value 2s. , the goods of
James Tester
; and that he had before been convicted of felony.

JAMES TESTER
. I am a carpenter . I lost my saw from Sussex-terrace, Kentish-town
, on the 17th of August, while I was gone to breakfast; I had left it in a house which I was finishing - on my return I met the prisoner; I had not known him before - a person had given me information; I said, "You have been stealing my tools," and I found the saw down his bosom.

THOMAS VATER
. I am a carpenter. I was sitting at breakfast, and a man came in and gave us information -I went out, and saw the prisoner coming round the corner of the building - I took him back; I thought he walked stiff and took this saw from his bosom.

SAMUEL BRACHER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and have the saw.(Property produced and sworn to.)

CHARLES CLARK
. I am an officer. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, by the name of
John Mason
, for stealing two planes and some other tools - I took him, and know he is the person - he was confined seven days in Newgate.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1730.
JAMES PIPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 hat, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Merry
.

THOMAS GILKES
. I am a Police-officer. On the 1st of July, within a few minutes of nine o'clock at night, I was near Hackney church-tower; the prisoner passed me, and had nothing with him - in about two minutes he passed me again, with something concealed under his coat; on going to see what it was, I found this straw hat, which he said. he had bought in a public-house, at Clapton, for 6d.: I looked in it, saw Mr. Merry's name, and went there - he was about one hundred yards from the prosecutor's.

CHRISTIANA BURGESS. I lived with Mr. Merry - he keeps a straw-hat warehouse . This hat is his; it had been taken from the end of the counter, near the door - I had seen it a few minutes before eight o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1731.
JOHN SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 silk handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
Jonathan Murray
.

ROBERT STUPART
. I live with Mr. Jonathan Murray, a pawnbroker , of East Smithfield
. On the 30th of July, I was informed that a person had taken a handkerchief, which had hung by the door; I looked and missed it; I had seen it about an hour before - I went to the door, and the officer brought the prisoner back with it.

JOHN MADDY
. I am an officer. I met the prisoner coming towards Rosemary-lane, about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's; a young man from the shop overtook him, and said he had stolen a handkerchief: he denied it, but I saw him drop this handkerchief from his jacket - I took it up, and took charge of him.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 38.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1732.
ELIZA SLATER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 gold seal, value 4s., and 1 watchkey, value 4s., the goods of
William Mosto
, from his person .

THOMAS ANDREW CAMROUX
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor laying on the ground in Hoxton, at a quarter-past nine o'clock, on the 7th of August - the prosecutor was very drunk, I heard the prisoner say, "Give me the watch;" I asked if he was her husband - she said Yes; I took them both to the station-house- the prisoner had the seal and key; the prosecutor could not speak - he was quite insensible.
NOT GUILTY .

1733.
WILLIAM FORSCUTT
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JOHN SMITH
. I am a baker . The prisoner was in my employ about seven months; he had to book his bread every night, and give an account of the money he had received - I had given him notice to quit previous to the 27th of June, but he seemed sorry for something he had done, and I forgave him - he left me without notice in the middle of the week.

JANE MARTIN
. I am a customer of the prosecutor's - I paid the prisoner 3s. 7d. for him on the 27th of June; he receipted this bill for it.

MARY WESTON
. I paid the prisoner 4s. on account of his master, on the 7th of July - he wrote a receipt on this bill.

MR. SMITH. He never accounted to me for these sums; the 7th of July was the day he left me - I had mentioned to him about the 3s. 7d. a morning or two before, and he owned he had not accounted for it.

Prisoner's Defence. I had between seventy and eighty customers to give an account of every night - when I gave in the account on the 27th of June I was money over in my pocket, and could not recollect where it came from; on the Monday, when I went to Mrs. Martin's I took her two bills - she said, "I paid you one;" she went to my master, and he took the work out of my hand.
The prisoner received a good character, and a master said he would take him into his employ.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1734.
JOHN DROVER
and
JOHN HARTIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 hat, value 10s.; 1 stock, value 2s., and 1 snuff-box, value 6d. , the goods of
Charles Edward Thomas Mills
.

CHARLES EDWARD THOMAS MILLS
. I am a medical-student , and live in John-street, Blackfriars-road. On the 14th of July I was in Newcastle-street, Strand
, about nine o'clock at night; I was not altogether sober, but was not drunk - a man insulted me by shoving against me; the two prisoners came up, and offered to assist me in getting away - shortly afterwards I stripped to fight, and took off my hat and coat; Drover took my hat - I do not know who took my coat; my opponents all ran off - I then looked for my coat and hat; they were gone also - Drover was taken with my hat; they were all strangers to me.

JOHN PERKINS
. I am a Police-officer. The prosecutor came, and said he had been robbed - he was sober enough to tell me all this; I went down my beat, met Drover with the hat on his head, and I found in his possession the pocket-book, handkerchief, and gloves - I took him to the prosecutor, who said it was his, and that was the man who took them; I asked Drover where the coat and stock were - he said he had sold them in Russel-court, Drurylane, and I found them there.

CHARLES YOUNG
. I am a Police-officer. I saw the two prisoners following the prosecutor up towards Templebar, and back again - the prosecutor was not sober, but was capable of walking and talking; in about a quarter of an hour I saw the prosecutor with a hat on, which I had seen Drover wear the same evening, and that caused suspicion; I took Hartin on the 13th of August - I had seen both the prisoners in company before, and knew they were associates.

Hartin. Q. Did you not see the prosecutor stripped, in the act of fighting? A. I saw him taking off his coat; he was having an altercation with some person - I did not see you pick up his clothes from under feet.
M - MOSES. I keep a clothes-shop. I bought this coat of Drover about half an hour before the officer came - there was some other man with him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Drover's Defence. The prosecutor took my hat off, put his hat on my head, and put mine on his head, to disguise himself, to go to fight a porter at the gate of the lun- the handkerchief was in his hat, and I put it into my pocket.

Hartin's Defence. I and a friend went into the public-house opposite the Angel Inn; I heard an altercation, went out, and saw the prosecutor fighting - the Policeman came up and separated them; he was beastly drunk: no man would have behaved as he did in his sober senses; the Policeman sent him towards Temple-bar, but he returned once or twice - I went into the public-house again, and he came in with his coat off, and Drover's hat on; the porter, and two female servants were in the house, having a glass of ale; the prosecutor insisted upon fighting the porter - the man behind the bar jumped over, and turned him out; a respectable person, who was with me, came to Bow-street, and proved that I was not out of his company till half-past eleven o'clock that night, but he was sent by the Scotch society to Scotland, the next day.

DROVER -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

HARTIN -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .

1735.
SUSAN CRESSWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July
, 1 silver spoon, value 1l. , the goods of Count
Jerome De Sails
; and
JANE GAZEY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen , &c.

JAMES BROADWAY
. I am a Policeman. On the 2nd of August I was in a pawnbroker's-shop in Sloane-street, and while I was there Gazey came in, and brought these two pieces of a broken spoon to pawn - they refused to take it, and then she wanted it mended; when she went out I followed her - she crossed, and joined three or four girls of the town; after some conversation with them she went on, and I followed her - I asked what she had got; she said Nothing - I said I had my doubts about that - she then said, "I have a spoon, which is my own property;" I said I should take her to the watch-house - she said she would not go, but she would take me to the house- she took me to the prosecutor's; she called Cresswell to the door, and told her the Policeman was after her - she slipped the spoon into her hand; I took it from her, and found there had been a crest on it, which was nearly erased - Cresswell said it was her own, that her mother had had it left to her before she was born; I said I was not satisfied, I should take her to the watch-house - she said I should not, for it was all right, her son had given it to her, who was now in the West Indies - on our way to the watch-house she said she had found it in a piece of rag, but she could not say when, nor where.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Were youdressed in your uniform? A. Yes; she was in the shop rom three to five minutes - I do not know any thing of either of the prisoners - Gazey took me to the house where Cresswell was.

JAMES ROBINSON. I have been for six years butler to Count
Jerome De Salis
. Cresswell had come to work there for about a month; I know this to be the Count's spoon - here is one letter of the crest on it now.
The prisoners received a good character.

CRESSWELL -
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined Six Months .

GAZEY -
NOT GUILTY .

1736.
PETER CORLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 1 pair of boots, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Rogers
.

THOMAS ROGERS. I lodge in Westminster
. The prisoner lodged in the next bed on the 2nd of September, and the next morning he went away with my shoes - I heard the outside door go, which awoke me; I ran down to the street; I saw a sweep and a boy - I asked if they had met a man; they said Yes, and he had just turned into Orchard-street - the Policeman came by; I told him I had lost my high shoes - he went and got them.

JOSEPH CLARK
. I am an officer. I overtook the prisoner with these shoes.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I get my living by hard labour -I went out that morning at a quarter before five o'clock; I found these shoes outside the door, a few yards off - I took them up; the officer followed me.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Confined Three Months .

1737.
WILLIAM BLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Calvert
, from his person .

THOMAS CALVERT
. I was in Hyde-park
on the 11th of July; I had a handkerchief - the officer asked me if I had been robbed; I felt, and said I had - I saw the prisoner with two officers.

ROBERT GOOSE
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket, and put it into his breast; I had seen the prisoner before.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to the review; I took my handkerchief out, and wiped my nose - I then put it back, and the officer took hold of me.
The prisoner received an excellent character, and one witness promised to employ him.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 15.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1738.
WILLIAM JOHN PRICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 40 lbs. of butter, value 2l. 16s. , the goods of
Samuel Cullam
, and
William Whitfield
.

WILLIAM HOLMES
. I am a servant to Messrs.
Samuel Cullam
and William Whitfield. butter-factors
, of Old-Bond-street. On the 20th of August, at half-past ten o'clock in the morning, I hung my basket on the area rails of No. 19, Cumberland-place
, while I went down with some butter; I returned in a few minutes - the basket still was there, but 40 lbs. of butter were gone from it; I found the prisoner at the office with it in about three hours - I can swear to the cloth it was wrapped in; the basket was too large to take down the area.

THOMAS SLEETE
. I am a Policeman. Davy gave me information - I apprehended the prisoner in a stable -Davy said he was the man; I found the butter on the steps of No. 9, Frederick-street.

JOHN DAVY. I was in Cumberland-street, and saw the prisoner take the butter out of the basket; he put it on his back, and ran away with it - I followed, and seeing me, he threw it down and ran into the stable - I told Sleete, who took him.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Did he not say the fellow deserved to be frightened for leaving his butter there? A. No - he said if I did not prosecute him he would me.
Prisoner's Defence. It was a lark - the witness must know I never meant to steal it.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

1739.
ROBERT SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 lb. of meat, value 4d.; 16 pieces of leather, value 4s., and 1 pair of boots. value 3s. , the goods of
John Sheldon
.

JOHN SHELDON
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Payne-street, White Conduit-fields. On the 5th of August I sent my little boy to fetch some work from Mr. Lyons, in Amwell-street; he never brought it - I was obliged to pay for it - I do not know the prisoner.

RICHARD SHELDON
. I am the son of the prosecutor. I saw Mr. Lyon put this property into my bag; there was one pound of meat, sixteen pieces of leather, and a pair of boots - I was bringing them to my father's, and saw the prisoner in Penton-street; he said he would give me 3d. to go an errand for him - I said I would; he said I must leave my bag with him - I was to fetch him some clothes from the corner of Vittoria-street, and he would take care of my bag - I was not gone above five or ten minutes; they said they had no clothes; when I came back he was gone with the bag - I never had the 3d; on the 19th of August, I saw him by Islington turnpike, and pointed him out to the constable, who took him.

JOHN SHEEHY
. I am a Policeman. The boy pointed the prisoner out at the turnpike, and said he had stolen his bag of work - I followed him; he looked back, and seeing me and the boy, began to run, but I secured him.

WILLIAM PRATTERO
. I saw the prisoner and prosecutor's son talking in Penton-street, and can swear to his person.
Prisoner. The Policeman said there was a charge against me, and I surrendered - I did not know what I was taken for.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1740.
ELIZABETH FOWLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 table-cloth, value 6s.; 2 candlesticks, value 9s., and 3 brushes, value 1s. , the goods of
John Fowler
.

JOHN FOWLER
. I am the prisoner's father - she went away from me at different times without leave, and on the14th of July, after she had done work, I told her to go and wash herself; I did not see her again till the officer brought me the duplicates of this property - I had promised to give her wages to stay at home; she was with me three weeks the last time - I never allowed her to pawn things; she was not born in wedlock, and I have every reason to believe her mother is the cause of this.

THOMAS FREEMAN
. I am shopman to Mr. Farrell, a pawnbroker, Lisson-grove. The articles stated in the indictment were all pawned by the prisoner on the 14th of July, but at different times.

WILLIAM CONNELL
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 16th of July, in Duke-street, St. James', sleeping at a gentleman's door - she said she did not know where to go; I took her to the station-house, and found these duplicates on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 14. -
Judgment Respited
.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1741.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 watch, value 3l. 10s.; 2 seals, value 2l. 2s.; 2 rings, value 1l., and 2 keys, value 10s., the goods of
William Henry Smith
, in his dwelling-house .

JOHN PHIPPEN
. I am a Policeman. On the 4th of August, at half-past four o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner run out of Mr. Smith's shop, and run along the street - I followed him a long way, and caught him; he had his hand in his waistband - I pulled it out, and he had this watch and seals.

WILLIAM HENRY SMITH
. I am a butcher , and live in Back-road, Shadwell
. On the 4th of August, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I went out, leaving this watch in the room behind the shop; I was fetched in about three quarters of an hour, and they were gone - I gave three guineas and a half for the watch four years ago, one for each seal, and 10s. for the keys; one is only gilt.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY of stealing to the value of 99s. only . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Alderson.

1742.
THOMAS WORLEY
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
James Tulloch
, on the 9th of September , putting him in fear, and taking from his person and against his will, two 20l. Bank notes , his property.

JAMES TULLOCH
. I am carpenter to the Jane of London. Last Friday, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in company with
Ellen Brooks
at a house in Glasshouse-street, and asked her to go over the way to a publichouse to get a glass of liquor, instead of which we went to the prisoner's house; I had two 20l. notes in my fob, and a sovereign, a shilling, and a sixpence in my trousers pocket - the prisoner asked me for some gin; I gave him 1s. - he was not satisfied, and I gave him 2d. more, and then 6d.; he did not get any gin; I went to change my sovereign at the public-house - I returned in a few minutes, and he wanted me to give him money again; I would not- he went to put his hand into my pocket; I would not let him, and he knocked me down - he fell down on me, and while he was on me took my money; before I could get on my feet he had gone out of the house the back way - I had felt the notes safe in his house, and I felt him take them out; I staid in the house a little time, and said to Brooks, "I am done now, my two notes are gone;" I had received my wages, which came to 58l., about a week before - he was taken on Sunday; I had gone to his house twice that night, but he was out - I was as sober as I am now; I had been to a good many places, but to no bad place till I got to this lane.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you know the Compasses? A. Yes, I was there, and had some gin and rum; I cannot say how many glasses I might take - one or two of both, not more, and that was all the day; I had no brandy - I do not think I had any brandy and water, but will not swear it, as I was in the house in the day-time once or twice in the morning, about seven o'clock, and had half a pint of rum then, but only drank one glass; I was at the lodging-house the woman lived at almost all day - I did not go to any other public-house that day; I went there once after seven o'clock, but cannot tell when, and had two glasses of gin; I sent out at the lodginghouse for a good deal of gin, and gave it to the women, but did not take much myself - I spent 1l. at that house, and might have had six glasses myself in the course of the day- I will not swear I did not have a dozen; I did not fall down drunk in the street, nor did a sweep pick me up; nothing of the sort happened - I was found asleep in the privy of the house I stopped at, but that was at nine o'clock, after I was robbed; I was not drunk - they said I was asleep; I do not know whether I was - I never used the word rooping, I do not know what it means; I never said I was rooped - I think it was a young woman awoke me in the privy; it was not much after five o'clock when I went to the prisoner-house - I left my hat in his house, not at the public-house; I did not stay there five minutes after I was robbed - it was in a bed-room down stairs; I found my hat there next day - I had only been with one woman that day; I do not know how many were in the house - I treated about a dozen.
COURT. Q. You treated women in the house on that day? A. Yes, I sent out for liquor for them from time to time.

ELLEN BROOKS
. I was with Tulloch, and went into the prisoner's house with him; he asked me to go out and have something to drink; I refused - he pressed me, and I went; the prisoner was standing at his own door, and called us over, and instead of going to the public-house, we went in: he asked Tulloch to give him something to drink; he gave him 1s.; he said that was not sufficient; he gave him 6d. more, which was all the change he had; as the prisoner brought nothing to drink, Tulloch went to the public-house, and changed a sovereign for half a pint of gin - he returned, and the prisoner began to pull him about; he said he did not like that, and then he knocked him down - I did not see him take the notes, but saw the prisoner upon him.

Q. When did you first see Tulloch? A. He lodged at our house two nights - I was in his company all day; he breakfasted there, and did not leave the house till the afternoon, about half-past four o'clock; I do not think he went out till then, but I was up in my room for half an hour about half-past twelve o'clock in the morning - he was in and out of the different rooms; I went with him about five o'clock to Worley's - the prisoner was not outabove two minutes, before he put his hand into his pocket, and said he was robbed of two 20l. notes; we returned to the prisoner's house, but he was not to be seen, and we returned to my place - he was found asleep at my place- he remained at my place all the evening, except going to see if Worley was there - I went with him; I was at the Compasses public-house with him about a quarter to five o'clock, and two women were there; he treated us to half a pint of gin, and nothing else - I am an unfortunate girl; the Compasses is next door to our house.

WILLIAM PENNY
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on Sunday evening, about eleven o'clock, and found 19s. on him, but no notes; he was standing under a lamp, with a female - he said he was innocent; I said, "Why did you abscond from your house with the woman you have lived with twelve years?" he then began to pretend intoxication; he had a new hat on, and almost all his clothes were new - I knew that, for I was in the habit of seeing him daily.

The prisoner, upon being called upon for his Defence, in a coarse and indelicate statement, represented that the prosecutor and Brookes had come to her house in a complete state of intoxication, and wished for a room, which he refused them, and turned them out of doors; and that he was robbed previous to coming to his house.

JOSEPH GLASS
. I am a chimney-sweeper. On Friday last, about half-past two o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prosecutor laying in the kennel, drunk; his face was bleeding - I picked him up, and a female that was with him; I wiped his face with my handkerchief, and took him to No. 9, Glasshouse-street - it must then have been near three o'clock, and between six and seven o'clock in the evening, I saw him sitting in the necessary, asleep- I and a female helped him out.
COURT. Q. Where is the necessary? A. In the back apartment of the house, No. 9, next door to the Compasses - I was called there to assist him out; he was quite drunk, and could not stand.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you hear him say some wh - s had rooed him? A. He said so when I took him out of the kennel - I am sure he was intoxicated at half-past two o'clock.

JOSEPH COCKNEY
. I am a waiter at the Compasses. Last Friday, about half-past two or three o'clock, I saw the prosecutor in our house - he was neither drunk nor sober, half and half; I saw the sweep pick him up out of the kennel; the left side of his face was scratched; Glass took him to the next house - his hat was under our bar all the night; it was a straw hat - he had it on when laying in the kennel - he came into our house after he was picked up, about three o'clock, and had five or six glasses of brandy and water, and then the landlord refused to let him have more; he went out with another female, returned in ten minutes, and wanted more; he said he had been with a girl, and had been dished - and about halfpast four o'clock, when I took a pot of beer to the next house, he was asleep in the privy.
COURT. Q.When did you hear about this business? A. Not till next day.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Alderson.

1743.
WILLIAM WRIGHT
and
JOHN JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 13 handkerchiefs, value 3l. , the goods of
James William Brown
.

GEORGE GIBBS
. I am in the employ of James
William Brown
, a hosier , in the Strand
. On the 14th of July, about half-past three o'clock, I found the glass of the window broken and thirteen handkerchiefs taken out; I looked round, and the Policeman brought the two prisoners back to the shop - he had some of the handkerchiefs in his hand; I had not seen the prisoners at the window.

JOSEPH MORTON. I am a Policeman. I was on duty, and saw the prisoners standing at Mr. Brown's shop window for about one minute; they then both ran away together; I followed, and took them; Wright took two handkerchiefs out of his bosom, and said, "I found these two, and will give them you - they are not mine;" Jones had nothing; on the way to the watch-house he abused me most scandalously, and struck me twice in the face; I did not see Wright drop any thing, but a gentleman picked up these six handkerchiefs in the Strand, and gave them to me, as I took them to the station-house; Jones got from me, but was secured again.

WILLIAM TREWATHER
. I searched Wright after he was taken, and found five handkerchiefs, between his shirt and skin.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Wright's Defence. I saw something in the window, and thought it was a bill; I looked at it, and a young man who stood there threw the handkerchiefs down - I picked them up, and gave them to the Policeman.
Jones' Defence. I do not know this boy, and was not with him.

WRIGHT -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1744.
JOHN MATHEWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 box, value 1s.; 1 sovereign, 9 half-sovereigns, 120 half-crowns, and 90 shillings, the property of
Sarah Cooper
, in her dwelling-house .
MR. DOWLING conducted the prosecution.

SUSAN COOPER
. I am the daughter of Sarah Cooper, who keeps the Nag's Head, in Hackney-road
. On the 18th of August, about seven o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came there with a person taller than himself, and had a pint of beer; they went away at eleven, came again about two, and had a glass of ale; I then went into the back room, leaving them alone in the front of the bar - I returned in about five minutes, and the prisoner was gone- his companion asked for a glass of gin and water; I went to call somebody to make it, then he said, "Never mind, I'll call again in five minutes," and went away; between four and five o'clock somebody came to borrow some money -I got the till out from under the counter, and there was only five or six new sixpences in it; the money-box was gone - I saw it there between one and two o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Did not the prisoner frequent your house? A. No, never; I have been there two or three years - I am not quite sure the clock had struck three when he left; I was backwards and forwards from the bar to the room behind.

EDWARD COOPER
. I am the son of the prosecutrix. -On the 18th of August, in the afternoon, a woman came toborrow some money; I examined the till, and the tin box was gone, which contained about 25l. in money altogether, besides papers - there were half-crowns in it, one of which I had marked overnight - I gave information to Brown almost directly; when the prisoner was taken I saw three half-crowns, one of which I had marked - (looking at it) I cannot positively swear this is it, but think it is.

Cross-examined. Q.Would he not have to reach over a considerable way to take it? A. No, I could do it - the mark on the half-crown is a scratch on the rim; I made it with my teeth - it is the mark, to the best of my belief; - there were a great many half-crowns in the box, and a bill of 300l.; I have found none of the contents.
MR. DOWLING. Q.What is your belief of the halfcrown? A. To the best of my belief it is the one I marked overnight.

JOHN BROWN I am an officer. I went in pursuit of the prisoner and his companion, and took the prisoner opposite the prosecutor's house on the following morning; I found this half-crown, with three others, and 10s. 6d. in silver besides; I found some keys, which he said belonged to his tool-chest, and went to his lodgings, but there was no tool-chest there.
Cross-examined. Q. You ascertained from himself where he lodged? A. No - the key fitted a box I found there; I found no money.
NOT GUILTY .

1745.
WILLIAM THEED
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 watch, value 50s.; 1 chain, value 5s.; 2 seals, value 5s., and 1 key, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Fuller
.

THOMAS FULLER
. I am servant to Sir William Young. On the 12th of August my watch hung on a nail in the hall about a quarter before eight o'clock in the morning - the hall door was left ajar by a person who had gone out; I saw the prisoner about the middle of the hall - he had no business there; he had just come from the peg - I immediately missed the watch, and followed him - I called to him to stop; he made no answer - I followed him up the area steps; I kept close to him till he was taken - he crossed the street opposite Lady Fitzberbert's, and the watch was found down her area - I did not see it thrown down.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Did you keep in sight of him? A. Yes, all the way - I was eight or twelve yards from him - he might throw it down without my seeing it.

WILLIAM WOOD
. I saw Fuller following the prisoner, who I saw throw the watch down Lady Fitzherbert's area- it was picked up, and given to the Policeman.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. No - I was about three yards from him.

PATRICK CONNOLLY
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge, and went to Lady Fitzherbert's; her servant gave me the watch from the area.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1746.
JOHN FRENCH
was indicted for
manslaughter .

GEORGE HAZLEWOOD
. I am a patrol. On the 23rd of July , about a quarter-past six o'clock in the morning, I was crossing from the south side of Cheapside
to this side of Gutter-lane - I heard a cry, and on looking round saw Hill, who has been killed, close to his cab, about a yard from it, on the Foster-lane side of the street; he had his arms up, as if he had received a violent blow - he immediately fell: I saw that he was very near the wheel of a dray, which was going on towards the Mansion-house; I saw the wheel of the dray come on his body - there were casks on it: I cannot say whether they were full or empty - I did not see any body attending to the horses of the dray; if there had been I think I must have seen; the wheel rested on his body, but did not pass over him - I did not see the driver at all; the dray was backed off by somebody, and I and my brother patrol assisted the deceased to the hospital.

Q. Was there room for the dray to pass at the time? A. I consider that there was not sufficient, as it was between a coach-stand and a coal-waggon, which was next to the footpath, and there did not seem sufficient room for the dray to pass between them; the horse of the cab was not injured, but the shaft was broken, I suppose by the shaft of the dray - the dray was drawn by two horses; I thought the deceased was dead, when we were opposite the Bull and Mouth, but the surgeon at the hospital said he was not- I did not see the prisoner till before the inquest.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You did not see the beginning of this? A. No, the cry first alarmed me; I only saw one dray - Bates and a butcher helped me to put the deceased into a cab - nobody else assisted; I did not see the prisoner, and do not think that he assisted; I do not swear there was not room to pass between the dray and the coach-stand - there did not appear so to me: I am not accustomed to driving - I did not see
Frederick Edwards
there; people gathered round after the man was taken up; I think there were others on the spot - whether they were there before I cannot tell; I might be thirty or forty steps from the deceased when I heard the cry; I was in the middle of the road at the time.

JOSEPH BATES
. I am a patrol, and live in Warwick-lane. I was on duty in Cheapside, on the pavement of the south side, going towards Bow church; I heard somebody scream, and saw the deceased under the wheel of a dray, which I think had four puncheons on it; it was loaded with beer, for I sounded one cask - the off wheel was pressing the deceased along the ground, dragging him along; I could not see the driver - my attention was directed to the man; some man pulled him from the wheel - I came up directly, and the wheel rested on the body, and went back again, not over him; I did not see who drew him from under the wheel - I lifted him up, and took him to the hospital, in his own cab - Hazlewood was so frightened I could scarcely get him to my assistance; I had repeatedly seen the man as a cab-driver; his cab was facing towards St. Paul's - I saw him again between eleven and twelve o'clock, at the hospital, dead; the shaft of the cab was broken on the side that the man had stood with his horse; I took the number of the dray after the deceased was extricated, and then saw a man, whom I believe to be the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you acquainted with the rules of driving? A. Yes; I was on the south side, the driver's proper place would be on the other side of his leading horse, there was another dray stood before - whether that had passed between the waggon and coachstand, I did not see; but it must have passed between them, the cab stood still.

Q. If the cab horse had jibbed towards the north side, might that not have drawn the shaft towards the dray wheel? A. It might - horses on the rank will shift sometimes, and the space of half an inch will bring them closer - the coal-waggon was going on at the time, and the farther it went on the narrower the road got - I cannot say it was not the prisoner who took the deceased from under the wheel; Hazlewood got there before me: my back was towards the dray - how the accident was caused I cannot say; Goodson the driver of the first dray came up, when I was taking the man up; two or three assisted, I cannot say whether the prisoner was one.

ROBERT DARKETT WYATT
. I am one of the housesurgeons at St. Bartholomew's hospital. The deceased was brought in between six and seven o'clock in the morning; he appeared to have received a very severe injury, and died almost immediately - several of the ribs of the right side were fractured and driven into the lungs, which were much lacerated; there is not a doubt the accident caused his death.

BENJAMIN WELLS
. I live in Mercer-alley, Bankside, and am carman to Mr. Elmer, a coal-merchant. I was driving his coal waggon towards the Mansion-house; my waggon was going on at the time of the alarm - it was on the Gutter-lane side; I was at my third horse's head on the foot path side, near the kennel - my wheels were in the kennel; I heard the alarm and stopped my horses immediately; the first thing I saw was their picking the man up - I did not notice whether any body was at the head of the horses of the dray; it had just past between my middle horse and the coach-stand - I did not observe the prisoner at all; when I first saw the cab-man, he was standing at the off side of his horse, on the side nearest to the dray; he and the cab were then quite safe.

Q. Was the cab the first in the rank, or the middle of it? A. It was first on the rank; my waggon and the dray were going in the same direction - the first dray cleared my waggon, except rubbing a little against the chain as it passed; I cannot say whether it went between the cab and my waggon, for I was on my near side, near the shaft horse's head - I saw the first drayman pass me, he had two horses; I did not see the leading horse of the second dray coming, for hearing the alarm I had just time to pull up my horses - I did not see the horse of the first dray till it was stopped.
COURT. Q. Was there a good road on the other side of the way? A. Yes; there was nothing passing just at that time.
MR. CLARKSON. Q.Would that not have been his wrong side? A. Yes, unless there had been a great deal of room - whether the cab had moved after the first dray passed I cannot tell.

JOHN COVENTRY
. I am a coal-porter. I was in Cheapside, standing at the end of Paternoster-row, looking towards Watling-street; I heard a cry out, and saw a man laying before the wheel on the ground - the cab was in the rank, and the coal-waggon standing near; I saw two drays, one had passed the coal waggon, but not the other - I went up, the man was then turned on his back; and the second dray backed a little; several persons were putting the man into the cab - I had seen the drays turn out of St. Paul's churchyard, but not afterward; the drivers were with them then.

CHARLES WEBB
. I drive a cab, and live in Francis-street, Tottenham-court-road. I was talking to the deceased, by the side of his horse, and went from him to my own cab, leaving him standing between his own horse and the pavement, in the middle of the road; my cab was not on the stand - I was on the opposite side of the way; I heard a scream, and saw the deceased down - I did not see him knocked down; the wheel of the dray was on part of his clothes - they could not get him up till the dray was moved; the man driving the dray, to the best of my knowledge, backed the horse; it was the drayman who backed it - he was at the fore horse's head when I first saw him; the dray had passed the cab, and the coal waggon had just passed the cab; I cannot say whether the driver was with his horses at the time they passed the cab, but when I called to him to stop, when I took the man up, he was at his horse's head.

BENJAMIN SIMS
. I am in the employ of the Post-office. I was coming along Cheapside, and saw the coal waggon on the pavement side; I cannot say whether it was moving; the first dray passed on, and as the second approached, I saw the cab-man was in danger, as soon as the first horse passed - he appeared to me, to be leaning on the shaft of his cab, and not to see his danger, till the wheel of the second dray came close to him, nearly in contact with him - I saw his hands extended, as though he was attempting to save himself, by trying to catch hold of the planks which cross the dray; he was so near that the dray wheel was hid from me; I saw him go down - I cannot say where the driver of the dray was; I was some distance off, and before I got up he was released; the prisoner was with his horses when I got up - I believe he was on the off side of his horse, having passed round to where the accident happened; I saw him back his horse as I came up.

MATTHEW IRENOUX
. I am a butcher. I was in Cheapside, in my cart, following behind the two drays; there was a coal-waggon going on in front; I saw the cab on the stand - one dray passed the coal-waggon, the second followed it, but there was not sufficient room to pass - I saw the cab-man just before the second dray came up, standing with his back towards the dray, with his elbow on the shaft - I did not see the driver of the second dray; he was some yards off, on the pavement; the horses were going by themselves - the waggon was between him and his horses I am certain; I saw the front piece of wood which held the first butt of beer strike the man, who could not recover himself, and he was driven on before the wheel about six yards - it was pressing him on; if the driver had been at his horse's head I think he might have stopped the dray before it got on the man's body; I am sure he was on the pavement at the time; I helped to put the man into the cab - the prisoner came up; I told him he had killed the man - he said he was very sorry for it.

Cross-examined. Q. Where do you live? A. In Dorset-street: I am a journeyman butcher - I was working for Mr. Wheel in Leadenhall-market, and keep ahorse and cart of my own; I saw Sims there - he had the same opportunity of seeing what passed as I; he was in the second or third cab - Bates was on the opposite side of the way, the right-hand from St. Paul's - Hazlewood was on that side, and they could not see; I will swear the prisoner was not at his horse's head till after the accident - I never saw the prisoner before; I was the first who got the deceased from under the wheel - the prisoner did not assist till after he was from under it.

Q. When did you observe there was not room for the second dray to pass?" A. As soon as I saw the man knocked down, and not before; I cannot say whether the wheel of the waggon or the cab were touched - my attention was directed to the man who was standing outside the shaft in front of the wheel; I saw the driver of the first dray- I was there before him; I was the first that laid hold of the man; I was much agitated and jumped from my cart - I did not lose sight of the man till he was under the wheel; it happened within twenty yards of Foster-lane; I did not look for the dray-man - I called out as soon as I saw the accident, and the next cab-man called the dray-man (the prisoner); he answered from the pavement, I believe, but I will not swear that, because I was so far away; I did not observe him till he was called - he was on the pavement, I will swear; for I saw him pass the coal-waggon.

THOMAS HAYWARD
. I am a cab-driver. My cab was on the stand, about eight feet from Hill's - I was behind Hill; I saw a coal-waggon, and two brewers' drays; the first dray passed without anything happening - I saw the second come up to the cab - I did not see the driver there, but he might have been there, as I was looking at the deceased, who was leaning on his shaft, and was struck by the dray; he went to lay hold of the iron part of the dray, missed it, and fell under the wheel; the dray went on, and the wheel kept pushing him on; a mob gathered, and I saw him taken up - I had spoken to him just before; he did not appear the worse for liquor; he might have had a glass; the dray-men did their best when they saw what was done, to stop their horses, and rescue him.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the man leaning on the shaft and projecting out towards the road? A. He was leaning on it just at the step; the dray made a kind of slough towards the pavement, and hit him; a brick, or a hole, might have caused it to slough; the dray-man assisted to put the man into his cab, and in getting him from under the wheel; they stopped the moment they were called to.
Q. If the man who drove the second dray was by his first horse, could he see the man who was behind that horse? A. I should think not, unless an alarm was given; there was no alarm till afterwards.

WILLIAM STEPHEN SMITH
. I am shopman to Mr. Lobsey of Cheapside. I was looking out of the second floor window, down towards the cab, which stood nearly opposite our house - I noticed two drays and a coal-waggon coming along; the waggon was first; the first dray passed between the waggon and the cart very close; the waggon was in motion at the time; the second dray had less room to pass, in consequence of the progress of the coal-waggon - I was rather surprised on seeing the second dray come on, that the cab-man, who was leaning on his shaft, did not move, and as it got very near to the cab; the horse of the cab made a little move, which appeared to awaken the man to his danger; he moved from the dray, rather more towards the south side, which gave the drayman room to pass - I thought he had been asleep; he made a sudden start, turned round towards Bow church, and ran, as it appeared, before the wheel of the dray; after going four or five steps I saw his hands extended, and he fell, after which I saw no more - I could not see where the driver of the second dray was, for I was more intent on the deceased.

Cross-examined. Q. Was your house close to where the accident happened? A. Exactly, so that I had a bird's-eye view of it - I should have thought that the dray made noise enough to awake the man before it got to him; there was plenty of time to have moved; in my judgment, it was pure accident; the man ran into danger certainly.

GEORGE GODWIN
. I live in Stacey-street, Seven-dials. I drove the first dray between the coal-waggon and the coach-stand, and passed without difficulty - I was at the head of my horses, and the prisoner was alongside his horses and never went on the pavement - I looked back before the accident, and saw him at his horse's head.

Cross-examined. Q. As you drove your dray through, did you see his approach? A. Yes; drays follow each other as close as possible - I looked back, to guide my horses, saw the man under the wheel, and stopped; the prisoner got hold of his horse's head, and stopped as quick as possible; he went up and assisted the man.
NOT GUILTY .

1747.
RICHARD CHAPMAN
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Henry Gallabin
, on the 12th of August , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 2s., his money .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

HENRY GALLABIN
. I occupy a house in Swan-place, Old Kent-road, and am in the employment of Mr. Marchant, of Ingram-court, Fenchurch-street, printer, and have been so nineteen years, seven of which I was an in-door apprentice. On the 12th of August, 1830, I dined at a venison-feast, in Stationers'-hall - I left the hall about halfpast nine o'clock, perfectly sober - I met the prisoner opposite Apothecaries'-hall - I had never seen him before, but have not the smallest doubt of him; he accosted me as I was going through into Bridge-street, and said, "How do you do?" - I said, "I am very well, but I don't know you;" he said, "That's all nonsense, you know how you and I have been situated, I want 2s. of you, I am out of work" - I told him I had no money to give any one; he said, "I will have it, and will follow you wherever you go" - I was in such fear and tremble at the time, I did not know what to do, and thought I would consult a friend - I had the money, but said I had not - I said, "Here, take my handkerchief, wait here, I will go and borrow the money" - I went to Mr. Rowe's, in Shoe-lane, who keeps the Globe public-house, to ask his advice, but he was from home - I came back, gave him the money, and released my handkerchief, considering it was worth more than the money - I then went towards Blackfriars-bridge; which way he went I do not know, but he did not follow - I saw him several times afterwards, and on the 16th of this month I gave him in charge to Betterton, a Policeman - I had related to Betterton, in his presence, the whole of the transaction which had passed, but did not state to him any thing of the present charge - I was greatly in fear when I gave him the money.
The Court ruled, that the language used on this occasion was not sufficient to constitute the offence charged.
NOT GUILTY .

1748.
RICHARD CHAPMAN
was again indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Henry Gallabin
, on the 6th of September , with intent feloniously and violently to steal from his person his monies .
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating it to have been with menaces, and by force.

HENRY GALLABIN. On the 6th of September, about two o'clock in the day, I met the prisoner as I passed the end of lugram-court - he was waiting under the court; he came up to me, and asked me to give him 3s. - I said,"I've no money, and shall give you none;" I walked about the streets in a zig-zag direction, in order to find an officer - he followed me all the way, and exactly at half-past two o'clock I got to Bow church; he accompanied me all the way, and there he said, "I am not like some people - extorting sovereigns, I merely ask you for 3s.; you may as well give it me at once" - I said, "I shall not give you any thing;" when we got opposite Dolland's, in St. Paul's church-yard, he said, "Do you mean to give me the money?" I replied, "I will not give you any;" he said,"By G-d, I want the money, and if you don't give it me, by G-d you shall not darken those b-y gates again, so do as you like;" I am positive he used those expressions; I was in greater fear than ever then - he is a taller and much more powerful man than me; my mind was in a dreadful state, I hardly knew what I was about; I made my way to the corner of Bride-lane, saw an officer by Poppin's-court, and gave him in charge - I went to the watch-house; he came up close to me there, and said,"Don't do any thing; if you won't, by G-d I'll never trouble you again;" I instantly walked away from him -I am quite certain I never knew him before the 12th of August, 1830 - I was never in any public-house with him, nor ever drank in his company.

Prisoner. I have known him two years; I never asked him to give me any money - I asked him to lend it. Witness. The 12th of August was the first time I ever saw him- he did not ask the 3s. as a loan; I am sure he said if I did not give him 3s. I should never darken the gates again, and while he used that expression he held my left arm.

WILLIAM BETTERTON
. I am a City officer. On the 6th of September, a little before three o'clock in the afternoon, the prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge - I do not think he was near enough to hear what the prosecutor said - when I took him he said he only wanted to borrow the money, he afterwards said he only wanted the lend of it, and afterwards that he did not want to extort it - when I was taking him from the Compter to Guildhall I asked how long he had known the prosecutor - he said about seven or eight years; I am certain of that - he had heard the charge as I took him to the watch-house; what he stated at Guildhall was taken in writing.
Prisoner. Mr. Betterton must be mistaken in my telling him that time, because I did not know him so long; I have been acquainted with him more than two years.

WILLIAM BETTERTON
. I am positive he said so, as it was the only question I put to him.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Life .
NEW COURT. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 15.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1749.
JAMES LEE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July, 1829 , 1 order for payment of and value 21l. , the property of
James Macdonald
, his master.
MESSRS. ADOLPHUS and CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

THE REV. JAMES MACDONALD. I am a clergyman . In 1829 I bought the machinery which had been used for the Steam Washing Company for 1,500l.; I had had some interviews with the prisoner, and on the 29th of June I took him and Smith into my service - their salaries began from that day; they were to have 300l. for the first year, 400l. for the second, and 500l. for the third; it was my intention to remove the articles I had purchased from where they were to the Isle of Dogs, but in July 1829, I had not began to build - I have had large buildings erected there since; I had no place then fixed to meet the prisoner, but I had seen him at the Somerset coffee-house, and he proposed that I should still meet him there - I met him there on the 4th of July, 1829, and he said there were a great many sets of harness, which had belonged to the old company, to be sold a very great bargain, and he had bargained for the purchase of them for 21l. with Mr. De Mole; and he asked me to give him a cheque for it - I drew the cheque which I have now in my hand, and gave it to him expressly to pay for that harness - it is drawn in favour of Mr. De Mole; I left London for Scotland on the 28th or 29th of July - I had given the prisoner a cheque for 50l. for the general purposes of the business, on the 11th of July; and before I left town I deposited in the hands of Messrs. Bosanquets 1000l., to the credit of Junius Smith and James Lee, with joint power to draw with two names to the cheques - I did not tell Smith that I had given Lee the cheques for this harness; he knew nothing of it - it was not till May of the present year that I discovered the cheque had not been paid for the harness.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. This cheque is dated July, 1829? A. Yes; (looking at an account) part of this is my writing; the prisoner had not been in the company's employ previously - Smith left me in July, 1830, and I appointed Captain Wager in Smith's place; the prisoner lived at Lewisham-hill - I preferred two or three indictments last September and four this - I did not complain to any Magistrate respecting this cheque.

Q. Then he appears here for the first time to explain, if any error has arisen? A. Yes, I charged him at Bow-street with embezzlement last April - there were two examinations, and he was dismissed, on account of his bringing forward a book, which he pretended was an account kept for me, and by me which I disowned; the very instant I discovered this charge I went to my solicitor - Iam not aware that three Sessions have passed - I dismissed the prisoner on the 11th of January last; he brought an action against me for wages, which was unjust, and I resisted it - I think that was in March - I proposed to give him 130l. as a settlement of all accounts, if he would stop the action, and he refused, but that was before I knew I was defrauded - he had taken one book away with him when he left; my cheques are generally kept at my bankers' for years, and sometimes I do not demand them for three years or more; I am not a man of business - they were returned to me a week or a fortnight ago- I keep a pass-book, and it is entered in my cash-books - it was proposed to me to refer all matters in dispute to an arbitration, and I agreed, but that was before I discovered the fraud; the prisoner and I very often went over the accounts to see how much had been expended, but not lately, before he left me, for we were not on speaking terms for some months; I do not recollect his telling me I had debited the washing concern with a great many cheques, which had been paid to my private account - I will say he did not say so - this cheque was never applied to my private purposes; there was no other cheque of 21l. about that time; these five items on this paper are my writing; it is a scribbling thing, it is no account: here appears for "Self" marked against them, and "Cheque 21l.; it is one of the items - I did not give any cheque of 21l.; it is my writing, but I do not call it an account - it is a rough scribble, which I might make to see what I might have to receive at a particular banker's hand; this is not the date in question, and probably not the year - here is a cheque of 21l. in Coutts's book, in July 1830, paid to Smart, and that may be the 21l. on that paper.

Q. Is there not on this paper "29th June?" A. Yes, but that means collections received from the beginning to June; there is no last date - it might be written in 1830, for there could be no debts collected till after 1830, as the buildings were not erected; the parties belonging to the harness were bankrupts four months afterwards, but not at the time; I imagined that it was to be delivered to me on payment of the money.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You went before Mr. Hall in April last? A. Yes - Mr. Harmer was then my attorney; I did not then know about this 21l. cheque being stolen -I never drew a cheque in favour of De Mole, except to pay for the harness; the prisoner never informed me it had not been applied for that purpose - there was no private account between us.
MR. ALLEY. Q. The prisoner has not been in custody? A. No, the Court admitted him to bail last Session.

JOSEPH PARTRIDGE
. I am a clerk to Messrs. Coutts. This cheque was paid on the 11th of July, 1829 - (cheque read.)
MR. MACDONALD. I have every reason to think I put a correct date on the cheque when I drew it, which is the 4th of July, 1829.

JUNIUS SMITH
. I was a clerk to Mr. Macdonald with the prisoner. I remember an application being made on behalf of Mr. De Mole for 21l., but am not certain whether it was for harness or the works - the prisoner and I agreed that it should be paid by a cheque; I think that was in August - it was after the prosecutor had gone to Scotland; this is the cheque - the prisoner never told me he had another cheque for the harness; this cheque is on Bosanquet's, drawn by us, in favour of De Mole, for 21l.; it was to be paid out of 1000l. Mr. Macdonald had left there to meet expences while he was in Scotland.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there any secrecy in the prisoner's transactions? A. Not that I saw - I had access to Bosanquet's cheque-book; the prosecutor still holds the concern.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Had you access to Coutts' cheques? A. No.

JOHN BAMBE DE MOLE
. I am an attorney, and live in Threadneedle-street. In 1829 the assignees of the Washing Company sold the property to Matthew Smith; there was some harness; I saw the prisoner several times about it; the harness was sold, or about being sold, to Mr. Smith, for twenty guineas - the prisoner called about the transfer of some property, of which I had no knowledge, and spoke of purchasing the harness, among other things, for himself or Mr. Macdonald - I told him a sale was made to Smith, and I could not well have any thing to do with it; I ultimately received this 21l. cheque on Bosanquet's about the 14th of August, and the receipt was given I think for Mr. Smith, as I was careful not to mix the accounts; I had before refused to receive payment, and wrote to deliver the harness to Smith - I am not aware that the prisoner ever offored me any other cheque, but he offered to pay on several previous occasions, and I refused it; I think the negociation had been pending two months or longer.

THE REV. MR. MACDONALD. The prisoner would not have occasion for more than the 1000l. during my absence- I had given him 50l. besides for general purposes; he had no need to apply this cheque to any other purpose.

JUNIUS SMITH re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner ever pay you 21l., or bring to your knowledge that it had been received by a cheque? A. I was at the building, and he brought me money from town to pay for materials, and work people.
THE REV. MR. MACDONALD. I have books with an account of money paid by Lee to Smith - I am sure this 21l. cheque was not returned to me.

The prisoner in a long address, stated that he had received the 21l. cheque himself, at Coutt's, and offered the cash to Mr. De Mole, as the prosecutor wished his name not be known in the concern - that on its being refused he had given the amount to the prosecutor, and that the prosecutor, on a settlement had acknowledged the receipt, as appeared by the account in question, and there was no other cheques to which the 21l. on that account could apply; that it must be evident if he had committed a fraud he would have taken the 130l. offered, rather than wait for a reference.

MR. MACDONALD re-examined. Q. On this account there is "Self 21l.," and other items - were these sums taken out of any banker's book? A. I think not; I have no doubt this applies to myself in 1830; I think I made them from a private memorandum of my own in 1830; the prisoner never paid me a sum of 21l., or any other sum on any occasion; these figures could not refer to any transaction previous to 1830, as there are collections entered which could not be made till business began - here is on another part of the paper "Hodson 60l." - that might be about the commencement of the works in 1830 - I do not swear that it might not be in 1829; I do not see in my book any account of any other cheque of 21l. - here is one for 21l. 15s. in June, 1830; I am certain he did not return me the money.
JUNIUS SMITH. I cannot say the prisoner did not pay me the 21l. among other monies at the works.

NICHOLAS HEALD
. I am a solicitor. I was employed by the prisoner to proceed against the prosecutor; a proposal was made to arbitrate - the prosecutor's solicitor made an alteration in the draft of the conditions, which Mr. Lee objected to.
NOT GUILTY .

1750.
JAMES LEE
was again indicted for
embezzlement .

THE REV.
JAMES MACDONALD
. The prisoner was in my service - he received money on my account, and paid them to Warner, the book-keeper -
Agnes Nicholls
was a customer: he has not accounted to me for any sums received from her.
Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. He did not account to you? A. No; Mr. Warner is the person he should account to.

AGNES NICHOLLS
. I keep a boarding-school in Kentroad. In December last my linen was washed at the Steam Washing Company - I paid these bills at the office in the Strand, but to whom I do not know; Mr. Warner and another were there, but which wrote the receipt I do not know.
Prisoner. To save trouble I admit they are my writing.

WILLIAM WARNER
. I was in the employ of the Steam Washing Company. The prisoner did not pay me this 2l. 3s. 11/2d., but it has been accounted for since - he gave me some paper about February, and there is a memorandum about Miss Nicholls and others, but he never gave me the money.
Q. When did he leave the service? A. He was in the habit of coming till February - I have not brought the papers here.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. While he was in the office did he inform you of an error to this amount? A. He gave me the papers in February; the prosecutor had forbid his coming to the office then, but he was in the habit of coming and transacting business as usual.

COURT. Q. Did he account to you weekly or how? A. He should account when he received it; it was in the latter end of February that he gave me the papers - he charges himself with this sum, but never paid it; I do not recollect the account being paid.
MR. MACDONALD. The accounts should be communicated to Mr. Warner the same day, and entered.

Prisoner's Defence. There was a great sum of money out - I received monies, and paid them; when Smith was discharged I took charge of the works - Mr. Macdonald came down and sent me to town to receive the accounts, and it is not likely I should account to an inferior clerk; I kept an account of what I received - I received this sum, and stuck the papers on the file, with a quantity of papers, and I overlooked it; in February I went to the file, and seeing these papers, I said, "Warner, I received from Miss Nicholls 2l. 2s. 6d., give me credit for it, I have credited Mr. Macdonald for it in my cash-book" - and the information he has got is from that very cash-book. If I intended wrong him should I have settled it at all?
MR. MACDONALD. I desired Warner to receive mone when I dismissed the prisoner; that was about the 10th of January.
NOT GUILTY .

1751.
JAMES LEE
was again indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of January, 1831 , 1 order for payment of and value 7l. 13s. , the property of
James Macdonald
.
MESSRS. ADOLPHUS and CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

REV. JAMES MACDONALD. The prisoner was in my service in 1830 - on the 6th of January he applied to me for 7l. 13s. 4d. to pay to Halliday and Carter for some ironingblankets; he drew the body of a cheque, and I signed it- this is it - the 4d. is omitted; I gave it to him to pay to Halliday and Carter - it is drawn in their name; on the 24th of April he again applied to me for a sum to pay to them - I think it was 8l. 11s. - I gave him a cheque for that - I did not know what the goods were, nor did I see any bill - I took it from his representation - he wrote the body of this cheque, and I signed it for goods had of the same persons; I discovered that I had paid these two sums on investigating my accounts.
