Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. I believe Messrs. Halliday and Carter live in Coleman-street? A. Yes; I discovered in April or May last that these two cheques had been received.

JOHN PRIOR
. I am clerk to Bosanquet and Co., bankers; I paid this cheque for 7l. 13s. on the 6th of January, 1830.

JEREMIAH CARTER
. I am of the firm of Halliday and Carter - we supplied blankets to the Steam Washing Company in 1830 - I have the books here; on the 2nd of January, 1830, we delivered goods to the amount of 7l. 13s. 4d. - I believe the bill of parcels went with the goods - on the 14th of January we supplied them with six pairs of cards, which came to 1l.; we had no other dealing with them till the 29th of May - we generally allow a discount for prompt payment - the first money we received was on the 23rd of April, 8l. 10s. discount 3s. 4d. - I received it by this cheque - this other cheque for 7l. 13s. I believe was never in my hand till now.

Cross-examined. Q. You have known the prisoner many years? A. Yes - I entered his name in our book as the person to whom the goods were to be delivered, and made out the receipt in his name; this is it - it was given by my clerk; he stated it was on account of a Washing Company, and the gentleman did not wish his name to be known - I knew nothing of Mr. Macdonald, but he afterwards called on me and told me to make out the account to the Washing Company; the whole of the balance has not been paid to me.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q.Had you received any money for goods between January and April? A. No - the balance not yet paid is a subsequent account. (Cheques read).

MR. ALLEY to MR. MACDONALD. Q. You had no account with this house till after these goods were purchased? A. No - I was arrested at the prisoner's suit, I think in March; it was before that I called on Messrs. Halliday and Carter to order the alteration to be made in the bills, as I had found out various things.
MR. ALLEY to MR. CARTER. Q.Could it have been so early in March that he called? A. I cannot say, but I think not.

MR. ALLEY to MR. MACDONALD. Q.Upon your solemn oath, was it not after you were arrested that you called? A. No, before - there was a bill of particulars delivered by my attorney; I pleaded a set-off, and was ordered to give the particulars of my account - I did give this very sum of 7l. 13s. 4d. in my set-off originally, and afterwards I amended it; after I had preferred my bill of indictment last Session, I gave in the amended particulars, omitting the sum for which I had indicted him - till I preferred the indictment it remained a matter of set-off against the claim he had for wages against me; I then altered it by omitting it - my solicitor advised it should be left out, for the purpose of sustaining the indictment.
1830, January, Cash to pay Halliday and Carter's bill, but returned, 7l. 13s. 4d.
Prisoner's Defence. When I saw that the cheque of 7l. 13s. was charged to me, I naturally concluded that it had been given to me, and I gave Mr. Macdonald credit for it.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Nine Months .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner, on which MR. ADOLPHUS declined to offer any evidence.

1752.
THOMAS JAMES
was indicted for
bigamy .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JAMES HILL
. I am vestry-clerk to St. James, Clerkenwell. I produce an examined copy of the register of the marriage, in the church of St. Philip and St. James, Bristol, and likewise an extract of the register of St. James, Clerkenwell - I have compared them both with the books, and they are correct.

STEPHEN JONES
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Gloucestershire. I know the prisoner; I was at his wedding at the church of St. Philip and St. James, Bristol; I think it will be sixteen years ago in October - he married
Martha Short
; I knew them living together as husband and wife for two or three years - I believe they had three or four children; I was overseer of the parish at the time - I saw his wife at my house on the 27th of August last.

MARIA WARBOYS
. I married the prisoner at Clerkenwell church on the 4th of October, 1825 - he lived with me two years, and it will be four years on the 25th of October next since he was taken by the Bristol officers on account of his first marriage; I did not know at the time of our marriage that he had a wife - the officers told me of it; I then asked him to tell me, and he said it was so.

JAMES WARBOYS
. I am the brother of Maria Warboys; I gave her away on her marriage to the prisoner - he always denied having a wife; my mother told him she had been very nearly bit two or three times, and she hoped she would not again - this was the night before the marriage; he positively denied having been married before.

Prisoner. I was drinking at a public-house all night -I was taken from there to church; I had not a single farthing - she paid for all. Witness. It is quite false - my sister had not a farthing in her pocket, and I am sure I did not pay.

SAMUEL MOUNTSTEVENS
. I am a beadle of Clerkenwell. I removed the prisoner and his family to Gloucestershire in May last; in going down his wife was troubling him, as she was fearful they would go to Bristol, and find his other wife - he told her to be quiet, she had nothing to fear.(The certificates were put in and read.)

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Six Months .

1753.
FREDERICK HILLYER
was charged, on the Coroner's Inquisition, with
manslaughter .

DIANA STEED
. I live in Salmon-lane, by Limehouse church. On the night of the 8th of September, which was the Coronation day, I was standing at our door, seeing the fire-works - the prisoner lived in my mother's house; I recollect a scuffle for some fire-works - a little boy named
Thomas Allen
was trying to get some of them; he was knocked down in the crowd, just as the prisoner crossed the road with a gun under his arm; Allen was getting up suddenly - he hit his head against the muzzle of the gun; it went off, and he was shot - he fell dead on the ground; the prisoner was taken into custody - he told the officer he was the man who did it, he was carrying his gun under his arm, with the muzzle pointed to the ground; I had seen him fire the gun in the course of the evening, but upon those occasions he raised the muzzle so that the contents went into the air - he dropped down immediately, and never moved afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you not been holding a stick, with a catherine-wheel upon it? A. Yes - it fell off, and that occasioned the scramble among the little boys; it appeared to me to be quite an accident: the prisoner called out immediately, "Oh, my G-d! the child is killed!"

EDWARD ALLEN
. I am the father of the deceased - his name was William Edward; he was ten years old last January - I was not there at the time, but I ran to the place, about twenty minutes afterwards, and saw him laying on the floor in a shop, dead.

WILLIAM SPINK
CUMMING. I am a surgeon. I was applied to to examine the child's head, in his father's presence; there were several causes which were sufficient to produce death - the carotid artery and the nerves were divided, and a great quantity of blood effused; that would have occasioned death - I saw him in about a quarter of an hour after the accident, but did not examine his head that night; in my judgment, the division of the carotid artery and the nerves was the immediate cause of his death; the explosion of gunpowder would have occasioned it; but I also found some wadding in the bottom of the wound, which was from one inch and a half to two inches deep.
NOT GUILTY .

1754.
BENJAMIN SILVESTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 live tame goose, price 5s. , the goods of
William Tillyer
.

ELIZABETH TILLYER
. I am the wife of
William Tillyer
- we live at Bedfont
. On Sunday evening, the 21st of August, I heard my two geese making a noise; I sent my daughter to fetch them in, and we missed a brown goose.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You had only two? A. No; I had seen the prisoner that day - I believe he was forward in liquor.

CHARLOTTE TILLYER
. I am the daughter of the lastwitness. When we missed one of the geese I followed the prisoner, and overtook him with it in his hand; I asked him to give it to me - he refused, he pushed me out of the pathway and threw the goose into a ditch; it was not quite dead then - the prisoner had a dog; he called the dog, and set it at me - it did not bite me; I got the goose, and took it home - I think he was in liquor; he was not above one hundred yards from our house then.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not see the dog attack the goose? A. No; the dog was before him, but he had the goose in his hand.
Prisoner's Defence What she says is all false; I never saw the goose till it was brought into a public-house where I was taken.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1755.
THOMAS WILLIAM BEARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 coat, value 20s. , the goods of
James Laing
.

CHARLES WALKER
. I am servant to Mr. John Michael, of St. Albany's hotel, Charles-street, St. James'-square
. On the evening of the 28th of August I placed a coat on a table in the house - it belonged to Captain James Laing, who was lodging in the house; I went down to clean the boots, and on returning I found the coat which the prisoner has on, laying on the stairs, but Captain Laing 's coat was gone; I had seen the prisoner standing in the tap-room when I went down; he came there again at half-past eight o'clock in the evening, with the captain's coat on.

Prisoner. I took it by mistake, instead of my own, and went back to rectify it. Witness. He did not tell me of it when he came back - he had no business to go into the room where the coat was; when I gave him into custody he said he had made a mistake - he walked into the tap-room, looked round, and was coming towards the door, as if to go out again, and I stopped him.

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner with this coat on; he owned his own coat directly - I found in the pocket a begging letter, in his own name, and a quantity of broken victuals.
NOT GUILTY .

1756.
MARGARET BRANDON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 51/2 yards of printed cotton, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Nichols
.

JOHN CORNELIOUS. I live with my parents, in Field-lane, Holborn. On Saturday, the 2nd of July, I was in Gray's Inn-lane
, selling water-cresses - I saw the prisoner go to Mr. Nichols' shop, and pull down a piece of print, tuck it under her clothes, and walk away - I told the shopman; he followed her, and took hold of her arm - she then dropped the cotton.

WILLIAM WOOD
. I was shopman to the prosecutor. In consequence of what I heard I went and stopped the prisoner in Fox-court, and the cotton fell from her clothes - she walked back with me a little way, then dragged herself from me; she got into a passion, and struck me several times, with such violence as to make me let her go - when she got into Gravel-lane the Police-officer came up, and took her.

HUGH CASH
. I am an officer. I received charge of the prisoner; I saw her strike the witness very violently, and her hands were bleeding; I took her to the watch-house - she wanted to make it up, and said she knew what she had done, that she had been guilty of shoplifting, and she should be committed to Newgate - I did not perceive she was intoxicated.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the cotton, but I was a little in liquor, or I should not have done so.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1757.
HENRY COUNT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 152 buttons, value 3s. , the goods of
John Doland
and
Lawrence Doland
, his masters.

The firm consisting of
John James Doland
and Lawrence Doland, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1758.
JOSEPH DEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 seal, value 10s. , the goods of
Simon Kleyser
.

SIMON KLEYSER
. I am a clock-maker , and live in Coppice-street, Clerkenwell. I was at the Harrow public-house, on the 29th of August; I lost a gold seal, suspended to a ribbon, but I had not seen the prisoner at all that evening, and there is no other witness here.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1759.
WILLIAM COCKLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Whatley Venn
, from his person .

JOHN WHATLEY VENN
. I am of no profession. I was in Upper Grosvenor-street
on the 11th of July - I had a pocket-handkerchief in my pocket; I did not miss it, but I was spoken to - I turned round, saw the prisoner scuffling with the officer, and one of them was picking up my handkerchief from the ground.

THOMAS GOOK
. On the 11th of July I saw the prisoner at the review; I watched him for an hour, and saw him try several gentlemen's pockets - he took a handkerchief from one gentleman, who turned round, took it from him, and struck him on the head - he then went to the prosecutor, and took his handkerchief; I told the prosecutor he was robbed, and secured the prisoner - Lindley picked up the handkerchief.

SAMUEL LINDLEY
. I saw the prisoner draw the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket, and throw it down- I picked it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Months .

1760.
GEORGE DALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 18d., the goods of
Robert Fletcher
, from his person .

ROBERT FLETCHER. On the 14th of August I was coming down the Commercial-road
; I did not miss my handkerchief till the officer told me of it.

JOHN THOMAS
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief out of the prosecutor's pocket - my brother officer took him; he dropped the handkerchief, and I picked it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Months .

1761.
WILLIAM EDWARDS
and
ELIZABETH EDWARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August 17 lbs. of feathers, value 25s. , the goods of
George Armstrong
.

SARAH ARMSTRONG
. I am the wife of
George Armstrong
- we live in Ironmonger-row, St. Luke's
. The two prisoners took our back parlour, furnished, on the 2nd of August - they left on the 20th, and the next day I found the bed had been opened; a week before they left the female borrowed a needle of me, and returned it with a piece of black thread in it - I found the bed had been sewn up with the name kind of thread; we had weighed the bed when they came - there were then 50 lbs. of feathers, and when they were gone it weighed 17 lbs. less - when the female was taken she told the Policeman we could not do any thing with her, because we did not see her take them; she was taken on a charge of stealing feathers - they owed us 5s. when they went away.

CHARLES SCOTCRMER. I am an officer. On the 21st of August I took the female prisoner, and told her it was for stealing feathers - she said they could not hurt her, for they did not see her do it - on the 23rd I took her husband - he said he thought it not worth his while to stay away any longer, that he heard she was remanded for a week, and he therefore gave himself up.

E. EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Six Months .

W. EDWARDS -
NOT GUILTY .

1762.
ELIZABETH GRIFFEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 10 handkerchiefs, value 35s. , the goods of
John Veall
.

GEORGE LEWIS HOWES
. I am in the employ of Mr.
John Veall
, linen-draper , of Islington
. On the 12th of July the prisoner came to the shop, and asked to look at some silk handkerchiefs; she appeared very respectable, and we showed her some - she had six cut off; she selected articles which came to about 4l., which she desired might be sent to Goulden-terrace, at half past two o'clock, and said she would leave 8s. deposit; she had a boy with her, and I suspected she had some handkerchiefs - I followed her about ten yards, and asked her what she had in the bag; she said I should not see; I was taking her back, and she attempted to run away - I brought her back, and the officer took her; these ten handkerchiefs were found on her - I asked her reason for doing so, she said, "Bad luck."(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner handed in a petition, for a lenient sentence. She received an excellent character.
GUILTY Aged 23.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Confined Six Months .

1763.
MARIA HEMLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 shawl, value 8s. , the goods of
Grace Roberts
.

GRACE ROBERTS. I keep a coffee-shop , in Widegate-street, Bishopsgate
. On the 1st of September the prisoner came and I trusted her with bread, butter, and coffee, which came to 6d.; she came again on the 2nd, and asked me to trust her again which I did - and when she was gone I missed my shawl; she was taken at twelve o'clock the same night.
CHARLES STILL. I am in the employ of Mr. Wood, a pawnbroker, in Union-street East, Spitalfields. I produce a shawl, which I took in of the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been drinking and did not know what I was doing; I pawned the shawl to get me a lodging, thinking it was my own.

GUILTY . Aged 55.
Transported for Seven Years .

1764.
JAMES FORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 30 penny-pieces, and 60 half-pence , the monies of
Henry Pye
.

HENRY PYE
. I keep the sign of the St. Luke's Church, Wenlock-street, St. Luke's
; the prisoner has lodged with me for the last ten or twelve months. On the 19th of August I remember he went out about eleven o'clock in the evening, to get a little money owing to him - I expected him back that evening, but he had no key to let himself in - he used to get over the wall sometimes, and get in at his own bed-room window; the Police-officer called me up about two o'clock, and said somebody was in the house - I was going down stairs, and saw the prisoner on the stairs; I said, "Jem, how can you be so foolish, why did you not call me up, without knocking at the door, and making a bother with the Policemen?" I let the Policemen in at the back door - they said somebody had been in the bar - I opened the bar, and missed a 5s. paper of halfpence; it was safe about half an hour before I went to bed - I was in the tap-room when the prisoner was searched, but I cannot say, from the fright I was in, whether I saw the Police-officers take a bundle from him, but I heard it smack down on the table; I have no doubt it came out of the prisoner's pocket - I believe it is what I had taken for 5s.; I had locked the hat, but there is a sort of half-door, which a person might lift up and unbolt one holt, and any little thing would unbolt the other; the Policemen found this wire in the tap-room, it had come from a window of the stairs, where we keep empty cans; we found a candle in a gin measure; it was not there when I went to bed.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe the prisoner apprised you of his going out that night? A. Yes; he went to a person who owes both him and me some money, and he was to receive my money as well as his own; I will not venture to swear to the money or this paper - this money was outside the till - the prisoner did not appear confused; this was on Sunday morning, at two o'clock - workmen are frequently paid in copper on Saturday - there was only 1d. more found on him.

COURT. Q. Do you believe that to be your money? A. I do not know what to say about it - I think it is, but I cannot swear to it - the paper is a good deal like the one I had - there was but one paper of copper in my bag - I had two others that evening, but emptied them; I said before the Magistrate that I could not swear to the property.

JOHN MORLEY
. I am a Police-officer; I was passing the house - I heard a kind of bolt or lock move backwards and forwards - I then heard a door open, and what I thought, was somebody in the bar; I stood, and then heard some person come towards the window - I then heard money rattle, as if a person was opening a till - I called my serjeant - we knocked at the next house, and asked them tolet us go in the yard; the serjeant placed some men round the house - I got over the wall - I knocked at the back floor, the landlord came down - I heard the prisoner say to him."It is only me, tell the Policeman it is all right;" I told the landlord I heard somebody in the bar - he would hardly believe me; I said to the prisoner, "You have been in the bar" - he said, "Me been in the bar?" - I said Yes; the bar-door was open, and the top part fell down - I saw this piece of candle in a measure, the cotton of it was quite warm; Mr. Pye said, "5s. worth of copper is gone;" I looked at the till, and saw marks of violence on it, and a piece broken off it; I searched the prisoner, and found this paper of halfpence in his pocket, and dashed them on the counter.

Cross-examined. Q.Did not the landlord say that he was in the habit of coming in that way, and that it was all right? A. Yes, he did; there is no mark on the paper - the landlord and the prisoner appeared excellent friends; we had thrown stones at the landlord's window before we knocked, as we did not wish the person in the bar to hear.

WILLIAM STANNARD
. I am a Police-serjeant; Morley called me - I heard a rattling inside the bar - we alarmed the landlord - I went in, and saw the prisoner in the taproom, without his shoes; Mr. Pye said, "He is my lodger, it is all right;" I said, "We must search the bar;" before his unlocking the half door of the bar, the shutter dropped down, the bolts having been drawn; we secured the prisoner - he pulled out this copper - Mr. Pye said, "These are my coppers, I can swear, by their being tied with one string;" I asked the prisoner how he came by them; he said he should not satisfy me.

Cross-examined. Q.Did he not say, "Here are 5s. worth of coppers," and put them on the table? A. Yes; I found some keys in the prisoner's room - one of the landlord's door, and one of the cellar; a person could enter the bar by getting down the shutters, without opening the door; I found eight gilt farthings on the prisoner; I gave them back by the Magistrate's desire.
Prisoner's Defence. I got in in the usual manner, and the noise which I think the Policeman heard, was occasioned by some cans rolling down stairs, when I pushed the window open.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1765.
JOHN HINDLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 1 hearth-rug, value 10s., and 1 table-cover, value 10s. , the goods of
John Heath
.

ANN HEATH
. I am the wife of John Heath. I live in White Conduit-fields
. On the 3rd of September I hung a rug and table-cover on the rails of my door while I was sweeping the passage; the prisoner had been standing about the street some time - I saw him stoop down at the door, as I thought, to catch the cat; in a minute my neighbour said, "That man has taken your things" - I pursued and saw him with them on his right arm - I said,"Put them down" - he threw out his left hand, and struck me across the throat, but I still pursued, calling Stop thief! and he was secured.

ROBERT ALLEN
. I was standing at my window; I heard a cry of Stop thief! - I saw the prisoner running with the things - I pursued him down Copenhagen-street, and took him.

JAMES SHEEHY
. I am an officer. I heard the alarm; I took the prisoner - I found on him two keys, a screwdriver, and a knife.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1766.
JAMES KELLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 1 smith's tool, called a stock, and 1 set of dies, value 4l. , the goods of
William Chambers
.

WILLIAM CHAMBERS
. I am a smith , and live in High-street, Shadwell. On the 16th of June I missed a stock and set of dies from Jewin-street
- the prisoner had worked for me.

TIMOTHY PERRY
. I am assistant to Mr. Matthews, a pawnbroker, in Whitecross-street, I took in a stock and dies from the prisoner on the 16th of June.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you known him before? A. No; I think they were pawned in the afternoon - I will not swear what time it was, but I recollect the circumstance, because he told me he had made them for a customer, and was to have 50s. for them; I cannot tell whether he had a great coat on, nor what cravat, but I can swear to the man - he was ten or fifteen minutes in the shop; I did not attend exclusively to him - he pawned them for 10s., in the name of
James Skinner
, Old-streetroad.

MARY LATTER
. I live with Mr.
William Chambers
. On the 16th of June the prisoner came to ask Mr. Chambers to let him have this article to do a job; Mr. Chambers was not at home - Mrs. Chambers said she thought he would have no objection, and she let him have it.

MARY ANN CHAMBERS
. The prisoner came to our house, and I lent him this article.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you the wife of the prosecutor? A. Yes - I knew the prisoner from his coming to work there; he had done work for himself at our shop - he has been industrious, and I believe he has a large family(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 65.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Confined Six Months .

1767.
SARAH HOOKER
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 7th of May , 16 lbs. of silk warp, value 24l., the goods of
William Abbott Kent
, well knowing it to have been stolen .

JAMES HADFIELD
. I am foreman to Mr. William Abbott Kent - he lives in Wilson-street, Finsbury
. I live in his house, and on the morning of the 7th of May, I missed sixty or seventy pounds of silk from the wires: my desk had been broken open, and about 12l. in cash taken from it - a square piece had been cut out of the back warehouse shutter with a centre-bit - a hand had been introduced, and the shutters opened; I discovered the robbery about five o'clock in the morning, and saw part of the property at Bishopsgate watch-house, about seven o'clock - I had not seen the prisoner near the house.

SARAH FULLER
. I am the daughter of
John Fuller
- we live in King-square. I am a bonnet-maker; I had been up nearly all the night, working for my mother - about a quarter before four o'clock that morning I looked towards a dust-hole, which led towards the back of Mr. Kent's premises, and saw two men, the prisoner,and another woman, at the dust-hole against the wall; the prisoner had one basket on her head, and another in her hand - each of the two men took a parcel out of the dusthole; one of the men took two parcels wrapped up in brown paper, and put them both into the prisoner's basket- her bonnet fell off; one of the men said, "Never mind your bonnet;" she said, "I must have it," and the other woman took it up, and put it on her head - the prisoner said to the men, "Now, you cut;" they all four went away together - the other woman carried the small basket to the corner of the court, and then the prisoner took them both again - I followed them down Horse Shoe-alley into Long-alley, and then gave information to a private watchman; he pursued them as far as Catherine Wheel-alley, Bishopsgate-street - I am quite sure the prisoner was one: there are two or three yards to cross from where the dust-hole is to the prosecutor's yard, but it will lead there.

Cross-examined. Q. Is that a convenient spot to get to the prosecutor's house? A. They can get that way - it is about fifty yards off; all the four persons seemed to be engaged in the same transaction - it was day-light; they were not there more than five minutes before I followed them - the prisoner did not take the parcel from the dusthole; she stood about four yards off.

JOSEPH RYAN
. On the morning of the 7th of May I received information, about half-past four o'clock that the prisoner had some property - I saw her carrying a basket, and another woman and two men with her - I met a private watchman, and he joined me in the pursuit; when they got to Bishopsgate-street, they crossed over towards Petticoat lane - when we came up to them they all ran; the prisoner was taken, with this property.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you found out that she is married? A. I have heard so.

JAMES CASTLE
. I am a watchman of Bishopsgate ward. On the morning in question I pursued the prisoner to Bishopsgate-street: there were two men and another woman, who made their escape - the prisoner had this basket and this property on her head.

JAMES PAYNE
. I was on duty at Bishopsgate watch-house. I received the prisoner in charge with this bundle of silk, and the basket.

MILES HANLEY
. I am an officer. I went to the prosecutor's premises, and found they had been opened by means of a hole made with a centre-bit - I found this dark-lantern - this centre-bit, and this piece of wood there.

JAMES HADFIELD
. I know this is Mr. Kent's property- here is a mark on this bundle, in his hand-writing, which I can swear to.
Prisoner's Defence. My husband told me to carry it- I did not know what it was.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
OLD COURT. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 16.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1768.
GEORGE CLAYTON
was indicted for
embezzlement ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 12. -
Judgment Respited
.

1769.
WILLIAM TUBBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 4 yards of silk, value 50s., and 10 yards of silk warp, value 6s. , the goods of
Samuel Apling
.

DANIEL APLING
. I am foreman to my brother Samuel, a silk manufacturer , of Spital-square. On the 18th of July I delivered to Rattery this warp and shoot to work - she worked at the prisoner's house, in Quaker-street
; on the 29th of July she came and stated that it was stolen during the night or early in the morning; I went to the prisoner's house that morning, about halfpast eight o'clock, and asked how he supposed it had been stolen; he said the thieves must have broken in at the back door - I found it had been cut out of the loom -I examined the back door; there was not the slighest appearance of violence - I heard Rattery say, in the prisoner's presence, that Woodcock did not sleep in the house that night - he did not contradict her.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe about this time there were a great many depredations committed on looms? A. Not within a year and a quarter - the prisoner was given into custody in about an hour.

JANE RATTERY
. I work at the loom, and live at the prisoner's house - he is my uncle; he is a weaver . Woodcock used to lodge there, but did not sleep there on the 28th or 29th of July; I finished about twenty-four yards of silk, and had about one hundred yards of warp - I left about nine o'clock at night on the 28th, leaving it safe; I slept in Pope's Head court - I went next morning about seven o'clock, and the silk was gone - when I left there was nobody in the house but the prisoner and a strange man - I told the prisoner I was not coming back, and he said he should not go out that night: on my missing the silk I told the prisoner I thought he had done it - he turned round, to a man who sat there, and said, "There is a b-h;' somebody asked where Woodcock was - the prisoner said he did not sleep there that night.

Cross-examined. Q. At what time did you tell the prisoner that he had done it? A. About eight o'clock - he remained at home till he was taken - I did not sleep there that night, because his wife was absent, and I did not like to be where so many men were constantly coming.

HARRIET TIMS
. I live in this house; the prisoner rents it, and occupies two rooms above me. Before Rattery left, the prisoner came down, and told me he was not well and should go to bed, would I fasten the door; the street door stood open from that time till ten minutes past ten o'clock - I bolted the back door inside; I went to bed between ten and eleven o'clock, and about eleven o'clock the prisoner was taken ill; he came down, and asked me to give him a light - he went into the yard, returned in a few minutes, and I heard him bolt the door after he came in; I heard a noise about two o'clock, or a little after, in the passage - I called out, "Is that Tubbs?" somebody answered, Yes - I cannot say whose voice it was, for I was hardly awake; I said "If it is you, will you fasten the door?" he came about seven o'clock, knocked at my door, and said he had lost his work, and that he had found the back door open.
NOT GUILTY .

1770.
THOMAS BARNETT
and
JOSEPH MILLER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , 3 sheets, value 1l., and 1 table-cloth, value 9s. , the goods of
Thomas Tribe
.

CHARLOTTE TRIBE. I am the wife of Thomas Tribe, and live at Uxbridge
. These articles I hung out to dry -I saw them safe about six o'clock in the evening, and in the morning they were gone - I knew the prisoners by sight.

WILLIAM FLETCHER
. I am a baker. I met the prisoners between seven and eight o'clock in the evening of the 13th of July, about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's house, in company together; Miller had a bundle - I asked what they had got - he said he did not know; I asked to see it - he put the bundle down; I opened it, and found this wet linen in it - I took them both in charge; I have seen them in company before, and know they are companions.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Barnett's Defence. A boy asked me to go bird's nesting, and these things laid on the common - he took them up, and as we came along Fletcher met us; I had told him to take them to his mother and have them cried.

BARNETT -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

MILLER -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1771.
JOHN BLACKERBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of March , 1 weather-glass, value 20s.; 2 brushes, value 1s.; 2 gowns, value 1s.; 1 piece of carpeting, value 1s.; 1 Bible, value 10s.; 1 coat, value 3s.; 1 chest of drawers, value 1l.; 3 pairs of sheets, value 10s.; 3 spoons, value 6s.; 1 bed, value 3l.; 1 counterpane, value 6s.; 10 lbs. of starch, value 13s.; 40 gallons of varnish, value 22s.; 1 writing-desk, value 10s., and a variety of other goods, the goods of
William Dalton Gibbs
, in his dwelling-house .

WILLIAM DALTON GIBBS
. In March last I lived in Kendal-mews. I took a shop and parlour in Duke-street, Lisson-grove
, and sent my furniture there on the 23rd of March, but did not sleep there till the night after the robbery, nor did any of my family; there were lodgers in other parts of the house. Plummer, who lived next door to me, volunteered to go with the van which Summerfield drove; I was not present when it was loaded - I do not know where Plummer is - I was in a situation at that time; I went home on the morning of the 24th, in consequence of information - my wife having gone with the rest of the things, I went to Plummer's to breakfast, and then went to Duke-street -I then went with my wife and Warren, the officer, to the prisoner's house in Middlesex-mews; I there found a weather-glass behind a table, two brushes in a box, and a coat which I have now on - I did not know the prisoner.

JANE GIBBS
. I was present, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, on the 23rd of March, when the van was loaded to take some things to Duke-street - I saw a bed and mattress, a chest of drawers full of linen, two wooden chests, a quantity of varnishes in carboys, and three bundles of clothes - my husband's coat was in one chest; Summerfield drove the van - Plummer went with him; he offered to go of his own accord - he kept a beer-shop next door to us: I do not know where he is now - I went myself about ten minutes after the van left - I got to Duke-street, and found the house-door fastened; the van was not there - I looked through the key-hole, and saw a carboy there; I came home, and got the key of the parlour from Plummer; I went again between eight and nine o'clock the next morning, with another load of goods; another man drove that van - Plummer went with me; he took the key from me, and when I went in there was nothing left but an empty carboy and can; I received information, and went to find out the prisoner's place; as I stood in Mitcham-street I saw some of my things coming out of a stable in Middlesex mews; a woman and a boy were bringing them out -I saw a man in a cart which had some of my goods in it; I cannot say whether it was the prisoner - there was a mattress in the cart, a table, a chest, and a fender - they were part of the things which had been in the van; I have heard the stable belonged to the prisoner - the things were in the cart when I got there; I left it there, and went for assistance - I returned with Lock, the Policeman, and the cart was gone; we went in search of it - I missed Lock, and then met Harrison; we came down to the stable, and knocked at the door; some children looked out of window, and refused to open it - we got in, and found a bundle inside, tied in a shawl; it contained linen, mere rags, pieces of my own, which I can swear to - I found some of my children's clothes up stairs in a chest - here they are, and this weather-glass is ours; all these things were in the van which I sent on the 23rd of March.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.What was Plummer? A. He kept a beer shop - he is not related to us, but was rather intimate with my husband; he appeared respectable - we had only lived there three months; he has absconded.

WILLIAM SUMMERFIELD
. I drove the van on the 23rd of March, and deposited all the goods in a shop and parlour in Duke-street - three men went with me, and while I was doing up my cords the door was shut, and we all came away together.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it not clear day-light? A. It was.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I am a Policeman. I went with Mrs. Gibbs to Middlesex-mews - two children answered us from the window; I got in, and in the stable found a shawl, with things tied in it - I went up stairs, and in a room, under the bed, found a carpet, and in a box some children's clothes and two brushes; in a basket under the bed eight books - in the next room I found the weatherglass behind the table, and two gowns; Mr. and Mrs. Gibbs claimed the things - I do not know whose house it was; nobody was there but the children - I do not know the prisoner.

MARY SMITH
. I live in Bone's-mews, Richmond-street, and have known the prisoner thirteen years. In March last he lived in Middlesex-mews; he had a stable and rooms above it - he is married, and has three children. On the 24th of March, about ten o'clock in the morning, he drove a horse and cart into our mews - he came up, and asked me if we had an empty stable; I told him No, and asked what he wanted it for - he told me to get up and see, and when I went to the window I saw a mattress and furniture in his cart, and said I thought he had better bring them up stairs, which he did - I asked where his wife was- he said at home; I said, "What, in an empty room?" he said, "No, they are not my things, but we are boundto assist each other;" he went away with his horse and cart, leaving the things in my room, and never came for them; Webster took them away three or four days after.

Cross-examined. Q.You was well acquainted with him? A. Yes, for some years - we had often been to his house; I know the cart was his own - I never knew him employ his cart to move goods; his name is on it - it was snowing at the time; I said, as it snowed he had better bring them in; we were at breakfast, and he took a cup; the goods were not covered. I live about a mile from Duke-street.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I am a Police-officer. I have known the prisoner for seven years - he lived in Middlesex-mews, and was a dealer in marine-stores; I went to Smith's about a fortnight after the robbery, and found a quantity of goods; I had them in my possession nearly two months - most of them are here; here is the Family Bible and a writing-desk; I looked for the prisoner from the 24th of March - I made every endeavour to apprehend him, day and night, and could not find him till the 26th of July, when I found him in the Bartholomew Arms new beer-shop, Long-lane; I said, "Well, Jem, I suppose you are aware what I want you for;" he said, "I don't know much about it;" I told him it was for Gibbs' robbery, in Duke-street, and he must go with me - he said, "Very well," and as we came along he said he knew nothing about it, only he was employed to move the goods - he said he had come that morning from Portsmouth, by the coach, with a person whom I knew.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say something, in consequence of which you went to look for a person? A. He did - I have searched Plummer's house, and cannot find him; I did not know him - the prisoner pointed out a place to me at Battle-bridge, where he said two loads of the goods were deposited; I found none of them.
MR. GIBBS. I can swear to this writing-desk and Bible.

MARY SMITH
. That desk was in the cart.
THOMAS HARRISON. I went to Middlesex-mews; the room up stairs appeared like an old iron-shop - there were scales and weights, and different old iron about.

Prisoner's Defence. I had left off dealing in marinestores six or eight months, and kept a horse and cart to move goods; the scales were to weigh goods which I buy-Plummer and his friend came and asked me to move the goods; I was engaged, and said it was not convenient, but he pressed me, and I went.

DAVID JENKINS
. I am a Policeman. I do not know Plummer - I recollect seeing some goods coming out of a cart or van in Upper Edward-street, Battle-bridge, about the end of March, and I asked when they were going to open the beer-shop, as I had noticed some new pots go into the house - I cannot say whether the prisoner was with the cart.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I believe that is the street he took me to.
GUILTY of stealing, but not in a dwelling-house .
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Alderson.

1772.
HANNAH LOWNSLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 watch, value 4l.; 2 seals, value 30s.; 1 key, value 6s.; 48 sovereigns, 2 guineas, 1l. 15s., seven 10l., and seven 5l. Bank notes, the property of
William Hodson
, in the dwelling-house of
Thomas Parker
.

WILLIAM HODSON. I am a plasterer . On the 16th of July I met the prisoner near Hanover-square, standing against the iron rails; she is a woman of the town : a conversation took place and I went with her, to No. 53, Old Pye-street, Westminster
; I had the Bank notes and money stated in the indictment - the notes were wrapped in separate papers in my inside waistcoat pocket, and the sovereigns in my inside coat pocket, with some silver -I had a silver watch and gold seals, she unlocked the door, which was padlocked, got a light, and got into bed; but I did not - I pulled off my coat and waistcoat, and laid them on the table; I laid myself down by the side of the bed, and fell asleep, about one o'clock; I was quite sober; I awoke before four, it was nearly day-light - she was then gone - I directly got up, felt in my right-hand pocket, and the eleven sovereigns, which were loose in my trousers pocket, were safe - I went to my coat, and found a handkerchief, which was not mine, on the table; my money and handkerchief were gone - I had laid my watch on the table, and that was gone - nobody had been in the room except her, for I bolted the door myself, before I fell asleep; I found it open in the morning - I have never found my money; I am certain of her person; I had a good opportunity of seeing her, for I called at a house in Oxford-street, and saw her there, besides when she was in the room - we were in the room with a light for above half an hour before I fell asleep; she must have taken the money while I was asleep - the light was still burning when I went to sleep.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you really mean to say you were sober? A. I do; I had 236l. about me - it was my own, and the produce of my labour -I lodge in Oxford-market, and am now at work at Lambeth, for Mr. Armstrong, as a journeyman plasterer - I am forty-three years old; I was unfortunately led away - I had my trousers and boots on in the room - I had met her between eleven and twelve o'clock - I had come from the seat of his Grace the Archbishop of Canterbury that evening - I arrived in town about five; I had come from Croydon in a go-cart, which took me up outside the Swan - I did not go into a public-house - several persons were in the go-cart - I have had very excellent jobs, by which I got the money; I have not charged any body else with this - three persons were brought to the office on suspicion of having the property, but not by my desire; they were no doubt connected with the prisoner; I have not charged any body with it but her - this was all the property I had - I have been earning it since 1817 -I thought it safer about my person than to leave it in my box - I have jobs at great country seats - I took about 190l. with me down to the Archbishop's; I had not looked at my money that evening, but I knew by the weight of the gold that it was there - it was in my inside coat pocket, wrapped in a silk handkerchief, and in three separate brown papers.

Q. How do you know you had the notes? A. I had been no where but in respectable company - I am accustomed to come from Croydon in a go-cart - the prisoner was taken on the 22nd of August; she had abaconded - I looked for her for three weeks - I do not often go to houses of ill-fame - I am single - I am not in the habit of carrying money about me.
COURT. Q. What were the sovereigns in? A.In three separate pieces of brown paper, tied tight round with my handkerchief; I did not see the handkerchief in the morning, nor any of the paper.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 27th of August - I searched the room this happened in on the Sunday morning, and found the handkerchief -Thomas Parker is landlord of the house, but does not live in it; it is let out in tenements to unfortunate girls.

WILLIAM HODSON
. This is the handkerchief my sovereigns were wrapped in; I have had it since 1825 - it was found in the prisoner's room.
GUILTY of stealing, but not in the dwelling-house .

Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1773.
WILLIAM HUNT
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Robert Wagstaff
, on the 17th of August , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 2 half-crowns and 3 shillings , his money.

The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1774.
HENRY RHODES
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Michael Pemment
, on the 7th of September , and stealing 1 coat, value 1l.; 1 handkerchief, value 4s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; and 1 pair of gaiters, value 1s. 6d. , his property.

MICHAEL PEMMENT. I live at Harrow
. On the 7th of September, about nine o'clock in the morning, I went out, leaving nobody in the house; all the doors were locked and fast, but the back window was left about four inches open - it is a sash-window, and lifts up - when I came home it was up high enough for a person to get in - it was wide open, and a small piece of wood which I had put under to keep it up, was thrown aside; I missed my coat, waistcoat, and gaiters, and a loaf, which were all in the room when I went out - I went next morning to give information to the Magistrates, and the prisoner went by; he was called in, and taken into the room - he had my coat and handkerchief on, which I had left in the room - they were marked, and I can swear to them.
GUILTY of stealing, but not in the dwelling-house .

1775.
HENRY RHODES
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 fishing-road, value 6s. , the goods of
John Thrupp
.

JOHN FULLER. I live at Green-hill, Harrow, and am servant to Mr. Bailey - Mr.
John Thrupp
had taken the house for a short time. On the 7th of September I saw the prisoner with the fishing-road in his hand; I knew him, called to him by name, and he dropped it - there was another man with him; I took it up, and knew it to be Mr. Thrupp's - I had seen it at nine o'clock that morning laying by the pond in the orchard, with the line in the pond; the prisoner ran down the road, and I lost him - I afterwards saw him when Mrs. Thrupp was accusing him of it: he abused her very much, he said he had lost a cricket-ball and had come over for it - he said he would panch my head; I went to the public-house - he came out to fight me, but said nothing about the rod.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years for each Offence .
Before Mr. Justice Alderson.

1776.
RICHARD ROPER
and
HENRY ATKINS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July
, various articles, consisting of soap, pearl-ash, pickles, dyes, &c. &c., value 12l. 1s. , the goods of
George Marchant
; and
FRANCIS ROPER
was indicted for
feloniously receiving several of the said articles, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE MARCHANT. I am an oil and colourman , and live in Shoreditch. The prisoners, Richard Roper and Atkins, were in my employ in July last, and had been so between two and three months; I missed property which they had access to - Robertson, the Policeman, has produced a great deal of it to me since.

Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q.Had Alkins lived in your employ before that time? A. No - the business became mine on the 14th of February; I engaged Atkins on the 9th of May - I knew that he bore a good character.

JOHN ROBERTSON. I am a constable, and live in Shoreditch. The prisoner in July last lived at No. 45, in the Curtain-road - I apprehended him, and he took me to his lodging himself; I found a key on him - there was a box under the bed in the room he took me to; I unlocked it with the key - I had asked him previously what was in it; he told me to open it, and I should see - I did so, and found a quantity of pickles, blacking, and a variety of articles; Mr. Marchant, who was with me, identified part of the property, which was in two boxes - before that the prisoner said he had bought it out of his wages on Saturday nights, but when it was identified he said whatever he had to say he should say at a future place; here are two boxes of property, which I brought from there - I said to Richard Roper, "I believe you are going into business with Atkins, at Chelsea:" he said, "I don't know about Chelsea, but we had an intention of going into business;" I afterwards mentioned it to Atkins, and he said they had an idea of going into business.

CHARLOTTE BUTLER
. My husband is a boot-maker. About May last a boy brought a box to my house; Atkins came in about half an hour, and asked if a boy had brought a box there for him - I said Yes - I showed it to him; he said it was his - I should know it again by two marks of ink on it - I saw it afterwards at Worship-street; Richard Roper has brought things to my house, which he said were sent by Atkins - he left some oil cans, and afterwards fetched them away - he came and asked for two oil cans of Mr. Atkins'.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known Atkins? A.Since Christmas, by seeing him at the prosecutor's shop; my husband worked for Atkins - he did not send any box to my house since Mr. Marchant has had the concern: he sent a large one there before he went into the country - he asked my husband to let him leave something; he said he was going into business forhimself, and had no place to put them in - he said they were his own; the box was in my possession two or three days - it is here; I have not a doubt about its being the same.

JOHN ROBERTSON
. I found that box in Cross-street, Islington, at Atkins' brother's, which is an oil-shop; Mr. Marchant saw the contents, and identified part of them.

WILLIAM COX
. I am an officer. I went to Mr. Marchant's house on the 12th of July, and saw Atkins; I assisted Robertson in apprehending the prisoner - I went up to a room in Marchant's house with Atkins; he pointed out a box as his own - paper and starch was found in it, which Mr. Marchant claimed; Alkins said it was his own, and Marchant spoke to a mark on the paper.

JOSEPH BUTLER
. I am the husband of Charlotte Butler. About the 24th of June I took a pair of boots home to Atkins at Mr. Marchant's; he asked me if I would take a jar home to my house - I did so, and have a sample of the contents; he afterwards called at my house with an oil can and a painted ornament - he told me to give it to a person who would call for it; that he was a man with big whiskers -
Richard Roper
, who answered that description, called for it; Atkins afterwards told me that man was going into partnership with him -I saw my wife give
Richard Roper
the oil can and the ornament; both are here now.
The prosecutor here examined several of the articles produced, and identified most of them by marks on the papers, and labels upon several jars of pickles contained in the box.

WILLIAM ATKINS
. The prisoner Atkins is my brother; the two boxes were left at my house - he afterwards saw them and opened them; I saw a bottle in one of them - the Policeman took them away in the same state as they came.

Cross-examined. Q.Should you know any of the boxes again? A. Yes; they came to my house between January and February - here is one of the boxes; I know it, because I am a painter and glazier, and I have mixed putty upon it.

Richard Roper's Defence. Part of the things I confess to; but the rest. I solemnly declare, I bought out of my weekly earnings - the things found at my brother's I engaged him to carry to my father's house, he being a porter; as respects the other things I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
Atkins' Defence. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
WILLIAM HOPKINS. I keep a public-house at Wimbledon. Atkins was apprentice to me for three years - but I was unfortunate.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Was he not in the habit of coming to you while in the prosecutor's employ? A. He was; we bought some candles of him, also starch, mustard, blacklead, and salt - we asked him to buy them, thinking he could get them cheaper in town; I knew he was living with Mr. Marchant.

COURT. Q. Did you never swear that you supposed he was selling them on his master's account? A. I do not think I did; (looking at his deposition) I very possibly might say so. R. ROPER -
GUILTY . Aged 25.

ATKINS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

F. ROPER -
NOT GUILTY .

1777.
TIMOTHY DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 2 pictures and frames, value 20s. , the goods of
Wallis Drew
.

WALLIS DREW. I keep the White Lion public-house, in White's-alley, Chancery-lane
. In August I had two pictures hanging in my back parlour; on the 23rd I missed one, and on the 24th the other - I have since found them; the glass of one has been taken out.

JULIA MATTHEWS
. I am servant to Mr. Drew. I saw the prisoner in the tap-room on the 24th of August, in the afternoon; master and mistress went out that evening, and about eight o'clock, I saw a man go out at the back door with a picture: I could not see him clearly, and do not know who he was - I went into the back parlour, and missed a picture.

THOMAS LAW
. I bought a picture of the prisoner on a Monday, about the middle of August, for 1s.
Witness. I gave him one shilling.
Prisoner. You only gave me, 10d.

SARAH HAND
. On the 24th of October I bought a picture of the prisoner for 9d.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. When I took the large one there was no glass to it; I was in distress, and had warning to quit my lodgings.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1778.
SAMUEL BUTLER
and
PHILLIP WILDEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 4 lbs. of beef, value 2s., and 2 lbs. of lamb, value 1s. , the goods of
John Owen
, their master.

JOHN OWEN. I am a butcher - the prisoners were in my service; I had taken Wildey in out of charity, as a jobbing-man. On the 18th of August I shut up my shop, and they were going home to their supper; they live opposite; I stopped Wildey, and asked what he had got in that cloth - he said a piece of beef, which Butler gave him to take - Butler ran across, I followed and brought him back, and the Policeman took a breast of lamb from him: both joints were in my shop two minutes before, when I left the prisoners there; Wildey said,"Master I had nothing to do with it, Butler gave it me to hold, till he came from supper:" Wildey had told me a fortnight before to look out - the cloth this meat was in is mine.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.Wildey was only an occasional man? A. Yes - when I took Wildey, Butler was crossing the street, and turned to go into the privy; he had been a long time with me, and I suspected he had been robbing me all the while: I stopped Wildey as soon as he got out of the shop.
Butler's Defence. I never saw the beef - I picked the lamb up going through the market.
Wildey received a good character.

BUTLER -
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

WILDEY -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined One Year .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1779.
HENRY LLOYD
was indicted for a
misdemennor .
MR. GURNEY conducted the prosecution.

JOHN HOWELL
. I am a hosier , and live in Aldersgate-street
. On the 13th of August, between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came in and bought two pairs of stockings, which came to 3s. 6d.; he gave me a 5s. piece, which the officer (Harrison) has - I saw him searched; another crown-piece was found in the lining of his hat, and a good shilling in his trousers pocket.

JOHN HARRISON. I am a constable. On the 13th of August I was fetched to Mr. Howell's and searched the prisoner; Howell gave me a crown-piece, I found another in the lining of his hat, and a good shilling in his fob.
JOHN FIELD. I am an inspector of counterfeit-coin. Both these crown-pieces are counterfeits, and cast from the same mould.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had gone to a pablic-house with a person and fallen asleep, during which time somebody must have changed his hat - and that upon putting the hat on a crown-piece fell out, which he thought was good.
GUILTY . Aged 33.

Confined Twelve Months , and to
find sureties .

1780.
JEREMIAH MULLENS
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

THOMAS TYRELL
. I keep the Farm and Castle, Little Trinity-lane
. On the 26th of July the prisoner came in, and ordered a pint of beer - he offered my wife a crown-piece, and she called me; she gave me the crown, and I gave it to Oldis.

HARRIET TYRRELL
. I am the prosecutor's wife. The prisoner gave me the crown-piece; I knew him before, and told him to sit down and wait for his change; I gave it to my husband, suspecting it was not good - there was an officer in the house, to whom we gave it.

JOHN OLDIS. I am a constable. I was in the house, and saw the prisoner there - I took the prisoner in charge; he was discharged before the Magistrate - I received a crown-piece from Tyrrell, which I marked, and when he was discharged I gave it to Mr. Field; Mr. Tyrrell was before the Magistrate, but not Mrs. Tyrrell.

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of counterfeit coin. I received this crown-piece from Oldis on the 29th of July, at Guildhall.

MORY SAVAGE
. I am the wife of Robert Savage, and keep an oyster-shop in Harp-alley. On Thursday, the 5th of August, about half-past twelve o'clock at night, the prisoner bought 1d. worth of oysters, which he paid 1d. for and went away; he came again in ten minutes with another man, had 4d. worth of oysters and 1d. of bread - the prisoner paid me a shilling; I did not examine it - I asked my brother-in-law to examine it; he thought it good, and put it on the counter, but did not mix it with any other - after he left the watchman came up; I then sounded it on the counter - the watchman said, "You have given that man changed altbough I cautioned you:" the prisoner had new been gone a minute - my brother-in-law went in search of him I saw him in custody on the Sunday.

WILLIAM HENRY HART
. I was in Savage's shop - I did not notice the prisoner; I received a shilling from my sister-in-law - I thought it good, and gave it back to her; the watchman came up - I then looked at it, and pronounced it bad; I went with the watchman to look for the prisoner, but could not find him - I saw the shilling at Guildhall, and knew it by a mark which I put on it; I had given it to the officer on the previous night.
Prisoner. I saw him put the shilling into his pocket. Witness. I did not.

MARK ADAMS
. I am a watchman. I was by Savage's shop on the 5th of August, between twelve and one o'clock at night, and saw the prisoner give her 1d. - as soon as he was gone I spoke to Savage; I afterwards endeavoured to apprehend him, and took him on Sunday morning, in Black Horse-court - I am certain of him.

JOHN BADDEN
. I am an officer. I was on duty in Harp-alley, and received a shilling from Hart, which I have now.
MR. FIELD. This crown-piece and shilling are both counterfeits, and both cast in a mould - I was before the Magistrate on the first charge; it was understood to be the first he had uttered.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Six Months .

1781.
JAMES CLARKE
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

CAROLINE NINER
. I live in Fore-street
, with my brother-in-law, who is a hosier and glover. On the 16th of July, about four o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came for a pair of stockings which hung at the door, and came to 93/4d. - while I was folding them up he put his hand into his pocket, and said he did not think he had sufficient without changing a half-crown - he put a half-crown on the counter, which I took up and told him it was bad; he said it was not, and said, "Whether good or bad I must have change for it;" I was alone in the shop - I went to the door, and beckoned to Pudley, a neighbour; I gave him the half-crown - he desired the prisoner to pay for the stockings, and told him it was a bad one; he objected to pay; a mob gathered, and the officer came and took him - he was not out of my sight; Pudley took the half-crown to his own shop (next door), cut it in two, and brought it back; the prisoner was searched, and 7d. found on him.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not offer to pay for the stockings, if you would return me the half-crown, to return the person I had it from? A. He said if I would give him the halfcrown he would go back and change it, and pay for the stockings - I said I should not part with it, for it was bad - he did not tell me where he took it.

CHARLES PUDLEY
. I am a porkman, and live next door to Miss Niner - I went into the shop, seeing a mob, and Miss Niner said, "Is this a good half-crown?" I said No; she said, "This man insists on my taking it;" he said he had no more money - I asked where he got it; he said he took it in change at the Elephant and Castle, at Newington, on his road from Chatham - I asked if he had sufficient to pay for them without changing the half-crown; he said he had not - he was searched, and two shillings, a sixpence, and 7d. in halfpence were found on him; he insisted at first that it was the coin of the Realm, and on having change for it - he never offered any money for the stockings.
Prisoner. Q.Did I not say I had not halfpence enough to pay? A.You said you had not sufficient cash.

GEORGE LOCK. I am a watchman. I saw a crowd, and found the prisoner was charged with uttering this halfcrown; I heard him say he had taken it in change that morning for a half-sovereign, at the Elephant and Castle; I found two shillings and sixpence in good money on him, and 7d. in copper.
MR. FIELD. This half-crown is counterfeit, and made of Britannia metal.
The prisoner put in a written defence stating that he had received the half-crown, and had no knowledge of its being counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Months .

1782.
RICHARD HORN
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

JOHN WALTER CROPLEY
. I live in Wilmington-square. On the 1st of September, about a quarter-past nine o'clock, I sold seven loads of straw for
James Jaggers
, (of Broxbourne,) in Smithfield market, to Norris, of Chenies-mews, Russell-square; before ten o'clock the same morning, the prisoner, who was a stranger, came to me at the Coach and Horses, Bartholomew-close; he had a frock on - he met me in the passage, and asked if I was Jaggers' salesman; I said Yes - he said he had called for the money for the straw I had sold for Jaggers; he produced a note, which I have; I said, "My name is not Brocklin;" he said, "If you are Jaggers' salesman, that note is for you;" I said I should not pay for the straw till it was delivered, and if Mr. Jaggers would call after it was delivered, it should be paid; I gave him the note back - he returned about half-past twelve o'clock, for the money, and I said the man had not returned from the delivery, meaning the farmer's man, who had to deliver the straw - he said the man would not return, for he had gone home Whitechapel way; I said I was certain he would, for he had not had his spending money - he left, and came again about half-past five o'clock, and from information I had received, I asked him into the house, and said, "Give me the note;" he did so: I opened it, and said, "Who gave you this note?" he said Mr. Jaggers, that he got it at Broxbourn last night, and he had told him to receive the money: I asked if he was related to Jaggers - he said he had married his wife's sister, and lived within a few yards of him; I said I suspected he was a bad fellow, and that Jaggers did not give it to him - he said he did, and it was perfectly right; I sent for an officer, and gave him in charge - the straw came to ten guineas - (note read.)
London, August 31, 1831.

MR. BROCKLIN, - Please to deliver to the bearer of this note, the money for the seven loads of straw you have sold, belonging to
James Jaggers
, Broxbourne, Hertfordshire.
Richard Horn; bearer.

JAMES JAGGERS
. I am a farmer, and live at Broxbourne. I employ the prisoner a little - he married my wife's sister; I sent seven loads of straw to be sold by Cropley - the prisoner did not go with it; I discharged him twelve days before, and never gave him a note to the salesman, or authorised ahy body to receive it - this note is not in my hand-writing.

FRANCIS DANNER
. I am a plumber. I was at the Coach and Horses about half-past five o'clock, and saw the prisoner demand the money from Cropley for seven loads of straw sold for Jaggers; I saw him produce the note - he said he received it from Jaggers on the previous evening.

JOHN PALMER
. I took the prisoner in charge.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined Six Months .

1783.
HELEN CASHMAN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 25th of July , 1 pair of gloves, value 2s., and 1 fan, value 20s. , the goods of
Thomas Bunn
.

THOMAS BUNN. I live in Cheapside, and am a haberdasher . In consequence of what Painter, my lad, told me I examined my stock, and know that I have lost these things - I do not know the prisoner - she informed me that she sold fruit opposite the Post-office; I have not found this property - Painter was four months in my service, and had access to my goods; I gave him over to his father the last Saturday in July, and on the Monday the father gave me information, which induced me to prosecute the prisoner.

FREDERICK PAINTER
. I am fourteen years old. I had known the prisoner about two months before I left Mr. Bunn's. On the 19th of July I took this pair of gloves from my master's, without his knowledge - the prisoner had asked me to get them for her two or three days before - she gave me 1d. for the fan; that was on the 19th of July - I do not recollect when I took the gloves; I did not tell master of this - I knew I was doing wrong.
JAMES CARR. I am a stone-mason. The prisoner sold fruit opposite the Post-office; I heard her acknowledge that she had received a handkerchief from the boy.
NOT GUILTY .

1784.
HELEN CASHMAN
was again indicted for
feloniously receiving 1 handkerchief, value 4s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Bunn
.

THOMAS BUNN. The prisoner was apprehended, and brought to my house; Painter charged her with having received two handkerchiefs - no threat or promise was held out to her; she readily acknowledged it, and said if I would allow her to withdraw she would fetch me one of them, and show me what it was; I never gave Painter authority to sell or give away any property.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. He has robbed you pretty extensively? A. It is impossible to say, but I have my fears; I had the best of characters with him from his parents - I have examined my stock, and miss the description of goods which he says he has taken, which are gloves, silks, handkerchiefs, and fans; I missed several chequed and figured handkerchiefs and stripes - I cannot tell how many; they were of various colours - the prisoner answered readily all questions put to her.
COURT. Q. Did she give you any information of receiving goods from him before he was taken? A.No.

FREDERICK PAINTER
. I was four months in Mr. Bunn's employ; the prisoner asked me for a silk handkerchief - she first asked me where I lived - I told her, and then she asked if I could not get her a handkerchief - I did not take any notice that day; she asked me again the next day - she was in St. Martin's-le-Grand, selling fruit - she told me to take it into Panyer-alley, Newgate-street; I took one handkerchief and took it there - she was waiting at the corner of the alley; as I went down she followed me, and asked if I had got it - I gave it toher; I believe she gave me 2d. for it - I told my father of it the last day of July: on the 1st of August she was taken up and brought to master's connting-house - I charged he with receiving a handkerchief of me - she said she had received one, and a piece of ribbon which she had round her neck, and that the handkerchief was at home; it was a new silk one, with a pink stripe - I did not bring is back to master.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Was she in custody when she was questioned? A. Yes; she was not at large afterwards; I cannot tell what it would sell for, perhaps, 3s. or 4s. - There was a private mark on it, which I do not understand - I was sent home to my father's, to be forthcoming on the Monday morning, and to tell my father about it; I said nothing to my father till I was turned away - he turned me away because he missed some gloves - he said there must be some receiver, and I was to tell my father every thing.

JAMES GARR
. I was present when the prisoner was taken; she was brought to Mr. Bunn's - I was in the parlour at intervals - Painter charged her with receiving a handkerchief; she said she had received a pink striped one - Mr. Bunn fetched some out of the shop, but she said none correspon ded with what she had received.

Cross-examined. Q.How came you to be concerned? A. I married this boy's mother - I do not recollect that she said she had no idea of the boy stealing it, or any thing of that kind; I never heard such a declaration.

WILLIAM SHEPPARD
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner at a stall in St. Martin's-le-Grand; I brought her to Mr. Bunn's - Painter was present, and so was Carr; but I did not hear the conversation.
Cross-examined. Q.You are in the habit of passing by St. Martin's-le-Grand? A. Yes; I have seen her selling fruit there ever since the New Post-office was opened - I did not tell her the charge.
Prisoner's Defence. It is quite false what he has stated.
MR. BUNN. I am positive she did not say she did not know the handkerchief was stolen when she received it of the boy.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 16.
Fourth Middlesex, Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1785.
JOHN PIPER
was indicted for
embezzlement .

THOMAS DELVES
. I live in Goldsmith's-row, Hackneyroad, and am a baker . The prisoner was in my service about eight months, and was employed to receive money, for which he was to account the same day - on the 1st of July I delivered him ten loaves for Mrs. Moore, and on the Tuesday following I gave him some more for her; I saw him no more till the following Friday, when the officer brought him to me - he had 18s. a week, and what bread and flour he wanted for his family.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. When was the last day he received any money? A. On the Tuesday - I did not offer to the prisoner's wife to take from her the amount he had not accounted for; it was offered, and laid on the counter, but I refused to take it - my barrow had been broken; I did not hear that the prisoner had been drunk in a skittle-ground, till it was stated before the Magistrate - I would not have taken the money his wife offered me, if she had paid me for the barrow; I did not say I would look over this if he would pay the money, and make an apology; I said I would not hurt him on account of his family.

COURT. Q. Did you deliver the prisoner any bread for Mrs. Denby? A. Yes - on the Friday and on the Tuesday; on the 30th of June I delivered him one loaf for Mrs. Lambert - on the 1st of July another - on the 2nd and the 4th one on each day, and she had one on the 5th, which was paid for.

ANN MOORE. I am the wife of William Moore - we live at Lea-bridge. I received ten loaves of the prisoner on the Friday, and eight on the Tuesday; he brought them, and I paid him 12s. on the Tuesday for his master, to be paid the same day.
Cross-examined. Q.What time was it? A. About ten or eleven o'clock.

MARTHA DENBY
. I am the wife of
James Denby
- we live at Lea-bridge. I received some loaves from the prisoner on the Friday and on the Tuesday; I paid him 3s. 4d. for his master, Mr. Delves.

ELIZA JUDD
. I was servant to Mrs. Lambert. On Tuesday, the 5th of July, I took in one loaf of the prisoner - I had taken infive loaves before, and I paid him for the whole six 4s. on account of his master.

Cross-examined. Q. Then bread is not always paid for on delivery? A. No; there was no book kept between us - it depended on his memory and mine; I do not recollect that it had ever happened before, but there was no memorandum between us.

JAMES HANLEY
. I apprehended the prisoner on Friday, the 8th of July - I told him it was for embezzling money and I asked what had become of it; he said he had lost it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not add that he had been into a skittle-ground, and been drunk? A. He did not then, but he did before the Magistrate; he did not say he had been robbed by some person putting their hand into his pocket.
MR. DELVES. The prisoner has never accounted to me for these sums.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there any book kept? A. I keep my own books; he does not keep any - he did not say that he had been drunk and been robbed; he sent word on Thursday night by his wife, that he had got a situation, and he would pay me by instalments.

Prisoner's Defence. My master agreed with my wife and Mrs. Melville to take the money, if I would send a written apology - I sent the money to pay him, and also for the barrow, which was not broken while it was in my care; he took the written apology, read it, and showed it to his wife, and Mrs. Melville put the money down twice, but he would not take it - he said he would if I were discharged, but if not it would do to keep me in prison.

MR. DELVES. He certainly did send a paper to me with an apology; I said that if he would send a written apology, and say he was sorry and pay the money, I would not have any thing further to do with it, but I was told I should get myself into trouble, and refused to have any thingmore to do with it; I would receive him into my employ again.
The prisoner received an excellent character.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

1786.
JOHN LILLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 2 shillings, and 6d. in copper monies , the monies of
James Middleton Hooper
, his master.

JAMES MIDDLETON HOOPER. I am a grocer - the prisoner was in my employ. I put some marked shillings into my till - I was called down on the 16th of July, and found him in custody; two shillings were found on him, bearing the same marks, but it is impossible for me to say that they are the same.
NOT GUILTY .

1787.
THOMAS WAKEMAN
.
ELIZABETH WAKEMAN
, and
JOSEPH LILL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 16 cwt. of printed paper, value 30l. , the goods of
Henry Butterworth
.

JOSEPH BRETTELL. I am a warehouse man to Mr. Henry Butterworth - he is a bookseller , and lives in Fleet-street - he has a warehouse in Apollo-court, Fleet-street
; there was a large quantity of law books in quires, which are very expensive - that stock is more valuable than any other stock of books. In consequence of information I went to the warehouse on the 15th of July - I missed, I should think, two or three tons weight of modern law books in quires -I should think they were worth 2000l. or 3000l.; I received information, and have found a large quantity of it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did your master recover nearly all his property? A. Yes; there is but about half a ton missing - I was present at Mr. Butterworth's when Mr. Chidley and
Thomas Wakeman
, the prisoner, came there - I was engaged, and did not hear the conversation; that was about an hour after the robbery had been discovered - I think the property must have been taken in small quantities at different times; I had not taken stock since the latter end of June or the beginning of July- I had only gone to the warehouse to get particular works which were wanted for the shop; I should not have missed small quantities of books.

JOHN EMBLIN
, JUN. I live with my father in Leather-lane - he is a tripe-dresser. On the 12th of July we bought two quantities of paper of the prisoner Thomas Wakeman; on the 14th he called again in the afternoon, and said he had about 10 cwt. of waste-paper, which I agreed to purchase of him, and on the 15th he brought it in a caravan - there was a young man with him, but I saw nothing of Lill; I paid him 4d. per 1b. for the paper, which is the price of good waste-paper: it came to 21l. 12s. 4d. - I kept it by itself, and Mr. Brettell came and claimed it the same day; I gave it up, and it is here to-day -
Thomas Wakeman
said he had it from a lawyer in Liucoln's Innfields.

Cross-examined. Q.Has your father carried on business there for some years? A. Yes; I have known Wakeman six or seven years, and my father much longer; I always considered him an honest fair dealing man - I had had dealings with him before, though not to so large an amount; I am not quite positive that he did not say he had it to sell for a person who brought it from a lawyer, but I understood he had it from a lawyer - Apollo-court and Bell-yard are very near Liucoln's Inn.

CHARLES JUPP
. I am a carter, and live in New-court, Peter's-lane, Cow-cross. On the evening of the 14th of July, Wakeman came to me in the stable yard, and said,"I want you to do a job for me between five and six o'clock in the morning;" he told me to take my cart, and remove some paper - I asked him what quantity; he said he did not exactly know, but he supposed four or five hundred weight - I said it was an awkward time, and an awkward morning, but I agreed to go, and I went with my cart and horse towards his house, where he had told me to go, but as I was going up Warner-street I saw Wakeman and Lill, apparently coming from Wakeman's house; we stopped at a public-house in Warner-street, and all went in and had something to drink - there was another person with him, who was a stranger to me; we staid about a quarter of an hour - Wakeman then told me to go to Carey-street;
