the strange man went on before my cart, and Wakeman and Lill went up Eyre-streetbill into Leather-lane - when I got into Leather-lane I passed them with my cart; the strange man still kept on before my cart, but on his turning out of Chancery-lane into Carey-street I lost him - I then drove on about fifty yards past Bell-yard; the strange man then called to me to back my cart as far down Bell-yard as the pavement - I tried to do so, but I could not get it above half-way down; while I was backing, the strange man and another strange man, each of them, brought a large bundle of paper out of a turning in Bell-yard, but I do not know where it leads to - it was on the left-hand side in Bellyard; they put the bundles of paper into the cart, and I let down the tail-board, unbuckled the seat, and got the cart in order while they brought some more - they kept bringing out till I expect they had got about 7 cwt. in the cart; I told them that was as much as my pony and cart could draw - they said I must take some more, they had not got much more - they brought out two bundles more, and said there was some more; I told them I could not take any more then, I must come a second time - I then began to tie some ropes across, and they brought out three bundles more; I tied them on, and moved my horse up Bell-yard till I came opposite the large new building, and there my cart, being loaded heavy behind, it swagged - both the shafts broke right off, and it went up; a great deal of paper fell off - the strange man told me I must go and get another cart; I said I did not know where to get one without going home - one of the strange men said he would go and look for one; while I was taking out the paper, and tying it up as well as I could, another cart came up; I took away my broken cart - after I had taken it home I went to Mr. Wakeman's house, and his wife paid me by his order; I do not know what became of the paper.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Yours is a pony-cart? A. Yes; I will not say whether Wakeman had an apron on - I had seen him many times with an apron; one of the strange men had an apron when I came - I had known Wakeman, and worked for him for two years; it was about twenty minutes before seven o'clock when my cart broke down - there were plenty of people about; I did not see Wakeman after I passed him about the middle of Leather-lane - I think that is a quarter of a mile from Bell-yard; I think I received information about eight o'clock or a quarter past eight the same morning, that Mr. Butterworth had lost paper - I know a man named Chidley, and had been to his house; I had been to Wakeman's house before that, but I did not then know of the robbery; I went to Wakeman's as soon as I got home, to try to get some recompense for my cart - Mrs. Wakeman said that Wakeman and the people were gone to take the paper to Chidley; I went to Chidley, and asked if Mr. Wakeman had been there - I heard there that the paper had been stolen, but from whom I did not know; I went back to Wakeman's - he was close by, and was sent for into the presence of me and Chidley; it was then about nine o'clock; Wakeman asked me how much I charged for my cart - I said 1s. 6d. was what he generally gave me for jobs that lasted about an hour, and he told his wife to pay me; I asked Mr. Chidley if he wanted me any more - he took my address, and I went home.
MR. EMBLIN. Wakeman brought the paper to our house about eight o'clock that morning.

THOMAS BALDWIN
. I am servant to Mr. Griffith, a skin-dealer, in Leather-lane. On the morning of the 15th of July I was at the end of Fetter-lane, by St. Dunstan's church, when I was called by two persons, whom I did not know, to go with my cart and take some paper; they took me up Chancery-lane, down Carey-street, and up Bell-yard, where I saw a cart broken down, and some paper in the mud - but before that, one of the two men had left me in Chancery-lane, and I saw no more of him till my cart was unloaded again; they first told me I was to take the paper to Mr. Emblin's, but when I got to the corner of Back hill, the man who was then with me said, "Down here;" I said "This is Back-hill" - he said Yes, but he took me down Eyre-street-hill to Mr. Wakeman's shop - there is written over the door "Stationer and rag-merchant;" the person who had loaded my cart was there, and Mr. Wakeman, who is the other person who had spoken to me about the cart, but did not go all the way with me, came there when the cart was unloaded - the person who had gone with me all the way paid me 2s., which he got from Mr. Wakeman - I saw him received it; I did not see Lill - I have known him a number of years.

JOHN BERRY
. I am in the employ of Mr. Clark, who keeps a van in Red Lion-yard, Warner-street. On the morning of the 15th of July a person, who was a stranger to me, came with Mr. Wakeman, and desired me to take some paper from Mr. Wakeman's house to Mr. Emblin's, and I took it there in the caravan; Mr. Wakeman went all the way with me, and two other persons went to the corner of Leather-lane.
Cross-examined. Q.Was this an open transaction? A. Yes; there were plenty of persons about - it was a little before eight o'clock.

RICHARD MAGUIRE
. I know Lill. On the morning of the 15th of July I saw him in Bell-yard, which is near my house; he was shoving forward a truck with some paper in it - it was about half-past six, or twenty minutes to seven o'clock; there were two men in front of the truck, pulling it, and Lill pushed behind - I passed by them, and saw them when the cart broke down; I had known Lill before.
Lill. I was not there at all, nor near the place: he said before that it was seven o'clock when he was there.

Witness. I said between six and seven o'clock; I had to go to Chapel-street, Lamb's Conduit-street, and I got there before seven o'clock - the cart breaking down first attracted my notice; I thought the paper might be Mr. Howard's - It did not strike me that it was a robbery; there were several people about, asking what was the matter - I spoke to Lill, and said, "Joseph you have got a good master, for he is teaching you to draw," meaning that a man is not a finished bricklayer till he is able to draw plans; my son was with me - but he is not here.

Lill to CHARLES JUPP. Q. What time were you in Bell-yard? A.From half-past six till twenty minutes before seven o'clock; I did not see you from the time I passed you in Leather-lane till you were at the bar at Guildhall.
COURT. Q. You did not see him from the time you passed him till he was in custody? A. No - he and Wakeman were going the same way that I was, but I passed them, and went on faster.

THOMAS LIGHTFOOT
. I am an officer. I produce the paper in the same state as I got it from Mr. Emblin's.
MR. EMBLIN. This is the paper I got from Wakeman.

JOSEPH BRETTELL
. This is part of Mr. Butterworth's paper; I tied it up myself, and put this card on it; it is Chitty's Commercial Law, Nos. 2, 3, and 4.

Cross-examined. Q.When did you see it? A. I put it there in December last; I cannot say when I saw it last, perhaps a month before; Mr. Butterworth is an extensive publisher - some law-books sell better than others; it is customary to sell works for waste-paper, which will not sell in books - Chitty's Commercial Law is a very saleable work.

Wakeman's Defence. Had I been in the least aware of being brought to a place like this, I could have produced proper documents to prove my innocence; the man I bought the first paper of is Bowyer, whom I have known for twenty-five years - he is a rag-dealer and dealer in paper: I could often sell paper for him, when he could not sell it himself - I sold twenty-four reams for him to Mr. Johnson, of Bishopsgate-street; I am aware that the law must take its course, but I am as innocent as I was the day I was born - Mr. Chidley called on me, and said, "You have had some paper;" I told him Yes, and where I had sold it: I went with him to Mr. Butterworth's, told him where I sold it, and he got it all backthe last parcel of paper I bought of a person a total stranger to me, to whom Lill introduced me; I said to the person, "I think you sold some of this paper to Bowyer:" he said, Yes he had, but should not sell him any more, for he could not get his money from him.

Lill's Defence. I never recommended Wakeman - the truth was this, two persons told me they had some wastepaper to sell, and I said I knew a person who bought it; I sent them to him with it, and he made the agreement - what it was I do not know, but I heard it was some where in Lincoln's Inn.

JOHN CHIDLEY
. I am a bookseller. I deal in wastepaper, and live in Goswell-street; Mr. Brettell called on me about half-past seven o'clock on the morning of the 15th of July, and asked if I had had any paperoffered me that morning - I said, No, it was not likely I should have it so early in the morning; he then told me Mr. Butterworth had been robbed of a large quantity of books - I told him to take pen and ink, and write down his master's name, place of a bode, and a list of books lost, and I should know what to do if they were offered me - I asked him if the warehouse had been robbed that morning - he said it had; I then said, I had had a quantity of law-books brought to me as waste-paper a fortnight before - if he would go with my young man to my warehouse he should see them - they went together - my young man came back and said the whole belonged to Mr. Butterworth; I then went to the warehouse myself, and said to him, "Are these your master's property?" he said,"They are;" I then said, "It is right I should give you the name of the person I bought them of" - I gave him the name of
William Denny
, Clare-market, but as I did not know his address, I took him back to my shop for my young man to tell him - while we were there, Jupp came and asked if Mr. Wakeman had been there; in consequence of what he said Mr. Brettell and I went to Wakeman's house - we found him coming out of the public-house at the corner of the street - when I saw him I said,"Wakeman, have you had any paper at your house today?" he said he had, and had sold it to Mr. Emblin, a tripeman - I had known Wakeman before, but not much of him; I asked him how much he had sold - he said 11 cwt. 2 qrs. and some odd pounds, but I do not remember how much; that he had sold it at 4d. per 1b., and I believe he said "a good price too" - he then asked me if there was any thing wrong about it - I told him I had received information that it was all stolen; he said he did not know it; I said, "I suppose you know who you bought it of" - he said Yes, of a bricklayer - I said,"I would advise you to go with me to Mr. Butterworth's directly, and give some account of it." which he agreed to do; Wakeman said, "I have bought paper of Bowyer;" my young man said, "Bowyer, in Ray-street?" he said, Yes - Wakeman looked across the way, and said,"Why, there is Bowyer, call him over;" this was in Great Warner-street, about one hundred yards from Wakeman's house - we went on to Mr. Butterworth's, and reached there soon after nine o'clock; Mr. Butterworth was there - I stopped till about eleven o'clock - Wakeman did not stop all the time there: he went in and out - the officer came in half an hour; Mr. Wooller was there part of the time, and I believe he took down what was said - I cannot state what passed; Wakeman stated some of the circumstances to Mr. Butterworth in my hearing - I have lived in Goswell-street sixteen or eighteen years; I attended at the Magistrate's by desire of the prosecutor - I was not called - Wakeman appeared very willing to give information.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. But whether what Wakeman said was true, you cannot tell? A. No; there were many cases inquired about; I knew nothing of the robbery, but what Mr. Brettell had told me - I had bought paper of Wakeman three or four times; I never went to a warehouse to get paper away - I do not think I told the prosecutor of Wakeman having said he bought it of Joe, the bricklayer - I cannot say whether I did or not; I believe I told him all that Wakeman said.
Lill. I had two examinations before Maguire came against me - I am quite sure I have not been in Bell-yard these twelvemonths.

COURT to
RICHARD MAGUIRE
. Q.Upon the solemn oath you have taken, and knowing how it affects the prisoner Lill, was he there, or was he not? A.Upon my solemn oath he was; I have known him these ten years - he was forcing the truck forward in the way I have described.

T. WAKEMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Transported for Seven Years .

LILL -
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Confined Two Years .

E. WAKEMAN -
NOT GUILTY .

1788.
MARY ANN BROWN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, of an evil-disposed person, on the 12th of July , 21 cwt. of printed paper, value 50l., the goods of
Henry Butterworth
, well knowing the same to have been stolen .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JOSEPH BRETTELL
. I was in the service of Mr. Butterworth. From the 1st to the 13th of July a great quantity of books in quires had been stolen from his warehouse - I have since seen a quantity of them at Mr. Cohen's; I think I went to him on the 18th of July.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you not aware when you lost them? A. I cannot state nearer than between the 1st and 14th of July.

JOSEPH COHEN
. I am a stationer and rag-merchant, and live in York-place, Kent-road. On the 7th, 8th, 9th and 10th of July I dealt with
Isaac Henry
for paper, which I afterwards showed to Mr. Brettell - I bought 24 cwt. and 4 lbs., at 4d. per lb.; I do not know the prisoner.

ISAAC HENRY
. I live in Market-street, Newingtoncauseway, and am a general-dealer. I have known the prisoner some time - she keeps a marine-store shop, in Portpool-lane; I have heard that she is married. In July last (I cannot tell what day) I bought some paper of her, which I sold to Mr. Cohen; I sold it him by sample before I bought it in the bulk - Mr. Cohen had the same paper and quantity that I bought; I bought it of her on a Friday, and sold it to Cohen on a Monday, but I should state, that before I went to the prisoner's I met Mr. Cambridge, in Holborn, and he asked me if I was going to his daughter's (meaning the prisoner) - it was in consequence of what he said I went to her; I said that her father told me to call - she then said she had paper to sell, and fetched me about a quire as a sample, which she brought from up stairs; she asked 3d. per lb. for it - I offered her 21/2d.; she said she could not take that - that it was her father's property, and she sold it for him; I took the sample, and said I would let her know - I went to Mr. Cohen, showed it to him, and asked him 5d. per lb. for it; he offered me 4d. - I went back to the prisoner's, and bought one lot first; I think I then took three or four hundred weight, but I do not know exactly - she said it had been weighed before; I said I should like to see it weighed again, and a lad, who was in her shop, helped me to fetch it down stairs and weigh it - we got it from a little room on the first floor: I did not notice whether it was a bed-room or not - I do not exactly know what quantity I had in all; I paid her 3d. a pound for it, and sold it to Mr. Cohen for 4d.
Cross-examined. Q.How long before you went to her had you seen the father? A. Just before.
NOT GUILTY .

1789.
ALEXANDER PETRIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 shawl, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
James Fallen
, from the person of Elizabeth, his wife
.

ELIZABETH FALLEN
. I am the wife of James Fallen; we live in New Gravel-lane. On Saturday morning I was coming over the bridge in New Gravel-lane
, and saw the prisoner and two other men on the bridge - I heard a step behind me, and upon turning saw the prisoner; he struck me in the mouth, and cut it - I called to the Policeman; he hit me several times about the head, and in my struggling to get away my shawl came off, or he took it off, I do not know which; he continued striking me till he heard the Policeman, and then he ran away - I lost sight of him in the pursuit for a few moments; he was stopped, and secured - I had seen his features by the light of the lamp, and know he is the man; I had not said any thing to him before.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Where is your husband? A. In the West Indies - I had no other person with me; I do not know whether my shawl was taken off, or fell off - I have not recovered it.
Q. Now, do you mean to say you have not had your shawl again? A. Yes, Sir, I have, but I do not want to hurt the prisoner, if I must tell you the truth.
COURT. Q. When did you get your shawl again? A. It was brought back from the road in which the prisoner had run.
Q. How came you to presume to say that you had not got your shawl, when you had? A.Because I did not want to hurt the prisoner - I have seen his friends.
NOT GUILTY .

1790.
EDWARD HAYLOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of January , 26 sovereigns, the monies of
William Webster
, from his person .

WILLIAM WEBSTER. I live at Waltham Abbey, Essex. In the month of January last I went to an eating-house, in Shoreditch, and in a short time the prisoner came in; he ordered some dinner, and soon afterwards another person came in - the prisoner and I had spoken before the other man came in; we all sat there in coversation some time, and then went to a public-house opposite Shoreditch
church - to the best of my recollection we had a glass of wine or two a-piece; I took out my money to wrap it up in a piece of paper on the table, and while I was doing it the prisoner caught it, and said he would put it into my pocket very securely - I was simple enough to let him do it, and in ramming it in as I thought, he put a lot of farthings in instead; he soon after said he wanted to speak to me outside - we went out; he said something or other to me, and went away - I went into the public-house, and the other man was gone; I saw no more of the prisoner - I went to Enfield races, a month or six weeks ago, and saw the prisoner at a thimble-table; I seized him, and called for assistance - he struggled very much, and the people about him pushed me very much; my friend, who was with me, got a terrible black eye, but I kept hold of the prisoner till the constable came.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.Were you ever in London before this? A. Yes, many scores of times; I had taken part of the money that day - I think it was near two o'clock in the day; I think it was about the 28th of January - I mentioned my loss to the landlord; I did not go to any magistrate in London - I never mentioned it to my wife; I told nobody of it but my brother-in-law, and the publican, until after I found the prisoner - I am sure I am not mistaken in him; he told me he was a drover, and he was dressed like one, but at the races he was dressed quite like a gentleman - I had not been drinking before I met with him; I might have taken a glass of ale.

COURT. Q. How long were you in company with the prisoner? A.I think an hour or more in the eating-house, and an hour or more in the public-house; we were in constant conversation - I noticed his voice and features; I have no doubt at all he is the man, though he was very differently dressed - when I seized him, he said, "What do you want me for? I have done nothing;" I recognized his features - I do not know what became of the farthings; the publican said he did not know him - I was quite sober; after he had thrust it in, I felt to see if it was safe, and felt them, as I thought - when he was gone I discovered they were farthings.
MR. BARRY. Q.The farthings were in the paper? A. Yes; I cannot say whether it was the same paper the sovereigns had been in - they were both brown paper.

JOHN CAMP
. I am an officer. I was at Enfield races on the 21st of July - the prisoner was given into my charge - he struggled very much to get away; there were two or three attempts at rescue - I found on him a good sovereign, a had one, and a sixpence; he denied the charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent of the charge.

MR. JAMES McCABE. I am a surgeon, and live in College-street, Westminster. To the best of my recollection I have seen the prisoner, at least I think he is the man, whom I attended from the 12th of January to about the middle of February; he was very ill - he might go out, but I think it must have been with very much pain; his complaint was the hydrocele, attended with much inflammation, for which I applied leeches twice - he might perhaps limp across the road, but I think he was not in a condition to walk the streets - I attended him at No. 12, Edward-street, New-street, Shoreditch.

COURT. Q. How came you to attend the prisoner there if you reside at Westminster? A. I was solicited to do so by a person named Webb, a silversmith, whom I attended for the same complaint, in Weymouth-terrace - I will not undertake to swear the prisoner is the same person - he was then dressed very shabbily; he wore a dirty flannel jacket, and had whiskers - I speak to his person generally; if I were to examine him I could speak posilively.

SUSAN BARNARD. I am a widow, and live in St. John-street, Brick-lane. I have known the prisoner for four years, and worked for him - I attended him in January, for an illness which he caught at his brother's funeral, and Mr. McCabe attended him; his brother was buried on Tuesday, the 11th of January - he had died the 31st ofDecember; I was called to attend the prisoner on the 12th, and I applied seven leeches, and next day seven more - he did not go out till the 15th of February, when he took his own little boy with him.
COURT. Q. Do you know any public-house in shoreditch? A. No; when he went out he was dressed in corded trousers, a blue coat, with gilt buttons, and a black waistcoat.

SUSAN HAYLOCK
. I am sister of the prisoner, and am a lace-maker by trade; my brother is a muffin-maker Barnard attended him in his illness; he caught cold on the 11th of January, at his brother's funeral, and did not go out from the 12th of January to the 12th of February, to my knowledge.

COURT. Q.Do you know the eating-house where he went to get his meals, when he was well? A. No - I have one other brother, who is apprentice to my uncle; he does not live with us - we have not seen him these three years.

SOPHIA WORDSWORTH
. My husband is a journeyman cabinet-maker. I know the prisoner - I was sent for to his house the beginning of January; I remember his brother's death, and I made the morning - I took it home about the middle of January; I went two or three days afterwards, to make some alterations, and then Mrs. Haylock wished me to stay and work there, and I was there for a fortnight- I did not see the prisoner - they said he was ill, and the doctor attended him; I saw some gruel there, and I know leeches were fetched on two occasions.
NOT GUILTY .

1791.
BRIDGET O'DONNEL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 6lbs. of bacon, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Byers
.

JAMES JORMAY. I am shop-boy to
Thomas Byers
, a cheesemonger , of Marylebone
. On the 12th of August I saw the prisoner at his shop window; she then came in, and asked the price of a piece of bacon - I said 61/2d. per 1b.; she said, "Can't you take 6d.?" and I said No - I was going to weigh it, and she said, "Don't weigh that, weigh this other piece - can you take 6d. for that;" I said No - she said, "I'll wait till your master comes down" I went to cut a piece of cheese, and cut my finger - while my attention was engaged with that I saw her going out of the shop with a piece of bacon under her arm; I pursued her, and took her with it - she said she had bought it up yonder, but I knew it to be my master's, and it had been in the shop while she was there; I found two pieces of bacon in her lap, and one under her arm.

WILLIAM HOOKER
I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found three pieces of bacon on her - she said she had paid the boy 1s. - he denied it; in going along she said a gossip of her's had given her two pieces, and she had bought the other.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY . Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1792.
SERINA PERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 pillow, value 2s., and 1 blanket, value 4s. , the goods of
Harriet Read
.

HARRIET READ
. I live in Suffolk-street, Battle-bridge
- the prisoner hired a room of me for 3s. 6d. a week. On the 19th of August I missed an umbrella - I suspected her, as she had left my house; I got into the window of her room, and missed the articles stated; she never returned.

JOSEPH HALL
. I am servant to a pawnbroker at Battle-bridge. I have a blanket, pawned by the prisoner.

JAMES BOURN
. I am servant to a pawnbroker. I have a pillow, pawned by the prisoner.

JAMES PHILLIPS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 26th of August, and found on her five duplicates, some of which relate to these things.
Prisoner. I did it from distress.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1793.
ROBERT ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 4 shoemaker's tools, value 3s. , the goods of
John Hounslow
.

ELIZABETH HOUNSLOW. I am the wife of
John Hounslow
- he is a bootman ; the prisoner worked for a Mr. Collins, of the Old Jewry, and used to lodged with us. On the 9th of July he breakfasted with us, and when he had gone about ten minutes we missed these tools - I followed him, and just as I came to St. Paul's, he said, "By G - d, here she is;" I took hold of his arm - he wrenched himself from me, and ran up a court, which was no thoroughfare, where I caught him - he said he had nothing; at last he took three pieces of those articles out of his pocket, and said he had no more; when the officer came he found this fourth piece.
Prisoner's Defence. I took the tools for a debt which a man owed me.
NOT GUILTY .

1794.
THOMAS WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 box, value 2s.; 3 shirts, value 20s.; 3 pair of shoes, value 20s.; 1 coat, value 30s.; 1 jacket, value 10s., and 1 waistcoat, value 5s. , the goods of
James Lock Cartwright
.

JAMES LOCK CARTWRIGHT. I am a cabriolet-proooprietor . The box containing the articles stated was sent by me, on the 5th of August, directed to my son, Master Cartwright, Burlington-house, Fulham; I delivered it to my servant,
John Allenten
.
JOHN ALLENTEN. I am servant to Mr. Cartwright - he gave me the box; I took it to the Crown and Horse Shoe, Holborn-hill, delivered it to Stainton, and paid 2d. booking.

Prisoner. Q. What was the direction on the box? A. I do not know; I can neither write nor read - I did not rest in the street, nor leave the box a minute, till I delivered it at the booking-office; they made no remark about the booking.

MARY STAINTON
. I keep the books at the Crown and Horse Shoe. I received the parcel, and 2d. booking; I said to my aunt, "There is a box to go to Fulham," I did not see it afterwards - I believe I received the 2d., but I did not book it - I believe it was forwarded to Fulham as intended; my aunt booked it - I did not look at the direction.

MARY KEATLEY
. I am the wife of
Thomas Keatley
. I was up stairs dressing; when I came down my niece said, "There is a box for Fulham," and I booked it - my husband was ill in bed at the time; I remember it was directed to "Master Cartwright, North-end, Fulham," not to Burlington-house - that I can swear to; after booking it I gave it to the Hammersmith carrier, as the Fulham carrier did not call, and knowing they were both in one neighbourhood; I should think it could make no difference whether Burlington-house was on it or not - I read the direction twice over to the carrier, who told me he could leave it next morning, which was Sunday, but not that night.

WILLIAM WEST
. I am servant to Mrs. Barnett, the Hammersmith carrier. I remember the box being delivered to me, directed to Master Cartwright; I took it to Northend, but could not find the owner - I then took it to Mr. Donaldson's shop, and left it there all night; next morning I saw the prisoner inquiring for Mrs. Barnett's stable- I did not know him before, but I told him I was her servant - he then asked me if I had a box directed to Master Cartwright, to be left at North-end, Fulham; he said it ought to have been directed to be left at the Red Lion, near North-end, Fulham - that he had been to the person who sent it; that he told him he sent it to the booking-office on the Friday, that he had been to the booking-office, and they told him Mrs. Barnett's cart had it; I came with him to the lane close to our yard, where he saw another man waiting for him, and he told him he had found it; I then went to the shop where I had left it, took it out, and walked with them towards North-end; they asked me what the carriage was - I said 1s.; they said, as I had had so much trouble and running about, they would give me another 1s. - the other man gave the prisoner 1s., and the prisoner gave me 2s., and they took away the box, which has never been found; when they were gone I began to think that all was not right - I ran after them, and said that I would rather go with them and deliver it myself; they said I need not do that, as there were two of them, and they had been sent for it - we went on as far as the Three Kings; we there had a pint of ale, and I went away - on the Saturday after we heard that it was lost, and on the Tuesday after I saw the prisoner and the other man, walking in Holborn; I jumped out of my cart, got a woman to mind it, and followed them from Grays' Inn-lane, to Chancery-lane, with an intention of finding an officer, but I did not see one; I then went up to them, and said,"A pretty row you have got me into about this box:" the prisoner said, "There is a row if you will go along with me, I'll put it all right" - he called the other man Jack or John, and said "Here's the man about this box;" the prisoner said to me "Can you go with me to Harry's?" I said I could not, but I saw my mistress in another cart; I asked him to go and speak to her, which he did; she asked him to go to the booking-office and make it all right there - he said he would, and he went on till he came to a court; he ran down there into a house; I ran after him, collared him and pulled him back - I am sure he is the man; his companion had gone off.

Prisoner. Q. Why did not you take us both? A. I could not; I do not think the other staid five minutes -I followed you up Holborn, and you were looking into a shop; if I had seen an officer I would have given charge of you both - you told my mistress the box was all right.

MARGARET BARNETT
. I am the carrier, and West is my servant. He pointed the prisoner out to me, and said, in his presence, "This is the man that had the box;" the prisoner said he would go back to the booking-office, it was owing to a wrong direction - when he came to a court he ran away; I called Stop thief! and he was secured.

JAMES WHITE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; he said he lived, at No. 3, Russel-court, Drury-lane; I have made inquiries and he does not.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not find I had lodged at a barber's shop there? A. Yes, at No. 28, not No. 3.

Prisoner's Defence. I consider it is a concerted plan, between the carrier and her man; I can assure you, however clear their evidence is against me, that I was not at Hammersmith at that time; I was not out of town till eleven o'clock that day, when I was at the Elephant and Castle; I took my breakfast in Drury-lane at nine o'clock: it is very clear some person changed the direction, and it is an astonishing thing to me, that the porter does not know something about it - it must have been somebody connected with the booking office that did it.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1795.
FRANCIS WILTSHIRE
and
JOHN PAGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 3 shoes, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Payne
.

MARY ANN FALSHAW
. I live near Mr. Payne's. On Sunday, the 16th of July, the prisoner brought this pair of shoes, and this odd shoe, to me to sell; I said I never bought any thing of lads; a constable came up, and I gave them into custody.

EDWARD HARDWICK
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - these are the shoes.

JOHN PAYNE
. I live in Whitecross-street, and am a shoemaker. These are my shoes - they were safe on the 16th of July; the window was pushed up, and they were taken out; I do not know the prisoners, but I have heard a very good character of them.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a boy had given them the shoes to sell.

WILTSHIRE -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

PAGE -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1796.
JOHN SHIRLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 1 watch, value 10s.; 1 seal, value 1s., and 1 key, value 1s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Prowes
.

ELIZABETH PROWES
. I am a widow , and live at Kentish-town
. On the 9th of July I was coming out at my door to go on an errand; I saw the prisoner at the next door, drinking water; as I returned, I met him just at my door; I went in, and missed a watch off the mantel-piece in the parlour - I had left the parlour door ajar; I followed, and called to him to stop - he began to run; I called Stop thief! and came up to him; he threw something over a gentleman's premises; the gentleman got on the pales, got on the tiles, and gave it me - it was my watch - I had seen it safe five minutes before.

GUILTY . Aged 11. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1797.
JOHN MACKAY
was indicted for
embezzlement .

THOMAS WELLS
. I am a cheesemonger . The prisonerhad been my servant up wards of twelve months - he used to take out goods, and receive money; he was to account for it when he got home; he entered the money he received in a book, which he carried with him, and I signed it every night.

FRANCIS MEDS
. I paid the prisoner 3s. 5d. on account of my master, Mr. Fisher, on the 20th of July; this is the receipt he gave - (read.)

ELIZABETH PRIDHAM
. I paid the prisoner 6s.2d. on the 20th of July; this is his receipt - (read.)

RICHARD WATTS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner- he acknowledged that he had received these bills, and not accounted for them; I had said it would be better for him to tell the truth.

THOMAS WELLS
. He never accounted to me for the receipt of these monies - I had gone to these customers, and found they had paid the prisoner - I then spoke to him; he said he had received other monies, but not these- he had made out bills himself, and destroyed those made by my daughter; he had not the means of making up the deficiency; it amounted to 2l. odd.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1798.
JOHN JONES
and
HENRY HARRIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 watch, value 20s., and 2 seals, value 6s. , the goods of
Ann Debarry
.

GEORGE THATCHER
. I saw the prisoners on the 11th of July, about one o'clock in the day, in Barlow-street, Marylebone, together, and Jones had something in his hand, which I saw him draw out of his pocket - they were standing close to each other; I went up to Jones, and asked what he had got; he said Nothing - I searched him, and found this watch, ribbon, seals, and key in his fob, not hanging out in the usual way; I took it from him, and asked if it was his - he said Yes; I asked if there was any name on it; he said No; I looked, and found there was a name on it - I took them to the office - they were nearly half a mile from the prosecutrix's; I had been in the Park at the review, and received information from an officer, whose wife lived in the prosecutrix's house.

ANN DEBARRY
. I live in East-street, Marylebone
. This watch is mine - I lost it on Monday, the 11th of July, between half-past twelve and a quarter to one o'clock- I went out for about three minutes, and in that time I lost the watch - when I went out it was on a chest of drawers in the front parlour; I met Harris going out of my house as I went in; the street door had been left ajar, and the parlour door had the key in it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Did you ever say Jones was the person you saw coming out of the house? A. No; I had been to get some beer for my dinner, and saw a stranger come out; I turned and looked after him - I have some lodgers, but I knew he was not one of them; I do not take notice of every one who comes in or goes out - I saw him about two minutes- I looked at his face; I knew he had a light waistcoat on; he had his hat on, and I think a coloured cravat
Jones. On the second hearing the prosecutrix said she could swear I was the man that came out of the house, and when she got to the office, she swore to Harris. Witness. I never said so.
Jones' Defence. Harris asked which was the way to High-street; I was directing him, and took my watch out

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

HARRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1799.
ELIZA ELDER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 3 handkerchiefs, value 11s. , the goods of
James Brown
.

JAMES FOX. I am a linen-draper - I lived with Mr. Pope. On the 23rd of August the prisoner came into his shop, in Ratcliff-highway, and asked to look at some black silk handkerchiefs - Mr. Pope showed her some; she did not buy, but went away - I had suspicion, and followed her to three other drapers' shops; at last she went into Mr. Brown's - Wilson was serving her; she looked at some black silk handkerchiefs, and I distinctly saw her put some into her pocket - I went in, and asked Wilson if Mr. Brown was within; the prisoner was then taken, and I saw her pull out the three handkerchiefs from her pocket.

JOHN WILSON
. I am servant to Mr.
James Brown
. The prisoner came to our shop, but bought nothing - Fox came in; she was taken, and in her pocket these three handkerchiefs were found.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . - Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1800.
HENRIETTA LETHULIER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August
, 22 sovereigns, the monies of
Robert Tomlinson
, from his person ; and
JAMES BRYAN
was indicted for
that he, well knowing the said felony was committed, did receive, harbour, conceal, and maintain her .

THOMAS TOMLINSON. I am a captain in the Newcastle trade. On Saturday, the 20th of August, about eleven o'clock at night, I went ashore to settle some bills, having just discharged my cargo, and fell in with the female prisoner in High-street, Shadwell; I was quite sober- I do not know whether I accosted her, or she me; we went to a public-house in Brook-street, and had a pint of beer - I said I would bid her good bye, as I was going on board to sail in the morning; she had a glass of peppermint - we walked on together about two hundred yards; I took her by the hand, and wished her good-bye - she ran away; I then felt and missed twenty-two sovereigns in a purse, from my left-hand pocket - I had taken no liberties with her; I am certain my money was safe when I met her - I went up High-street, and described her to the officers; the sovereigns were in a purse, tied with white twine - I am sure she is the girl.

JOHN EASTERBROOK
. I am an officer. The prosecutor described the prisoner to me, and said he was going away the next morning - I apprehended her on the Tuesday following, in Ely-place, Bethnal-green; I knew her before, and knew her haunts, but could not find her there- I went to the house in Ely-place, at nine o'clock in the morning, and asked for Bryan; I saw him, and asked for her - she came down; I took her, and found 2l. 18s. 6d. on her - I asked if they had any more property; they said two donkeys - Bryan said he bought one on Sunday, and the woman said she bought one on Sunday; I tookthem to the office - the prosecutor said the woman had a stall on her fore-finger, which I found she had.

Lethulier. I had a rag on my right hand, and he said it was on the left. Witness. I saw her shift it from one hand to the other; when I said she was charged with robbing a captain, Bryan said, "He be d - d - she knows nothing about it, that I know."

MARY SHARPE
. I went into the White Hart, Brook-street, and saw the female prisoner and prosecutor behind the bar - I knew the prosecutor, and drank with him; I am certain the prisoner is the woman.

SARAH BARTER
. I was locked up on Sunday, the 21st of August, about a misunderstanding with my master: the female prisoner was there - I heard her say she had lost her money; she then said she had found it - she counted fifteen sovereigns, and put them into something she had taken them out of before; I did not see what it was.

HENRY LENNON
. I am an officer. I took charge of the prisoners.

GEORGE PHILLIPS
. I am an officer. I received information - I searched Lethulier's sister, and found six sovereigns on her.

SELINA LETHULIER
. I am the prisoner's sister. She was in the watch-house on Sunday for something, and when she came out on Monday, she gave me the six sovereigns to take care of for her - Bryan was there at the time, getting his dinner.

FREDERICK SMITH
. I am a shoemaker. The prisoners each ordered a pair of shoes of me on the Monday - I was to get them done that night; they paid me 10s. 6d. on them.

MICHAEL WHEELER
. I am a cabinet-maker. The prisoners were indebted to me; on Sunday, the 21st, Lithulier paid me a sovereign.
Lethulier's Defence. A man told Easterbrook, if he would come and make the most of this case he would give him a new suit of clothes a pair of boots, and stockings - my sister heard it.

SELINA LETHULIER
. I cannot say I heard any thing of the sort.

LETHULIER -
GUILTY .
Transported for Life .

BRYAN -
NOT GUILTY .

1801.
JAMES BLACKFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 60 yards of calico, value 25s. , the goods of
Robert Philps
and another; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ROBERT PHILPS
. I live in High-street, Poplar
, and have one partner; we are linen-drapers . On the 7th of August I lost this calico from my shop, but I knew nothing of it till the officer came - it had been safe at nine o'clock that evening, and the officer came at eleven.

AARON GERMAIN
. I am an officer. I came down my heat, and stood against the toll-bar; a man crossed into the road; he saw me, and turned round - I followed him, and saw the prisoner with this parcel in his apron; I took him, he said he had it from a pawnbroker.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the goods were given to him to carry by a man named Scott.

WILLIAM MATTHEW
. I am a Police-officer. I have a certificate of the former conviction of the prisoner; I know he is the person - (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Life .
OLD COURT. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 17.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1802.
ALEXANDER BRAND
and MARY ANN
, (HIS WIFE ) were indicted for
stealing, 1 carpet, value 10s.; 2 sheets, value 8s.; 1 set of bed-furniture, value 12s.; 2 window-curtains, value 7s.; 2 pillows, value 7s.; 1 candlestick, value 2s.; 1 looking-glass, value 9d.; 1 bolster, value 6d.; 1 blanket, value 6d.; 1 poker, value 1s.; 1 shovel, value 1s., and 1 pair of tongs, value 1s. , the goods of
George Miles
.

LOUISA MILES
. I am the wife of
George Miles
, a carpenter , in Regent-street, Chelsea
. I let the prisoners a furnished room on my first floor, about Christmas, at 5s. a week; they paid regularly till within the last five weeks- the woman said her husband was a cabinet-maker; we had given them warning several times, not liking them, and they left on Tuesday, the 14th of July, without saying a word - I was at home; they had nothing of their own, and walked out of the house - I did not expect they were going for good; I got into their room with the key of another door, which we found would open it, and missed all the articles stated in the indictment; the man returned by the house, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night - I sent for an officer, and gave him in charge; they had no right whatever to pawn my property - they owed me five weeks' rent; the lodging was let in the usual way - I had no security for the furniture; we asked for the rent - he sent us down a few duplicates of wearing-apparel, as security for rent, and I found they belonged to another person.

Alexander Brand
. Q. How long did you know the goods to be in pawn before I was taken? A. The same afternoon; I did not know before - I had been continually asking them for a pair of sheets, which I had lent them, and as they did not return them, I suspected they might be pawned; we did not find them in linen - my husband, on the Friday before, had threatened to send for an constable to turn him out, because he would not leave; we did not like him in the house, because he came home at all hours - they sent down twelve tickets on the Sunday, and said they would pay the rent on the Tuesday; they were not as security for the property - I did not know it was pawned.

HENRY BOND
. I am servant to Thorp and Co., pawnbrokers, of King's-road, Chelsea. I have a blanket, bolster, pillows, curtains, book, handkerchief, sheet, carpet, two pillows, looking-glass, and other things, pawned at different times, by a girl, in the name of Walker; she said she pawned them for her mother - she had been in the habit of pawning at our house for twelve months; the female prisoner had authorized me to take in whatever pledges the girl brought - I know she was their daughter- they were pledged at different times, from January to May.
MRS. MILES. The girl lived with them - she was about thirteen years old.

THOMAS BROWN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live inSloane-street. I have two curtains, pawned by the female prisoner on the 8th of June.

JOHN BRIEN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Gwyn's-buildings. I have some fire-irons, pawned on the 11th of June, for 18d., by
Mary Brown
, for
Mary Walker
, No. 9, Regent-street.

HENRY BAINES
. I am a Policeman. On the 14th of July, about eleven at night, I was fetched to this house, and took the male prisoner for robbing his lodging - he took the duplicates of all this property out of his pocket, and offered them to Miles.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The male prisoner handed in a long written Defence, stating that poverty had compelled him to pledge the articles; that the prosecutor had taken security for them, (and complaining of the Magistrate's inattention to the case while under his examination,) and stating that he had witnesses to prove the fact.
The case was postponed for five hours, but no witnesses arrived.

A.BRAND -
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

M.A. BRAND -
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1803.
JOHN TERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 1 gelding, price 2l. , the property of
John Cavenor
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1804.
JAMES JANSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Ladd
, from his person .

JOHN LADD
. I am a watchmaker , and employed in Cheapside; I live in Westmoreland-buildings, City-road. On the 17th of August, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Chiswell-street
and I felt a pull at my coat pocket - on turning round, I saw the prisoner close to my elbow; I accused him of taking my handkerchief out of my pocket - he asked what handkerchief I meant - I said, "The handkerchief you took from my pocket" - he said he had not got it; I took him to the station-house, and on the road he gave it me.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not give it you immediately you asked for it? A. No; I accused him of it three times before he gave it me.

NEAL LYNCH. I am a Policeman. The prisoner was brought to the station-house, about half-past eight o'clock, with the handkerchief; Ladd gave the same account as he has now.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY - Aged 22.
Transported for Life .

1805.
WILLIAM DUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 84lbs. of lead, value 7s.; 5 holdfasts, value 2d., and 13 brass ornaments, value 4d., the goods of
William Henry Alfred
, fixed to a building .

EBENEZER CREED
. I live in Coleman-street; William Henry Alfred has three houses at Park-place, Hackney
. On Tuesday, the 30th of August, I was instructed by him to go down there, and found the lead which goes from the front kitchen to the back one gone; I was there two or three days before - it was then safe - it had been fresh cut the whole length, and then hammered down to prevent the water coming in; the escutcheons were gone from the key-hole of the door - the holdfasts were taken.

CHARLES WALLER
. I am a Police-man. I was informed about half-past ten in the morning, that the prisoner had come out of an empty house in the Kingsland-road, with a basket tied up; I followed him into a beer-shop, about three-quarters of a mile from the house - I asked what he had got - he said some lead - I asked where he brought it from; he said up the road - I asked if he had brought it- he said he had; a person said, in his hearing, that a lady had seen him come out of an empty house, and he had followed him from there - I said he must go back, and show me where he had bought it - he said, "Why, what is the use of going back? I did come out of the house;" I took him to the station-house - I found a handkerchief, escutcheons, hooks, a pair of pinchers, and a knife on him; on going to the office, he said somebody had been there before him and taken the sink.

EBENEZER CREED
. The sink was not gone when I went there.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1806.
FREDERICK FREWSTER
and
WILLIAM THOMPSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
James Stephenson
, from his person .

JAMES STEPHENSON. I live in Lower Islington-terrace. On the 14th of July I was looking in at a linen-draper's shop in High-street
, with my wife; I did not feel my handkerchief taken, but on receiving information I felt my pocket, and it was gone; I am quite sure it was safe just before - Thompson was then in custody: Colton produced the handkerchief to me.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I keep a carver and gilder's shop, within about twenty doors of this linen-draper's. I saw the two prisoners following the prosecutor; I and Taylor, whom I met, watched them - the prosecutor stopped at a shop; the next thing I saw was Taylor taking hold of Thompson - I then saw Thompson throw the handkerchief away; Frewster stood a yard or two from him, and could not avoid seeing what he did - he went away when Thompson was taken; next day as I was taking Thompson to the station-house, I saw Frewster at some distance - knowing him I went after him; he ran away, but I took him in about ten minutes, in White Conduit-fields.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I live at Pentonville. I was with Colton for about five minutes, and saw the lady and gentleman stop at the linen-draper's window; the prisoners then went on each side of them - Thompson then pulled the handkerchief out of the prosecutor's pocket; I caught him in my arms directly he came away - Erewster ran away.

The prisoner Thompson put in a written Defence, stating that he was going to bathe, and picked the handkerchief up in the street, not knowing who it belonged to - that he gave it up immediately it was claimed.
JURY to WILLIAM COLTON. Q.Did you see the prisoners in company? A. I had seen them together for three hours, passing backwards and forwards from the Angel.
GEORGE TAYLOR. I saw Thompson take the handkerchief - Frewster ran away directly.

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Life .

FREWSTER -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1807.
JAMES TERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 1 cart, value 15l. , the goods of
Benjamin Nias
, the younger; and that he had been previously convicted of felony.

BENJAMIN NIAS, JUN. I am an upholsterer , and live in Beraer-street. On the 19th of July, between twelve o'clock at night and six in the morning, I lost my cart from Berner's-mews
- I gave information at the Policestation, and in about three weeks I found it in a shed in Gower-mews, with two or three other carts; it cost me eighteen guineas nine months ago - when I lost it it was a chocolate colour, but when I found it it was green; I can identify it by certain injuries it had sustained before I lost it, and the manner in which it was repaired; a few of the rails were broken when I lost it.

GEORGE POWELL
. I am a Policeman. On the 4th of August, about ten o'clock in the morning, I apprehended the prisoner, in Gower-mews, where the cart was found; I told him he had a stolen cart in his shed, belonging to Nias- he said he had bought it in Smithfield of a man he had known some time; that was all the account he gave - Nias spoke positively to the cart, and so did others who he brought with him, and pointed out marks where it had been repaired- it was fresh painted, green, but there was a kind of chocolate colour remaining at the edges, which I could see.

JOHN NEWTON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner and told him it was for stealing a cart, and having another in his possession, knowing it to have been stolen; he said he bought them in Smithfield, of a man he had known twelve months: Nias claimed one cart, and pointed out different places where it had been repaired -I got some of the new green paint off with turpentine, and under it could see written "Common stage cart;" but could not read any more, it was a chocolate colour under the body; the paint was damp and had not been done more than a day or two - he did not give the name or address of the man he bought it off; he said he knew where to find him, he produced nobody before the Magistrate; the cart was scraped, and we could trace a chocolate colour and a pink line.

BENJAMIN NIAS
. I could trace the chocolate colour with pink lines.

ROBERT BEST
. I am a soda-water maker. I let a coach-house to the prisoner early in July, and on the 19th, about one o'clock, I saw a dark chocolate coloured cart there, with one or two more carts; nobody else rented the coach-house, the same cart was taken away by the Policeman, and is now in the yard of the Court -I bought it of the prisoner myself, paid him part of the money, and he has painted it since for me; I do not recollect whether any name was on it, because two or three places had been painted over with lead colour before - I bought it on the 19th of July, for 5l., it was almost pulled to pieces and much of the wood-work gone; the prisoner agreed to put it in repair and paint it - to the best of my recollection the part where the name should have been was painted over.

Prisoner's Defence. I am a smith and wheeler. On the 19th of July I was passing Long-lane, Smithfield - it was not market-day; I saw a man who I have frequently bought things of before in Smithfield, not quite in the market - he had this cart and a horse, and asked me to have something to drink; he asked me to buy the cart, I said I was very short of money; he wanted 7l. for it - it was very much damaged; I gave him 4l. 5s. for, it and had a stamp receipt.
ROBERT BEST. The prisoner stated himself to be a jobbing wheeler; I have seen him at work on carts - he had no forge there.
BENJAMIN NIAS. There were a few rails broke at the side of the cart, and one step was broken; I did not have that repaired.

JOHN SMITH. I live in West-street, Globe-fields, Mileend. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, by the name of James Stephens - he is certainly the person who was convicted; I was present at the trial (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1808.
THOMAS THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on 10th of July , 1 reticule, value 2d.; 1 purse, value 2d.; 1 crown, and 11 shillings, the property of
Mary Anne Williams
, from her person .

MARY ANNE WILLIAMS
. I am single , and live at Enfield - I have been brought up with my aunt, and live with my friends till I get a place. I had been out with my friends on Saturday night, the 10th of July, and about half-past five o'clock in the morning I was near Dalstonlane
- I had my reticule twisted round my fore finger, and felt the prisoner take it off my finger; I am quite sure he is the man - he was alone; he took it off without saying any thing - I immediately followed, and asked him several times to give it me; he would not answer, but walked on very fast - I kept him in sight till the officer took him, which was in three or four minutes; the officer heard me calling him to return it, and he took him - the reticule and contents were found on him; I never saw him before that.

Prisoner. Q. Was it not thrown from the door where you were sitting? A. No, I was sitting at a door; he saw me, and came and took it off my finger - I had my head resting on my elbows, and the string of the reticule round my finger; I was alone - I had been with a few friends, and being very tired, sat down and fell asleep; the prisoner taking the reticule off my finger awoke me - I immediately got up, and went after him; it is not a place of resort for Policemen.

THOMAS ROACH
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty in Dalston-lane, about three hundred yards from where the prosecutrix was sitting, which was in a brickmaker's shed- she was a stranger to me; I saw the prisoner enter the shed, reach his hand forward, as if to take something, and steal back - I had not then see the prosecutrix; he entered the next field, and in about a minute the prosecutrix came round the field, and hallooed after him - I followed him to Hackney-downs, and took him; I found the purse in his right-hand jacket pocket, with a crown-piece, a half-crown, and 8s. 6d. in it - he said he had picked it up; I kept the purse concealed till I got to the prosecutrix - I then asked her the colour of it; she said red, which it was - he had the reticule in his hand.

MARY ANNE WILLIAMS
. My purse was in my reticule- this is it; this purse is mine.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been out of employ about four months, and had nothing to eat; I thought I could godown to Lincolnshire - when I got to Delston I was tired, I went into the brick-field, and sat down till one o'clock; I then saw some person, whether it was the prosecutrix I do not know - I fell asleep till nearly three; when I awoke I saw this old sand-house, and thought I would go and lay there - I went, and saw the prosecutrix and another person, who I suspected was the Policeman; they were asleep - I turned to where I had been laying, then got up, and came to this place - I saw something black laying about a foot within the door; I picked it up, and found it was this bag with some biscuits in it - I was very hungry, and did not think of there being money in it; I went on, took a biscuit out to eat, and a halfpenny dropped out - I then felt, and found the purse.

M. A. WILLIAMS. I had been out the Saturday night with my friends: it was late when I left them, and I sat down in this place, about four o'clock, and dozed - there was nobody there all the time I was; I am sure I did not drop my reticule; there were four biscuits in it.
GUILTY . Aged 30.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Nine Months .

1809.
GEORGE THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 sheet, value 2s., and 1 loaf, value 4d. , the goods of
James Macintosh
.

CATHERINE MACINTOSH
. I am the wife of
James Macintosh
- we live in Cartwright-street, Rosemary-lane
, on the ground-floor; my husband was not in town - it is a lodging-house for single men. The prisoner came that night, and paid me 3d. for his bed, and I trusted him 1d.; I was awoke at four o'clock in the morning, by hearing the plates moved, and saw him going out at the door - he slept up stairs; I followed him, but lost him - I found him at a public-house about ten o'clock; I heard him say to the Policeman, "Don't let her give charge of me - I have left the things at the public-house, and will give them up;" they were found at the public-house.

HENRY BROWN
. I was on duty in Rosemary-lane. The prosecutrix gave the prisoner in charge; he was in the yard of the public-house, washing himself - I went to the Anchor and Hope, East Smithfield, with him; he took the loaf off the shelf in the tap-room, and told me he had done it to get transported - I found the sheet there; he said he had taken it there.(Shirt produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1810.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 2 saws, value 8s., and 1 stock, value 2s. , the goods of
Richard Mitchener
.

RICHARD MITCHENER
. I am a blind-maker , and live in Great Castle-street, Oxford-market
. On the 30th of July I went out of my shop for a quarter of an hour, leaving these tools safe; it was about half-past four o'clock - my wife was in the back parlour; on returning I found the prisoner and two others in custody in the shop - the Policeman produced two saws and a stock to me; he was a stranger

JAMES KENNERLEY
. I am a Policeman. I was in Oxford-street, and saw the prisoner and two others; I watched them - they watched me along two or three streets; I then kept out of their sight, but could see them - I followed them into Castle-street, and met Betraun; we followed them to the prosecutor's shop, I saw Smith go in and come out, and speak to the two others, who stood some distance off; he went in again, and Betraun said he had come out - I then saw him about two yards from the shop, running down towards Regent-street; I saw Powell secure him, and take something from under his coat - I showed Powell the shop, then followed, and took one of the other two.

ANGELIOUS BETRAUN
. I was with Kennerley, and watched the prisoner and two others to the prosecutor's shop; I saw him go in and come out - he went in again, and came out with something bulky under both arms, under his coat; he ran towards Regent-street - I afterwards went to the prosecutor's shop with another, who I secured; I saw the property in Powell's hands.

GEORGE POWELL
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner running through Castle-street; I followed and took him, with the two saws under his coat, and the stock in his hand - I took him to the shop, and Mitchener claimed the property; the bill against the other two was thrown out.

ROBERT ISAACSON
. I am a Policeman. Powell and I were together; I saw the prisoner cross the street - I secured one of the others.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1811.
WILLIAM SPIERS
and
JOHN ROBINSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 silver spoon, value 7s. , the goods of
Edward Pinder Lygon
and others.

THOMAS TURNER
. I am under-butler to Colonel Edward Pinder Lygon. This spoon was for the service of the whole regiment, and was in his care; I count the plate once a day - it was all right between one and two o'clock on the 2nd of August; I saw a boy down the area, at the kitchen door, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, but do not know who he was; Mason brought me the spoon next morning.

JOHN DICKSON
. I am a shopman to Mr. Hunter, a silversmith, of Tottenham-court-road. On the 2nd of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoners loitering at our window, and heard one say to the other, "Break a piece off;" our shop door was open - Rohinson then brought the bowl of the spoon in to me, and asked if it was silver - I detained him, went out and brought Spiers in, and on him I found the other part of the spoon.

JOHN MASON
. I took the prisoners in charge with the spoon.
Spiers put in a written Defence, stating that Robinson asked him to go with him to sell something, and gave him part of the spoon to hold while he went to know what was the value of it.
Robinson. I am sorry for having taken the spoon - I never was accused of any crime before.
Robinson received a good character.

ROBINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped , and delivered to his Master.

SPIERS -
NOT GUILTY .

1812.
ROSINA SAVELAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 2 pairs of slippers, value4s., and 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
Rober Richardson
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1813.
JOHN OWEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 2 shovels, value 5s. , the goods of the
trustees of St. Leonard's, Shoreditch
.

ROBERT LANDER
. I am a Police-man. On the 27th of August, about half-past twelve o'clock at night, I was in Kingsland-road, and saw the prisoner standing by the gates of the parish stone-yard, in Fleming-street
- he turned round, and went towards the wall next the gates, where two shovels were handed over the wall to him - he went about forty yards with them under his arm; I stopped him; he said he had picked them up by the side of the gate, and would take them back.

JOHN WHITTY
. I hold a situation under the trustees of the poor. These shovels are their property; I left them locked up in the yard on the Saturday night.

Prisoner's Defence. I had occasion to stop for a moment, and on turning my head I saw the shovels lay there; I carried them about forty yards, and then thought I would have no more to do with them - as I turned back, the Police-man came up.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1814.
JOHN OSBORNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 1 pair of boots, value 2s. , the goods of
Samuel Lea
.

EDWARD MARRYATT
. I am a servant to
Samuel Lea
, a shoemaker , in Peter-street, Saffron-hill. On the 22nd of August I heard somebody in the shop, turned round, and saw the prisoner just turning the door-post, going out: I missed these boots, which I had seen safe on the counter a quarter of an hour before; I went after him - he dropped them at my feet, and I secured him.

JOHN CLARK
. I am a constable. I received the prisoner in charge - he said nothing.(Property produced and sworn to)

GUILTY. Aged 14. -
Judgment Respited
.

1815.
DENNIS MCDONALD
and
JOHN DONOGHUE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 4 coach-springs, value 40s. , the goods of
John Robson
and others.

WILLIAM FACHE. I am in the employ of
John Robson
and three others, who are assignees to the estate of
Robert George
, Parker-street, Drury-lane
- I was in care of the whole property. On the 15th of July I saw these coach-springs in the loft, and missed them next day - the prisoners were strangers; on the morning of the 28th of July I saw Donoghue leaning on a post, opposite the gate- I told him to move, to make way for a carriage which was coming in; he was taken that afternoon - four coachsprings were stolen.

WILLIAM LASSITER
. I am porter to Mr. Leslie, an auctioneer, of Charles-street, Middlesex-hospital. Master and I took sixteen springs to the yard, on account of the assignees, to be entered on the catalogue, and on the 16th four were missing.

JAMES ELLIS
. I am a coach-spring maker, and made these springs on Mr. George's premises - I saw them there about three weeks before they were lost, and on the 29th I saw them in the officer's possession; I know McDonald by sight - he is a stranger to the premises.

ROBERT HUSON. I am a Policeman. On the 28th of July, about ten o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoners together at Mr. Jones', a pawnbroker, High Holborn- they were both leaning over the counter on which the springs lay, offering them in pawn; they came out together; I took McDonold, and in about an hour and a half, in consequence of information, I charged him with stealing the springs - he said he would fetch the master who gave them to him in half an hour; I trusted him to go, but he never brought any body to me to own them -I found him in the shop of Mr. Washbrook, a springmaker, for whom he worked; I took Donoghue that evening - he said he had nothing to do with the springs, he merely carried them there for a man: I brought the springs from the pawnbroker's, and have had them ever since.
McDonald. I came to the station of my own accord. Witness. I told his master if he came in to detain him, but I met his master bringing him to the station.(Property produced and sworn to.)

McDonald's Defence. Seven weeks last Thursday, as I was going to breakfast, I met this man and another opposite St. Giles' church; being in the habit of pawning for my master, to get the work on, this man asked me to show him where I pawned, and as it was in my way home, I did so.

Donoghue's Defence. On Sunday evening I stood at the corner of Drury-lane; a man came up in his shirtsleeves and a hairy cap; he asked me to carry a parcel, and if I had a basket - I said No; I borrowed one - the man took me into a stable in Parker-street; he told a man to put the things into my basket, and told me to meet him at eight o'clock on Monday morning; I went, and he brought out the springs and asked me to pawn them; this man being in the habit of pawning, I asked him where to go.

DONAGHUE -
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Confined Six Months .

McDONALD -
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 17.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1816.
SARAH BONIFACE
&
MARY DONOUGH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 coat, value 14s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 10s.; 1 shawl, value 16s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Michael Ryan
.

MARY RYAN. I am the wife of
Michael Ryan
- we live in Drury-lane
; Boniface was employed to nurse my child - I know nothing of Donough. On Sunday, the 31st of July, my husband went to clean himself, and missed these articles; I had seen them all safe on the Friday night, in the trunk, which stood between two beds; my husband kept the key in his pocket - I had Donough taken, in consequence of what Boniface said.

WILLIAM OLIVER
. I lodge in a small room adjoining the prosecutor's. On Saturday, the 30th of July, I saw Boniface in their room, alone, but soon afterwards the other prisoner joined her; I then went out - Donough had beenthere in the morning, to know if Mr. Ryan would want Boniface that day, and I said yes; I left them in the room - I returned in half an hour, and they were gone.

SAMUEL FLETCHER
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. On the 30th of July Boniface came to our shop, and pawned the coat and trousers; a person, who I believe was Donough, was with her.

JOSEPH HEWITSON
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Gray's Inn-lane. On the 30th of July, in the morning, between eleven and twelve o'clock, Donough came to our shop with another girl, and pawned this handkerchief and shoes.

WILLIAM ROBINSON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoners together, on the 31st of July, in St. Giles'.(Property produced and sworn to.)

BONIFACE -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

DONOUGH -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Confined One Month .

1817.
WILLIAM JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 pocket-book, value 1s., and two 5l. Bank notes, the property of
William Boucher
, from his person .

WILLIAM BOUCHER
. I am a Chelsea pensioner , and live at Wapping. On the 7th of September I received 17l. 12s., at Chelsea, and had 2l. or 3l. besides; the prisoner went with me to receive it - we went into a publichouse in Audley-street
; I had two 5l. notes in a book in my breast-pocket, and 9l. or 10l., in a red purse in my waistcoat pocket - he sat on my right side, and said, "Take care of your money;" I said, "There is nobody to take it but you;" he left me soon after, and on looking for my pocketbook, for a letter, I missed my pocket-book and purse of money - I had drank something, but do not think I fell asleep; I dare say I was a little gone - I could not find the prisoner that night.

Prisoner. His pocket-book fell out of his pocket on the table, at
Mary Cave
's brother's, which is a mile from that house - I took it up, and said I would take care of it. Witness. He did not; I missed it in the public-house.

THOMAS WALTERS
. I am a Policeman. On the afternoon of the 8th of September, I saw the prisoner in company with a woman, in the Almonry - I took him in charge, and found on him 12s. 6d.; when I put him into the cell, his hat fell off with the pocket-book in it, and two 5l. notes - he was tipsy; when I saw that he was sober, I went, opened the book, and asked if it was his - he said it was, and the notes were his; I said, "That cannot be, you gave your name Jackson, and there is William Boucher in the book;" he said, "Ah, it is all one, we live together;" I said, "If you can tell where I can find him, I will go to him;" he said, "No, if you will let me go, I will find him, and bring him in the morning; I can go to St. Katharine's-dock for him;" I found the prosecutor at Chelsea.

SAMUEL BANISTER
. I am inspector of the Police. The prisoner was at the watch-house; he said the pocket-book and papers all belonged to him, and he could take as good care of them as Boucher.

The prisoner, in a written Defence, stated that the prosecutor and himself had been drinking at a private house, and the prosecutor went out, leaving his pocket-book on the table, and he took it up to take care of for him.

WILLIAM BOUCHER
. We were intimate - this is my pocket-book and my notes.
GUILTY . Aged 44.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Months .

1818.
WILLIAM McNEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of June , 11/4 yard of woollen cloth, value 14s., and 1 stock, value 1s. , the goods of
Edward Minister
, his master.

EDWARD MINISTER. I am a tailor . The prisoner was my errand-boy - I missed some claret cloth, and after his left me I found him in custody at the station-house in Vinestreet, and saw a piece of blue cloth there, which I compared with a pattern I had.

JOSHUA FREDERICK CLEMENTS
. I am an inspector of the Police. I received the prisoner in charge, on the 15th of July, and from information, I asked him what had become of the cloth, lost from his master's while he was in his service; he said voluntarily that if I went to No. 14. Crown-street, I should find a piece of blue cloth in a cupboard -I went, and found this piece, also this stock, in a hat-box; he said he had sold the claret cloth to a servant in Regent-street - we went there, but it was then made into a coat.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner begged for mercy, and received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1819.
ANN CUFF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 2 gowns, value 15s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Ragsdell
.

ELIZABETH RAGSDELL. I am a widow , and live in South Conduit-street, Bethnal-green
- the prisoner lodged in my back parlour, and left without notice. On the 30th of July I missed two gowns out of my box.

JOSEPH CLEMENTS
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner - she said she had pawned the gown at Taylor's for 9s., in the name of
Ann Jones
.

GEORGE BROMFIELD
. I am servant to Mr. Taylor, a pawnbroker, of Bethnal-green. These gowns were pawned for 9s., in the name of
Ann Jones
- I do not recollect the person.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 47.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1820.
JOHN BLACKWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 1 bag, value 2d.; 1 sovereign, and 10 shillings , the property of
Jane Bunker
.

HANNAH DONALSON
. I am a widow, and assist my sister Jane Bunker, who keeps the King's Head, Great Ryder-street, St. James'
. On the 4th of September, between eight and nine o'clock, the prisoner came for a glass of gin; I gave him change for 6d. - he then asked for some water, which I gave him, and then the newspaper; I wanted him to go into the room - he said he was waiting for somebody, and would stand at the bar; I went into an adjoining room, and then saw him run out - I went, and on opening the till I missed a sovereign from a cup, and a bag of silver; I saw them safe when I gave him change - I saw him in custody in about twenty minutes.

GEORGE BALDWINSON
. I was near Ryder-street, and saw the prisoner - I followed; he went into King-street,and in about ten minutes I saw him on the top of Mr. Robinson's house; I gave an alarm, and he was secured.

SARAH JEFFERY
. I live in King-street, St. James'. In consequence of an alarm I went to the top of the house, and found the prisoner behind the door in my bed-room -I had left the window open, and found it shut down; our house is next to Robinson's and there were marks of a person's getting over the parapet.

JOHN JARVIS
. I am a Policeman. I went, and found the prisoner in this room - I found on him a sovereign, 16s. 6d.; and 5d.

GREGORY DUDLEY
. I am a Police-serjeant. I found this bag in the gutter of Robinson's house.(Bag produced and sworn to.)

JOSHUA CLEMENTS
. The prisoner was given in charge- he afterwards said the bag was on the top of the house.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Six Months .

1821.
SARAH BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 sheet, value 7s. , the goods of
Isaac Williams
.

ISAAC WILLIAMS
. I keep a lodging-house in French Horn-yard
. On the 29th of August the prisoner came to lodge there, but I did not see her - I went to the room when she was gone, and missed a sheet.

Prisoner. I left at half-past eleven o'clock, leaving the man I had been with to sleep there, and next morning he gave me the sheet to pawn. Witness. There might be a man with her; we let rooms for an hour.

WILLIAM BURD
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. -This sheet was pawned by a woman, who I do not know.

JAMES FORD
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner, and found the duplicate on her.
NOT GUILTY .

1822.
HENRY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 4 frocks, value 4s.; 5 aprons, value 3s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; 3 shirts, value 2s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 1s. 6d.; 1 cap, value 1s.; 1 collar, value 6d.; 1 table-cloth, value 1s., and 4 window-blinds, value 6d. , the goods of
James Grant
.

ELIZABETH GRANT
. I am the wife of James Grant; we live in King-street, Camden-town
. On the night of the 7th of July this linen was in the back garden, and at half-past one o'clock in the morning the Policeman alarmed me.

JAMES CARTER
. I am a Policeman. About one o'clock in the morning I was on duty in King-street, and saw a bundle thrown over the wall; I saw the prisoner getting over the wall - I asked what he was about; he said he intended to have slept there - I took him in charge, and saw him drop this frock; I got over the wall - nobody was there.

WILLIAM LODWICK
. I am a Policeman. I took up the bundle, which contained some of the things - this handkerchief was found round the prisoner's body, with other things, and another article in his hat.
Prisoner's Defence. I had had no food all day; the things laid under the wall, and I took them up.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1823.
SARAH BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 watch, value 20s., the goods of
William Barber
, from his person .

WILLIAM BARBER. I live at Chelsea. I was in a public-house in the Haymarket, about two o'clock in the morning of Sunday, the 27th of June, and went to Whitcombe-street
with the prisoner, whom I was talking to for some time; she wished me to go home with her - I refused- she turned round, and said, "Here comes the Policeman;" I turned to look at him, and she ran away - I immediately missed my watch; I followed, and lost sight of her, but saw her in custody the same day.

WILLIAM ABBOTT CREWS
. I am a Policeman.
