On the 27th of June, about half-past two o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner going down Parliament-street with a soldier, who was having words with her; she had some thing in her hand - the soldier said, "You have something there, I will give you in charge;" I walked over, and saw her put her hand to her bosom - she turned a corner, and began to run; I followed her, and put my hand on her shoulder - she then took this watch from her bosom, and threw it away; I asked what it was - she said she had no watch; I took it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went to a public-house with him; he was intoxicated - he went to a room with me, and gave me the watch to keep till Monday; we then came out, and he said I had robbed him.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1824.
JOHN BURTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 pocket-book, value 10d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 glove, value 6d., the goods of
John David Barnes
, and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Cross
; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN DAVID BARNES
. I lived in Church-street, Marylebone. I went to a skittle-ground in Bridge-row, Bishopsfields
, on the 7th of July; the prisoner was setting up the skittles - I took off my coat, and hung it on the rails, and on going to it missed my pocket-book, handkerchief, and gloves; I went and took him - he said he had got them, and gave them to me.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. What time did you go there? A. About twelve o'clock; I missed the property about half-past four - there were five or six people there; there was a bustle there, but my coat was not thrown about - I found it where I hung it; the property could not fall out - the prisoner had left the ground, and as a man lost his handkerchief, I looked and missed my things, and went after him; I was sober.

JOHN CROSS
. I was in the skittle-ground. My handkerchief was taken from my hat, on the bench; Barnes stopped the prisoner in a garden, and my handkerchief was found at his feet.

Cross-examined. Q. Where is the garden? A. About twenty yards from the skittle-ground; we were not tipsy- the prisoner offered to fight me; I did not see any other scuffling - my handkerchief was safe after the scuffle; my coat was thrown about.

WILLIAM COWLE
. I am a serjeant of the Police. The prisoner was given into my custody, with the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked the property up underthe form; I did not know whose it was - I kept it till it was called for.

MICHAEL CANNON
. I am a shoemaker. I was passing the skittle-ground, and heard a scuffle - I went in, and took up a coat and hat, which I put on a beer-cask; there was a quarrel among the prisoner and others - Barnes was intoxicated, and was scuffling; clothes and hats laid about in all directions - there might be fifteen or twenty people there, and a great disturbance.

WILLIAM COWLE
. Barnes was not tipsy at all - I saw him about five o'clock.

THOMAS DERBRIDGE
. I am a stone-mason, and live at No. 132. Edgware-road. I have known the prisoner six or seven years - he always bore a very good character; I have had him in my employ - he always bore the character of an honest boy.
Q.Did you not know he was convicted here in January last? A. I certainly did.

SAMUEL DILLON
. I am an officer. On the 6th of January I saw the prisoner tried here; I have a certificate of his conviction - (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .
The witness Derbridge was committed.

1825.
CAROLINE DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 1 watch, value 2l.; 2 sovereigns, and 14 shillings, the property of
Henry Carr
, from his person .

HENRY CARR
. I am mate of the ship Martha, which lays at Limehouse. On the night of the 23rd of August I went with a girl named Allen, to a house in Union-street ; I had two sovereigns in my left-hand pocket, 14s. 6d. in my right, and a watch in my fob; I did not take off my clothes, as I had to go on board early - I laid on the bed, and went to sleep; I told the prisoner to go away, I did not want her - the Policeman awoke me about half-past two o'clock.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not give me the watch and money to take care of? A. I did not - they were in my pockets when I fell asleep; I did not go to her lodgings at all.

WILLIAM WHEELER
. I am a Policeman. I went in search of the prisoner, and found her at a house in Leming-street, Shakespear's-walk; she said if I would go down the yard she would give me the two sovereigns and watch, if I would keep the other girls from coming down - I went, and she gave me them in a piece of flannel; she took them from the privy - I said, "Are these what you took from the man?" she said Yes.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutor had gone to her lodging with her, and given her the property to take care of.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1826.
WILLIAM GARDNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 half-crown, and 1 shilling , the monies of
John Peters
, his master.

JOHN PETERS
. I live in Warner-place, Hackney-road, and am a braid-manufacturer . The prisoner had been two or three times in my employ - on the 1st of July I sent him to Bethnal-green-road, with a half-crown and a shilling, to match some worsted; I expected him to return, but I did not see him till the next morning, when his father brought him.

GEORGE TEAKLE
. I am a Police-officer. I received the prisoner in charge - I asked what he had done with the money, and he said he had spent it.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1727.
WILLIAM GLEESON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 watch, value 5l.; 1 hat, value 10s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 5 half-crowns, 4 shillings, and 3 sixpences , the property of
George Horn
.

GEORGE HORN
. On the morning of the 14th of July, before day-break, I changed a sovereign at a confectioner's shop in the Strand; I received chiefly half-crowns in change, and some shillings and sixpences - I was rather the worse for liquor; a man spoke to me, and followed me from the Strand to Waterloo-bridge
, where I sat down, and fell asleep; I had then a hat, a handkerchief, a watch, and my money - I was awoke by the Policeman, and missed them.

JOHN CRISPIN RAWLEY
. I am a Police-officer. On the morning of the 14th of July, I was on duty in the Strand, about two o'clock, and saw the prosecutor and the prisoner - the prosecutor seemed to wish to get rid of him- I told the prisoner I did not believe he had any knowledge of the prosecutor; he said he had known him for four or five years; I soon afterwards saw the prosecutor asleep on the bridge - he had no hat on - I awoke him, and he complained of his loss; I took the prisoner about three o'clock the same morning - I took from him this hat, five half-crowns, three sixpences, and two shillings, but no watch.

GEORGE HORN
. These are my property.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. You were in liquor? A. Yes; I had been to the Theatre, and might have been in two or three houses - I know my hat was not changed at any of these houses.

JOHN RATTRAY
. I am an officer. I saw the prosecutor and prisoner walking towards Waterloo-bridge - one of them had his handkerchief hanging out, and I told him of it; I saw them turn, and both fall down - I assisted to help the prosecutor up - he then walked towards Waterloobridge; he appeared to have been drinking - the prisoner said, "He is an acquaintance of mine," and walked after him.
Cross-examined. Q. When they fell down were their hats off? A. Yes, and they might be changed at that time.

J. C. RAWLEY. The prisoner had only this one hat when I took him - I recollect seeing their hats fall off, and I particularly noticed the prisoner's hat; he put his own hat on his head, not this one - his hat was a very indifferent one.

Cross-examined. Q. Is not this such a hat as the little boys in the street follow, crying "Shocking had hat?" A. I should think not - I went to the hatter, and found the prosecutor by that means; I took the prisoner opposite Wellington-street.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent. I was very much intoxicated, and cannot say whether that was the gentleman I was with or not.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Life .

1828.
MICHAEL HAYLES
was indicted for
stealing 1 half-sovereign, 3 half-crowns, 4 shillings, and 6d. in copper , the monies of
Ellen McCarthy
.

The prosecutrix being married, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1829.
MARY LAWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 2 sheets, value 8s., and 2 pillow-cases, value 2s. , the goods of
William Buckingham
.

HANNAH BUCKINGHAM
. I am the wife of
William Buckingham
; we live in Wood's-place, Westminster
- the prisoner had a furnished room in our house. On the 7th of August I went into her room, and missed these things; I asked about them - she said they were gone to the wash - I gave her into custody - the officer found on her sixteen duplicates - three of them relate to my property; my husband is a groom in the country.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shawl and two pillow-cases, pawned on the 1st of August, for 1s. 3d., and a sheet on the 2nd, for 1s. 6d.; I think by the prisoner, but I cannot swear it - they are in the name of
Susan Williams
and Mary Williams.

THOMAS WALTERS
. I am an officer. On the 7th of August I received the prisoner in custody; she said she had sent the things to wash - I sent the prosecutrix to see, and it was not true - I then asked the prisoner to give up the duplicates - she would not; I then searched, and found these duplicates on her.

GEORGE RODOLPH
. I have a sheet, pawned on the 27th of July; I cannot say by whom, but I gave this duplicate for it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The woman who pawned them sent me the duplicates, and I kept them to get them out, which I should have done with pleasure.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY .

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1830.
HENRY BROWN
and
JOHN BURN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the money of
James Michie
, from his person .

JOHN PENNY
. On a Saturday evening, (I think the 16th of July,) I saw the prisoners together by the Duke of Devonshire's, in Piccadilly; they followed the prosecutor - I saw Brown put his right hand into the prosecutor's lefthand pocket, and take out a silk handkerchief, which he gave to Burn, who put it into his pocket; they went different ways - Boothman took this handkerchief from Burn.

JAMES MICHIE
. I was in Piccadilly
on Saturday, I think the 16th of July, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening, with my sister; I felt my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; I saw Burn brought across the road, and my handkerchief was produced to me - I did not see Brown that night; this is my handkerchief.

WILLIAM BOOTHMAN
. I took Burn, and got this handkerchief from his pocket; I had seen the prisoners following the prosecutor up Piccadilly - I did not see the handkerchief pass, but I saw Burn put it into his pocket - on the following Monday I took Burn to the Police-office - Brown followed, and I took him.
Brown's Defence. I was in Silver-street; the officer came and asked what I had done with my green coat; I said I had not one.

WILLIAM BOOTHMAN
. He had a green coat on when it was taken.
Burn's Defence. I am a carpenter; I picked up the handkerchief in a crowd.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

BURN -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Life .

1831.
JOHN SMITH
and
JOSEPH FROOM
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 cart, value 15l. , the goods of
George Wiseman
.

JOHN NEWTON
. I am a constable. On the morning of the 2nd of August I saw Smith coming out of Chapel-street, into Lamb's Conduit-street, drawing a spring-cart; I saw him again in Brunswick-square, and Froom with him - Smith then gave up the shafts, and Froom drew it some distance; then Smith took it, till they came to Gower-street, and there they left it; I stopped Smith in Gower-street North, and said he must come with me - he said it was all nonsense; I took Froom on the 3rd of August, in a stable - I was behind a door, and heard him say,"We shall go down to the office to-morrow, and hear more about it."
Smith. I was hired to draw it to the corner of Tottenham court-road. Witness. He did not say so at the time; he did at the office.

GEORGE WISEMAN
. I live in Queen's Head-court, Grays' Inn-lane. The cart is mine; on the Monday night I had left it safe in Cockpit-yard
, which is no thoroughfare; it had stood there for two years - I missed it the next morning, between five and six o'clock, and saw it again between seven and eight; it is worth 15l. - my name is on it.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 25.

FROOM -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1832.
JOHN WINES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
Robert Warren Miller
.

HENRY SHIPP
. I am a Thames Police-constable. On the 6th of September I stopped the prisoner going out of the West India-dock
, with a wheelbarrow, with a box in it; I asked for the key of it, he felt in his pocket, and said he could not find it - I broke it open and found this blue coat and this bit of canvas; the prisoner said he did not know how they came there, nor what they were; he afterwards said some man whom he did not know, gave him 1s. to take it out.

ROBERT WARREN MILLER
. I am an officer on board the ship General Palmer, in the West-India dock. I had seen this coat safe at half-past twelve o'clock - I saw the prisoner there before one; he was supplying the sailmaker's in the loft with beer; that was where my coat was.
Prisoner. A man asked me to take it.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1833.
ELIZABETH RIDLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 3 sheets, value 12s.; 1 blanket, value 4s.; 1 table cloth, value 2s., and 4 pillow-cases, value 2s. , the goods of
Silas Vidler
.

ELIZABETH VIDLER
. I am the wife of
Silas Vidler
, a green-grocer , who lives in Cromer-street
. On the 11th of March the prisoner took a room at our house, and on the 5th of September I took an officer, and examined the room; I then missed this property - the duplicates were produced.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Is your husband here? A. Yes; I was greatly surprised at the loss of these things - she had pawned before, but the things were replaced, and it was made up; she had not apprised me of pawning these things - they owed money for rent, but since she had been in prison, her husband had paid 1l. 13s.; the prisoner had said she had 2000l. coming to her, I do not consider such a person could be in distress: I had not asked them for rent - she had promised to pay the rent two or three days before she was taken.

WILLIAM HALL
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner on the 5th of September; I asked if she had any duplicates - she said Yes, went to a drawer, and pulled out a purse with a great many duplicates; I looked them over and the prosecutor claimed some of them - the prisoner said her husband was in the City, she thought he would not he long, but if he were there, he would know nothing about it; as she had pawned them herself - she said the pillow-cases had been lost at the wash; she made no difficulty of showing the duplicates.
Cross-examined. Q.Were they not in distress? A. They did not appear so; there was a good dinner providing, of meat and pudding - there were some duplicates for pledges as low as 6d.

THOMAS WARD
. I am in the employ of Mr. Burgess, a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, pawned on the 31st of March, and on the 31st of August, by a woman; I cannot say who - I gave her these duplicates.

ELIZABETH BARTLETT
. I am a pawnbroker, in Crownstreet. I have a sheet and table-cloth, pawned on the 20th and 26th of August, by a woman; these are the duplicates I gave.

JOHN SPENCER
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker. I have a blanket, pawned on the 19th of August, by a woman. to whom I gave this duplicate.
MRS. VIDLER. These are all my property; I did not know any thing was missing till I went into the room.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that they had pawned the goods being in poverty, and that the prosecutrix had agreed to allow them time to redeem them.
SILAS VIDLER. That was the first pawning; I did not know about these.
NOT GUILTY .

1834.
JOHN AUSTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 30 yards of diaper, value 30s. , the goods of
Matthew Halling
and others.

THOMAS OSBORN. I am a clerk to Matthew Halling, Pearce, and Stone, warehousemen, Cockspur-street. The prisoner was their porter ; on the 15th of August the prisoner received an order to take out some goods - I followed him, and brought him back; I searched his bag, and found thirty yards of diaper, which he had no right to take out.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were not the parcels he had to take out in the warehouse? A. Yes, he had to take out five or six; these diapers were within three or four yards of them - he told me it was a mistake; he had been entrusted with considerable sums of money - I never had any quarrel with him; I have heard him complain that I imposed more work on him than I did on the other men, but I did not do so - he had got about one hundred yards from the door when I took him; I did not say before the Magistrates that it was twenty yards - I think not.

WILLIAM DAVIS
. I was an officer. I received the prisoner, and produce the diaper given me by Mr. Pearce.

COURT to
THOMAS OSBORN
. Q.Were the parcels he was to take out directed? A. Yes, they were written on when the young men sold them in the shop; it was the prisoner's duty to put the parcels into the bag - I enter them in the book, and he calls them over.

JURY. Q. Does he enter his parcels in a porter's book? A. No, they sometimes make a memorandum on a slip of paper; I had missed this parcel before I went after the prisoner - he did not call this over; I am not aware of any parcel being left behind which he should have taken out.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1835.
MARY ARNOLD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 1 sovereign, the money of
John Vincent
, from his person .

JOHN VINCENT. I am a labourer at Mr. Richmond's brew-house. On the 2nd of July I left the brew-house, at half-past ten o'clock, and was going home; I saw the prisoner, who was a stranger to me - she said she wanted me for a few minutes; I said, "What do you want me for?" she slipped her hand into my right-hand trousers pocket, and took out a sovereign - I had not spoken three words to her; I felt her hand in my pocket, and as she was pulling it out I seized her arm - she slipped the money round to another girl behind; I know it had been safe not two minutes before - I then gave her in charge -4s. 41/2d. was found on her.
GEORGE FURLONG. I am a Police-officer. The prosecutor gave charge of the prisoner for taking a sovereign out of his pocket; she was trying to get from him.
Prisoner's Defence. He was against the shop, and I was on the curh; I could not take it from him.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Life .

1836.
WILLIAM HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 purse, value 6d., and 8s., the property of a person unknown, from his person .

EDMUND LANCASTER
. I am a Police-constable. On the 1st of August I was in the Strand
, between six and seven o'clock in the evening; it was a few minutes before their Majesties came from the opening of London-bridge -I saw the prisoner near Hungerford-street, and two or three others very near him; I saw the prisoner and another mix with the crowd when their Majesties came by - I watched them, and soon afterwards saw the prisoner's hand in a gentleman's trousers pocket - he drew out his hand, and this purse was hanging in it; I seized his hand, and the purse twisted round my finger - his companion struckme on the ear, and knocked me down; Styles came to my assistance - we were both beaten about a great deal, but I still kept hold of the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. No; the officers were standing in a line, about eight yards apart - the pressure was so great that the gentleman could not hear me; he was carried away with the crowd - I was struck the very moment I caught hold of the prisoner.
COURT. Q. Are you able to say whether the prisoner himself struck you? A. He struck me several times, but not at that moment - he and I had a fight up as far as St. Martin's church.

JAMES STYLES
. I was on duty, and saw Lancaster engaged with the prisoner and another; I went up, and Lancaster said, "Secure that hand, he has got some money in it" - I seized the prisoner's hand, which was then up, and found 8s. in it.
Cross-examined. Q. How far were you off? A. Not two yards; I did not see the person who lost the purse, the confusion was so great, and we were so ill-used.

Prisoner's Defence. The property belonged to me - I believe I have people here to prove it; there was 8s. 6d. in the purse, and I took it out to lend a young man sixpence- the Policeman took hold of it; I said, "You shall not have it;" he said he would - I said, "Mind, there is 8s. 6d."

CAROLINE DAVIS
. My husband is a broker. I have known the prisoner about twenty years; on the day the bridge was opened, I had seen him from about twelve o'clock to between six and half-past six - he then went out, and did not return; I know he had a dark red purse, with some silver, as he had been taking shillings and sixpences for allowing people to see the sight on the water.

COURT. Q. You do not live with him? A. No; my husband is a furniture-broker - I went to Arundel-street, where the prisoner lives, to see the sight; the prisoner has been employed by my husband these three months, to carry furniture; I saw the purse in his hand that evening, and saw him put money into it - I have seen the purse before, but not to notice it; it is a silk purse.

CHARLOTTE READ
. My husband was an outrider, and lives at Hampstead. On the 1st of August I was in Arundel-street, at a house which the prisoner's mother has the care of; I saw the prisoner receive several shillings from persons who came to see the procession - I did not see any purse.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1837.
MARY CROSS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 sovereign, the monies of
John Hood
, from his person .

JOHN HOOD. I am a seaman ; I came home in the Cambridge. I put into the hands of my landlady three sovereigns and a half, on the 24th of August; next day I went there, and called for a glass of liquor, asked for the money, and gave them the card they had given me; they gave me the three sovereigns; I said, "Change the halfsovereign, and take for the liquor;" the prisoner came in, put her hand into my hand, and took out a sovereign - I turned round, and said, "Give me that sovereign;" she put her hand to her mouth, and said, "I have not your sovereign, I have not seen it;" she said she wanted a pint of beer - the landlady took her backwards, and overhauled her; but the sovereign has never been found - I had never spoken to her before; I do not know that I had seen her.

MARY ELIZABETH PERKINS
. My father keeps the White-hart public-house, Shadwell
. The prosecutor left three sovereigns and a half with us; he came and had the three sovereigns, and wanted change for the halfsovereign; I saw the prisoner take a sovereign out of his hand - he mentioned it directly, and she was searched, but it has never been found.

JOHN MITCHELL
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner, but found nothing on her.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to get a pint of beer; there were several young women there, and one of them, whom I knew, asked me to have a glass of liquor, which I did; I was coming out, and the prosecutor said I had taken his sovereign - I had never seen it.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1838.
JAMES CARTWRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 5 umbrellas, value 30s. , the goods of
George Mason Isaacs
.

GEORGE MASON ISAACS. I live at Goodman's-style
, and am an umbrellas-maker . I lost these umbrellas on the 29th of August, from the window.

ESTHER ISAACS
. I am the prosecutor's sister. The prisoner came to the house, and I opened the door - he rushed in before I could get the door open; he went to the window, and took the umbrellas - I hanged the door too, and set my back against it to prevent his getting out of the shop - I had no one in the house, but I called out Uncle! thinking that would frighten the prisoner - I saw the Policeman go by in about five minutes; I called him in, and gave charge of him.

THOMAS DAULBY
. I am an officer. I was called in about twelve o'clock - I found the prisoner with his back against the counter, and five umbrellas lying on his left side, which Isaacs charged him with stealing from the window - I asked him his reason for doing so; he said that would be known by-and-by; he supposed they sold them; I said Yes, but they were not to be stolen.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I shall leave it to the mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1839.
JANE CHARRINGTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 spoon, value 2s. 6d., and 1 table-cloth, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Elizabeth Vincent
, her mistress.

ELIZABETH VINCENT. I am single , and live in Henry-street, Bedford-square, Commercial-road
- the prisoner had been twelve months my servant of all work. On the 8th of August I went to the theatre, at half-past nine o'clock, leaving the property all secure; I left only the prisoner in the house - I was sent for, and informed something had occurred; I got home at twenty minutes past ten o'clock - I saw the prisoner at home; she said, "My dear creature, you are ruined, and robbed of your money, watch, chain, and two silk dresses," but I found the silkdresses were not gone; I asked if she had seen any one- she said she fancied some one brushed by her in the back yard; I asked her what sort of a person it was - she said he had a great-coat on; I took the candle, went up stairs, and found the three drawers were turned out of my chest of draweres, and were all in confusion - I had left them locked; I asked her where she had been - she said in at the next house playing at cards, and while there she heard a double knock at my door; that she thought I had come home, and she asked them to let her get over the back way and get in at the back door - she went to the street door, and found it bolted; the officer then came in, and I gave charge of the prisoner; I had a gold watch in my drawer, and the prisoner had seen me put three sovereigns to twenty-two, in a purse in the drawer, while she was making the bed in the morning; I left it all safe when I went to the play - I have never seen the watch or the money since; no person but the prisoner knew they were there - a table-cloth and spoon were afterwards produced, which I had not missed then; I afterwards found a key in the bottom of the coal-hole, which unlocked all my drawers; I believe I had seen that key in the prisoner's possession; my drawers had not been broken open - the prisoner went by the name of Lill when she first came to me; that was her first husband's name.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q.Was there any thing to have prevented the prisoner from absconding before you got home? A. No; there is a communication to the next house by the back way- she might have come in that way; 3s. 6d. was found on her; a Mrs. Carter might have visited at my house unknown to me - I have since heard she was in the habit of coming; I believe search has been made for her- the prisoner sent for me home, and told me of this; I know the persons who live at the next house - I have visited there, but not played at cards or drank tea there; I never allowed the prisoner to go - there is a kitchen and a wall between the two back doors; I have gone by the name of Thompson, but my name is Vincent.

GEORGE HARRISON
. I am a Police-constable. I was on duty, and went to this house; the prisoner was there, but the prosecutrix had not arrived - the prisoner said her mistress had been robbed of money and jewellery during her absence next door; that the people said there was a double-knock at the door, and as her mistress had desired her not to leave the house, she got over the back wall - when she got to the street door, she found it bolted; she said she fancied all was not right, went up stairs, found the drawers out, and missed the property - she said she fancied that as she got over the wall some one brushed by her, but it being dark she thought it was a cat; but when she found the drawers had been opened, she thought it was a person in a dark coloured coat; she went up again with me, and I saw the doors opened - I went backwards, and scaled several walls, but saw no one; there was nothing found on her.

Cross-examined. Q. What sort of a neighbourhood is this? A. The square is very respectable; some of the streets adjoining have bad houses in them, but I know of only one bad house in that street, and that is the prosecutrix's.

REBECCA CLUTTERBUCK
. I searched the prisoner at the watch-house, and found this duplicate under her shift - she parted with it very reluctantly.

JAMES HARRIS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a tablecloth and spoon, pawned on the 8th of August, in the name of
Ann Lill
, by a woman, for 1s. 6d. - I gave her this duplicate; it was not the prisoner who pawned them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent; the duplicate was picked up at the step of the door, when a person came to light a candle.

GUILTY . Aged 52. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1840.
THOMAS FORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 box, value 2s., the goods of
John Drinkwater
, from his person .

JOHN DRINKWATER. I was coming, on the 1st of August, from Hanwell
to Brompton
; my mother and brother were with me - I was taken unwell, and retired; I fell into a fit, and as I was recovering, I found the prisoner's right hand in my right-hand waistcoat pocket, where I had a box, containing two duplicates - he still staid with me; we then went on; I told my brother and mother of it, but I did not ask the prisoner for the box - we went on to the Seven Stars, and called for a pint of beer; the prisoner followed us in - I sent for the Policeman; my brother knew the prisoner, but I did not.

WILLIAM PEASGOOD
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner; I said, "I want you, you know what for;" he said, "I shan't come;" the prosecutor then said, "I give him in charge;" the prisoner said, "Oh! about this box," and took it out of his pocket - I said, "Give it to me;" he said, "I shan't," and put it into his pocket again - I took him to the station.(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS DRINKWATER
. I was with my brother - I did not see the prisoner take the box, but I saw him pull it out at the public-house.
Prisoner's Defence. He said would I give up the box; I said not till I got to the office.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined Seven Days .

1841.
SAMUEL GREENLAND
was indicted for
embezzlement .

CHARLES JAMES FOX
. I am a trimming-manufacturer . The prisoner had been in my employ about five weeks - he was employed to go out to sell goods, and receive money; he was to account for them every day - I did not keep a book; I looked over his box when he returned.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Was he your regular servant ? A. Yes - Bell, Bentley, and Co., in Cheapside, became customers of mine a few days after the prisoner came into my service; I charge the prisoner with selling goods to them, and not accounting to me for them - I did not trust him with a very large stock; I never allowed him any commission on what he sold, or agreed to do so - I keep some books, but when he took out goods for sale I merely made a memorandum of them, and looked over the box when he came back; he should account as soon as he came home - I entered the goods that were sold in a day-book; I have not brought that book - these sums I charge him with are entered in the day-book, but not as paid; I have no means of knowing what he sold, except from the day-book, and the bills of parcels.

JOHN BUCKERIDGE
. I am in the service of Bell, Bentley, and Co. I am not in the habit of buying goods, but I paid the prisoner 6s. for two pieces of cotton-fringe, on the 25th of June.

HENRY BOLTON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner- his master asked him what he had done with the money; he said he had lost two sovereigns, he had lent 6s., and 13s. he had spent at Fairlop fair.
COURT to CHARLES JAMES FOX. Q. Did he at any time give you an account of the 6s.? A. He said he had sold the goods, and he was to call again for the money.
Cross-examined. Q. When was that? A. On the 25th of June, the day he sold the goods - there is a memorandum of the fringe being sold, but not of the money being paid.
NOT GUILTY .

1842.
JOHN JUDD
(THE YOUNGER) was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 1 purse, value 6d.; 4 sovereigns, two 10l. Bank-notes, and one 5l. Bank-note, the property of
Thomas Philip Davis
, from the person of
Elizabeth Kingsford
.
MR. PHILLIPS. conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS
PHILIP DAVIS
. On the 30th of June I was just outside the Red Cow, at Hammersmith
, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night -
Elizabeth Kingsford
was with me; she had two 10l. notes, one 5l. note, and four sovereigns of mine - I had seen the prisoner about half a mile before we got to that public-house, and he went there with us; he was a stranger to me - we were in the public-house for a quarter of an hour; there were candles there, and I had a full opportunity of seeing his person - I am quite sure he is the man; we came out together, and soon afterwards I fell down (being lame) - the prisoner held me up in his arms till I was half up; he then ran off as fast as ever he could; I was not exactly sober, but was perfectly sensible to know every transaction - he had not shown any anxiety in the public-house to get away, but when he had got me half up he said, "I shall be locked out, I must run as fast as I can;" soon after he was gone Kingsford complained of the loss of my money - I saw the prisoner a few days afterwards, in Hammersmith: I got off the coach which I was on, and gave him and Hammond into custody - I saw the prisoner searched; a silver watch and 7s. 11d. was found on him - I told the officer that I took him for robbing Kingsford of 29l., and the prisoner said, "You remember I was by myself on Thursday night."

SARAH DAVIS
. I am sister of the prosecutor. I gave him two 10l. notes and one 5l. note on the 30th of June, which I had got out of the Court of Chancery.

ELIZABETH KINGSFORD
. On the 30th of June I was with Mr. Davis; he gave me two 10l. notes, a 5l. note, and four sovereigns in a purse - we went to the Red Cow; I saw the prisoner there - I had a full opportunity of viewing his features; I am confident he is the man - on going out Mr. Davis fell down; I stopped to assist him, and the prisoner stopped to assist me - he then ran off as fast as he could towards Hammersmith; I called to him, he said he must go, or he should be locked out of his lodging - soon after he was gone I put my hand into my bosom, and missed the purse and all the money; I have not seen it since - we had some ale at the Red Cow.

COURT. Q. What are you? A. I am servant with Mr. Davis; he at that time lived at Hammersmith - we had been to London that day; he has frequently given me his money to take care of - I opened the purse when he gave it me, and counted the money before his face; I am quite confident it did not fall out of my bosom - it must have been picked out, but I did not feel it taken; I had put it low down while we were in the public-house - the prosecutor asked if I had the money safe; I told him to put his hand to my bosom, and he would be convinced, which he did - the prisoner saw that.

RICHARD HAMMOND
. I was in the street with the prisoner, and Mr. Davis gave him and me into custody; I had known him a great while, and on the day before we were taken he had given me two 10l. notes, and one 5l. note, to get changed for him - I changed one of them at Mr. Munday's, a cheesemonger, at Kensington, and I changed the 5l. at Mr. Brown's, at Knightsbridge - the prisoner asked me to get them changed for him; I did not give it a thought why he could not change them himself - he told me he had found them, but did not say where.

COURT. Q. Did he give you the three notes at once? A. No, at different times - he did not give me any thing, but I drank with him; here is one of the notes I got changed at one place; I do not know which - I know it by the writing on the back.

THOMAS BROWN
. I changed a 5l. note for Hammond on the 1st of July, when he took some goods out from my shop, in the name of Judd.

SARAH DAVIS. I know this 10l. note, by the name of Emery, which I wrote on it, and I know this 5l. note also, but I was not aware till this moment that they had been found - I gave them both to my brother.

CHARLES JOSEPH BEETSON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner and Hammond; I found this purse on the prisoner's father, in the house the prisoner lives in.(Purse produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. My father sent me with two dirty shirts to wash; on my return, just before I got to the Hand and Flower public-house, I picked up the purse - it was then about nine o'clock; I went on, and saw the prosecutor laying down - he asked me to pick him up, and said his wife was on before him, in a waggon, and they had left him behind; he said at the next public-house he would have something to drink - I believe I had two glasses of ale, and then said, "I must run home."

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1843.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 12 half-crowns, 30 shillings, 20 sixpences, and three 5l. Bank notes , the property of
Thomas Wilkinson
.

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the property of
Thomas Smith
.

THOMAS SMITH
. I drive the Wantage waggon - the prisoner was in my service, and used to assist me in driving, On the 23rd of August I had two purses, containing 20 half-crowns, 20 shillings, 20 sixpences, and three 5l. Bank notes; they were all in a bag in the waggon - he walked away in the night, without saying any thing to me, which gave me suspicion - I got into the waggon, and missed the bag, money,and notes; I spoke to Dunner, the patrol, and he brought the prisoner to me in the course of the night.

SAMUEL DUNNER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. Smith gave me information, and I found the prisoner near the ten mile-stone on the Staines road; the waggon was going the contrary direction - he said he had not been with the waggon at all, that he had been up the road with four baskets, and was then returning home; I found on him the two purses and the silver - I could not find the notes, and he denied having them; I took him back, and met the prosecutor - I then stripped the prisoner, and he took the three 5l. notes out of his bosom; here are the notes, the bag, and the money.

THOMAS SMITH
. This purse is mine, and I believe the notes also.
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me the notes out of the waggon, told me to walk on, and I should meet him at Colnbrook the next morning.

GUILTY . Aged 16 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1844.
ROBERT JASSET
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 1 pair of trousers, value 4s. , the goods of
John George Caiger
.

JOHN GEORGE
CAIGER. These are my trousers - I lost them on the 5th of August, from opposite Goldsmith's floor-cloth manufactory, while I was gone to Billingsgate; they hung on a rail of the bedstead - I had employed the prisoner to sell ginger-beer for me; he left me without notice - he was taken on the 11th of August, with the trousers on him.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Seven Days .

1845.
WILLIAM MASHFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of June , 1 live tame drake, price 1s. 6d. , the property of
William Barlow
.

CHARLES BANFIELD
. I live in York-terrace, Kingsland-road - Mr. William Barlow has a duck-pond in a field which he rents. About the middle of June I saw the prisoner with a man named Ware, who was convicted here; they got a penny-loaf, and they threw the bread to the ducks, and when they came near, they caught them, and put them into their pockets.

GEORGE BARTRAN
. I am servant to Mr. Barlow. I was in his field - I saw the prisoner and the other lad come and entice the ducks with the bread - they went away - the prisoner escaped at that time, but was taken afterwards.

WILLIAM BARLOW
. I am a corn-dealer . The ducks were mine; Ware was tried for stealing a drake - I knew the prisoner many years ago.
Prisoner's Defence. I am not the person who was with Ware.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Three Months .

1846.
EMMA WRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 4 table-cloths, value 30s., 2 aprons, value 2s., and 1 sheet, value 5s. , the goods of
John Thomas
, her master.

MARY ANN
THOMAS. I am the wife of
John Thomas
. I am a lace cleaner, and the prisoner was my apprentice - she has been with me since March 1827. On the 17th of August I had desired some boxes in the cellar to be be broken up; I noticed one, which was very clean, and on opening that, I found a box containing several duplicates, and some small remnants of lace.

WILLIAM HOLMES
. I am a pawnbroker. I live in Museum-street. I have four table-cloths, one sheet, and two aprons, which I took in pledge from the prisoner at different times.

GEORGE BOLTON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1847.
GEORGE THOMPSON
and
PETER DALEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Guest
, from the person of
Thomas William Guest
.

THOMAS WHITNEY. I am an officer. On the 18th of July, about half past one o'clock, I was at the corner of Union-street, Hackney-road; I saw the prisoners, with another person, attempting to pick a gentleman's pocket; I followed them, and at the corner of Union-street
I saw Daley go deliberately behind a young woman, and unclasp the necklace from the child's neck, which she had - I seized the prisoners, but they had passed the necklace to the third person, who ran off with it; he was younger than them.

EMMA BEDFORD
. I am nursery-maid to Mr.
Thomas Guest
- he lives in Union-street. I had the care of his infant,
Thomas William Guest
; I clasped on his necklace when I left home; it was a coral necklace, with a gold snap - the officer apprised me of its being taken - the child was in my arms, leaning on my shoulder.
The prisoners received a good character.

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

DALEY -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

Confined Six Months and
Whipped .
OLD COURT. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 19.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1848.
GEORGE DUNCAN
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JOHN BADDER
. I keep the Duke of York public-house , Vauxhall-bridge-road: the prisoner was in my service - he had to receive money, and to account to me for it every night. On the 14th of July he asked leave to go out for an hour, and did not return; he was found in the street next day, tipsy, and this was discovered afterwards.

ABRAHAM HORNBY
. I live in Arlington-street. On the 10th of July I saw my wife pay the prisoner 3s. 2d. on Mr. Badder's account.

ELLEN MAHONY
. I live in Berwick-street, and am servant to Mrs. Jones. On the 9th of July I paid the prisoner 7s. 8d. on my master's account - here is the bill, upon which he has written his name in peneil.

JOHN BADDER
. The prisoner never paid me either of these sums; I repeatedly asked him for them - he said he had not received them: this is his hand-writing on the bill.
Prisoner. I never received these sums.

GUILTY . Aged 47. -
Confined Six Months .

1849.
MARY MYDDLETON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 boy's dress, value 5s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; 1 frill and collar,value 1s., and 1 pinafore, value 1s., the goods of
Robert Newton
, from the person of
William Newton
.

JAMES ROBINSON
. I am a gate-keeper of St. James'-park. On the 31st of August I stopped two boys from going into the Park, because they had pinafores on; the prisoner came and asked why I turned them out - she went away with them; I saw her talking to them a few yards from the gate, and then lost sight of her.

WILLIAM CRICK
. I am a Policeman. On the 31st of August I found two poor children close to Shoreditch church, crying - they were stripped; I made inquiry, and another constable found their parents out two days afterwards; I took one of them to Shoreditch poor-house.

PATRICK MURPHY
. I am a labourer. On the 31st of August I saw one child crying in Shoreditch, it was a boy; he had nothing on but a pinafore, and a small pair of trousers.

CAROLINE MARTHA NEWTON
. I am eleven years old. I went to the Park with my two little brothers; the keeper would not let us in, because we had pinafores on, and I was not old enough to mind them; the prisoner came up, and told us to keep inside the Park; I said the keeper would not let us; she spoke to him; she then came and told me to go round to the Horse-guards' gate; she was then within a few yards of Storey's-gate; she gave me a penny, and said, "Go and get a penny worth of apples" - I had some playthings and an apple in my lap; she said, "That apple is not large enough for you, go and fetch a pennyworth;" I went, and when I came back she was gone, and my two brothers too - I was not gone long; I said, "William and Johnny don't go away"- she said, "No, I'll take care of that;" one of them is six and the other four years old.

JOSEPH HAWKRIGG
. I belong to Aldersgate-street parish. The prisoner was given into my custody at Guildhall on another charge; I heard of these children being stolen, and had her detained; Newton took his children to the prison - they are too ill to be brought here, and have been so ever since.

ROBERT NEWTON
. I live in Tothill-street, Westminster. From Wednesday to Friday I was in the greatest distress about my children, and out day and night; I found one in the workhouse in Shoe-lane, and the other in Shoreditch workhouse - the youngest had a pinafore over him, with his little trousers; the other had scarcely any thing on - I took my daughter, Caroline, to the prison; all the female prisoners were turned into the yard; she pointed the prisoner out among twenty, immediately; I have not found their clothes.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not strip the children, or take any thing from them - I was at Red-Lion-square in the evening from half-past four o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Life .
See page 831. - There was also another indictment against her.

1850.
JANE BRUICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 2 watches, value 2l.; 1 seal, value 7s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 3s., and 2 sovereigns , the property of
Moss Jewell
, her master.

MOSS JEWELL
. I live in High-street, Shadwell
. The prisoner was in my service for about a week; I missed a watch the latter end of July; and on Monday, the 1st of August, I had occasion to look over a looking-glass drawer in my bed-room, I took out two sovereigns, and left three there - the prisoner went out that day with my daughter, who gave me information; I went to the drawer that evening, and two out of the three sovereigns were gone; the drawer had been opened by a key - next morning, when the Policeman came by, I called him in; I then called the prisoner, and said, "How came you to open my drawer, and take two sovereigns?" she said,"How could I do so when mistress had the key?" I said,"How came you by the two sovereigns you spent yesterday?" she said she was married to a man who gave her one, and that her former master gave her another - she said,"You may search me, I have not a single shilling;" I took her to the station-house - a sovereign, 4s. 6d., and the duplicate of a watch were found on her - we asked where the young man she was married to lived; she never told us - we found in her box a gold seal, which I had missed, and a key which opened my drawer, also a pair of shoes of her mistress, and a street-door key - we found out the young man; I asked him for the watch Jane had given him; he gave me a watch; I had lost two watches, and about six sovereigns had been stolen.

GEORGE FURLONG
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner's box, and have the duplicate of the watch; the prosecutor's evidence is correct - I found the seal at the bottom of one of the prisoner's stockings.

MARIA EDWARDS
. My husband is a Police-officer. I searched the prisoner, and found a purse, containing a sovereign, 4s. 6d., and a duplicate in her pocket; she said if she told me something, would I not tell again; I said I did not want to hear any thing; she afterwards said the money belonged to her father.

SOMERVILLE TELVER
. I am a pawnbroker. The watch was found at my house, in Broad-street: I believe the prisoner to be the person who pawned it - the duplicate found is what I gave for it.

JOHN HENRY ROLT
. I am a shipwright, and have known the prisoner three months. On the 31st of July she gave me a watch to take care of; Mr. Jewell came to me on the 2nd of August, and I gave it to Clayton; the prisoner told me a young man who kept company with her four years ago, was drowned, and that was his watch.

WILLIAM CLAYTON
. I am a Policeman. I have the watch.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she purchased the shoes of her mistress; that one watch belonged to her father, the other had been given to her by the prosecutor's son, who had been intimate with her, and that the money was her own.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1851.
MARY CASHMAN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving 11/2 yard of ribbon, value 1s. 2d., the goods of
Thomas Bunn
, well knowing the same to have been stolen .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1852.
LUCY DAY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 3rd of June , 4 yards of ribbon, value5s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Bunn
, well knowing the same to have stolen .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1853.
ELIZABETH LANGHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Millar
.

THOMAS DAVIE. I am a shopman to John Millar, a linen-draper , in High-street, Shadwell
. On the 9th of July, about twelve o'clock at night, the shop was closed; the prisoner came there with her mistress, and looked at some things, and was in the shop about ten minutes - her mistress bought nothing; the prisoner bought a piece of ribbon for shoe-strings - when I put the handkerchiefs on the counter, the prisoner took them up, and shortly afterwards went to the door; on my putting the handkerchiefs back I missed one, and accused her of having it, but she denied it - I called the servant to search her; she would not allow her bonnet to he taken off - the servant saw part of the handkerchief behind part of her bonnet; I sent for an officer - he brought it to me; it has the shop mark on it.

ELLEN MANAH
. I am a servant to Mr. Millar. I saw part of the handkerchief under the prisoners bonnet; she sat in a chair, and put her hand up, pulled the handkerchief from under her bonnet, and put it under her chair- the constable was sent for, I said, "You need not search her," she has got it under her chair.

WILLIAM BUTLER
. I am a Policeman. I saw the handkerchief under the prisoner's person.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I lived at home with my mother and father. Mrs. Bulmer asked me to come and mind her house while she lived at Gravesend; she came back on Saturday night, and asked me to go with her to the linen-draper's, she being intoxicated - when she got there she gave me one of the handkerchiefs, which she said she would pay for, and told me to put it away in my basket; the Policeman was called in - Mrs. Bulmer gave him 4s. to let her go; they dragged me to the watch-house.

JULIA BULMER
. I accompanied the prisoner to the shop; she was my servant - I went to buy some ribbon; the box of handkerchiefs was produced - I did not see her take any, but on one being missed, I refused to leave till I was searched - after the prisoner was charged with it, I saw her take it from under her bonnet, and put it on her chair; I did not give it her - she had been three weeks with me; I had her character from her mother.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

1854.
JOHN LANGHORN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Charles Peake
, from his person .

CHARLES PEAKE. I live at Kennington-common. I was going through Hatton-garden
last Monday, and felt a motion at my pocket; I turned round instantly, and seized the prisoner, who had two others with him - he produced my handkerchief to me immediately; it was safe just before.

PATRICK WALLACE
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Two boys picked the gentleman's pocket, and threw the handkerchief at me; he turned round and seized me as I was going to deliver it to him.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1855.
JOHN LABURN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 portmanteau, value 5s.; 7 neckcloths, value 7s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 3s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 6d.; 3 pairs of gloves, value 1s. 6d.; 1 comb, value 1s.; 1 brush, value 2d.; 1 Bible, value 2s.; 1 razor, value 1s., and 1 shaving-box, value 6d. , the goods of
John Jones Fouracres
.

DIANA JONES FOURACRES
. I am the wife of
John Jones Fouracres
, who is a labourer . On Wednesday, the 24th of August, at one o'clock in the day, this portmanteau was safe, on the drawers in my own room, No. 1, Willow-walk, Hoxton
, on the ground-floor; it contained the articles stated in the indictment - it was locked; at four o'clock that afternoon I was informed that it was taken out of my room - I went and found it in a privy; it had been cut at the top, and part of the contents were gone - the privy is no great distance from my house; as I brought it back I met a girl, who gave me information.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is your real name Fouracres? A. It is - I have been married these eleven years - I have been called Jones by some people; the landlady said it was a long name, and I might as well go by the name of Jones only - I went by the name of
Diana Jones
Fouracres at the first examination - I have every reason to believe so; I will not swear it, for my mind is so tortured I scarcely know what I do say; I am convinced I gave my right name - I washed for a Mr. Willoughby, a bookseller, in Goswell-street; I then lived just by Aske-street, Hoxton - I will be on my oath I never pawned his clothes; I have lived in Beverden-street - I went by the name of Fouracres there; it is about twelve months ago that I washed for Willoughby; I then lived in Beverden-street - it might be nine months ago that I left there.

Q. Did Willoughby lose any of his linen? A. I will not answer these questions, it has nothing to do with this- if he thinks proper to come forward, I will answer him, but not strangers; he did not charge me with stealing his linen - I did not remove about his linen; I heard that he had lost some.

Q. Do you know that he got nothing back from you but pawnbroker's duplicates? A. I do not know any thing of the kind; I saw a great many duplicates - I saw Mr. Willoughby yesterday, and should think if he had any thing against me he would have stopped me; I do not know Phoebe Jones, or John Baker - the property in the trunk formerly belonged to
John Bedding
, and I was answerable for it; he left it in my care - he attended once before the Magistrate, and what he said was taken down; it was read over - I never saw his hand-writing; he did not tell the Magistrate he did not trust me with the property, nor that he did not believe what I said, nor that I had pawned Mr. Willoughby's linen.

ANN GATES. I am twelve years old, and live at No. 12, Willow-walk - Mrs. Fouracres lives two courts fromus; I saw the prisoner every day. On the 24th of August I was going for some ale for my mother's dinner - a little girl called me names, and I ran after her; she ran into her mother's privy - I went in, and found the prisoner there doing something to the top of the portmanteau; directly he saw me he sat down, and tucked his hand between his legs on the top of the portmanteau - I know nothing more; it was about two o'clock - I heard about four o'clock of Mrs. Fouracres loss, and told her what I had seen; the portmantean was taken into Mrs. Anderson's after it was found out - I saw it there; it had been cut at the top of the lid.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see Bedding before the Magistrate? A. Yes, once - he gave evidence; the prosecutrix went by the name of Jones, and when before the Magistrate she gave the name of Diana Fouracres Jones- she first gave her name as Jones, and then as Fouracres, because the Magistrate said she had no right to the name of Jones.

Q. How did he find out that her name was Fouracres? A. She told him so herself; he asked if she went by any other name - she has not told me how much a day I shall get for coming here, and I never heard; the prosecutrix knows
Phoebe James
, but she was never in her house - she lives at the bottom of a court, but not in the same court; there is no door to the privy - it has been taken away; it is down a little court, by the side of some houses - it can be seen from the back windows of one or two houses; I ran away directly I saw him there - there were no other people about, and when I returned, after getting the ale, there was another one standing at the prosecutor's gate; he lives right opposite the prosecutor - the prisoner was seen on the Thursday at the top of the court, and Mrs. Jones went for the Policeman, but he ran away; Bedding was here on Saturday - the Policeman says he has had 30s. to stop away; I never heard him tell the prosecutrix he did not believe the prisoner had taken the things - the portmanteau was locked, and Bedding gave the Policeman the key; Bedding stated what was lost before the Magistrate; Mrs. Hawkes lodges in the prosecutor's house- nobody else.

ELIZABETH FOURACRES
. I am ten years old, and live with my mother. I saw the portmanteau on my mother's drawers about two o'clock; I was at the top of the court and saw the prisoner bringing it up our court - I do not know where he took it too, I am certain it is the same portmanteau.

Cross-examined. Q.What day of the month was this? A. Three weeks ago last Wednesday, at about two o'clock; the privy is about two minute's walk from the court, I was standing talking to a young woman at the top of the court: she is sixteen years old, but she is not here - she did not stand as I did, and might not see; I said to her, "There goes John Bedding with a portmanteau" - he was bringing it away from my mother's, I do not know where he took it to; my mother washed for Mr. Willonghby when she lived in Beverden-street - I heard some of his linen was lost, but it was not taken out of my mother's place; I believe some of it was pawned.

Q. On your oath, did not your mother take it to the pawnbrokers? A. My mother got somebody to get it out of pawn; my mother went by the name of Fouracres there; we afterwards removed to where we live now.
COURT. Q. Did you ever see your mother in possession of Willoughby's linen? A. Once I did.

JOHN MORLEY
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on the 24th of August, I should think; but cannot exactly recollect the day; I found him in Willowgardens, and told him he was charged with stealing a portmanteau, cutting it open, and taking the top part of the contents out - I collared him; he said there was no occasion for that, he would go quietly; he said nothing, but went willingly - I found the portmanteau in Mrs. Fouracres' place: Bedding came to the first examination; he went to the office with the prisoner and me - he gave evidence, and was ordered to come the following day to have his deposition taken, but he absconded; I saw him here yesterday.

Cross-examined. Q.What do you mean by absconding? A. I went to his fathers, and he had not been home; I was sent for on the day of the robbery (Wednesday), I think I took him on the Thursday; it was in the same week, but I cannot say on what day - he lives in the same gardens: it was on the Wednesday when the portmanteau was stolen, and on the Thursday, I think I took him.

WILLIAM ROWLAND
. I am a Policeman. I heard of the portmanteau on the Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon; I was present when the prisoner was apprehended, it was on a Friday - there were two persons taken; we said they were wanted for cutting open a pormanteau - the prisoner said he knew nothing about it.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure he said he knew nothing about it? A. Yes; Morley was present; I do not know whether he heard it - we came into the gardens in a sort of triangular way, and there were five of them standing together - we took two; there had been three seen together, it was so given in evidence - I think the woman herself saw the parties together; the little girl said she saw them together about the same time - Morley and I might have been a yard and a half apart when he said he knew nothing about it; it was I collared him, and not Morley.

Q. That you swear? A. Morley came up to the two first, and he had hold of him; he gave him up to me, and it was while I had him, that he said he knew nothing about it; it is very likely Morley heard that.
MRS. FOURACRES. This is the portmanteau which was taken from my room.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to swear you do not know Phoebe James? A. I do not know her only by passing; I did not know her name - I swear I know nothing of the pawning of Willoughby's goods.
Prisoner Defence. I am innocent; when I heard of the charge I surrendered myself.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1856.
GEORGE LAWRANCE
and
HENRY BERRY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 lookingglass, value 10s. , the goods of
Richard Bond
.

RICHARD BOND. I keep a furniture warehouse in Seymour-street, Euston-square. On Tuesday, the 2nd of August, I was removing some goods under a distress-warrant, and about two o'clock I saw this looking-glass put into the body of a carriage which was in my van; I missed it between eight and nine o'clock at night - I saw Lawrance by the van when the glass was put in, and when I heard it was taken I came round the corner where the van stood,and saw Lawrance attempting to take some small things out of the van; I went up to him, and said, "My good man, what are you doing here?" he said, "Master, I am tying the ropes;" he was not employed by me, nor had any of my men asked him to do it - I told him to leave the ropes alone, and go about his business; the van at that time was waiting near my back premises in Drummond-street
; when I went down to arrange about unloading the goods three persons gave me information - the carman got into the van, and the glass was gone; they pointed out Lawrance, who was standing by - I told him I should not lose sight of him till I saw a Policeman; I then gave him in charge.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q.Whose goods were they? A. The person's name was Lawrance - the distress-warrant is not here.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Who was the carman? A. Henry Mince; I left him in possession of the goods - they were not taken more than a quarter of a mile from Drummond-street; the cart remained in the street from two till between eight and nine o'clock, in order to determine about them.

JAMES WOOD
. I am servant to Mr. Brand, a butcher. On the 2nd of August, between eight and nine o'clock at night, I was in Drummond-street, and saw both the prisoners; this van stood between the Royal George and Drummond-street - I saw Lawrance get on the van, and shift the looking-glass out of the body of the chariot, and put it by the side of the van; Berry was at the other side of the van, and could see what he was doing - they walked up and down, and in about ten minutes they went to the side of the van; Lawrance took the looking-glass off the van, and gave it to Berry, who put it under his coat, and went away with it - I went and told the carman; I then went to look for Berry, but he was out of sight - Lawrance stood by the van, and said he had only been shifting the ropes; I saw Mr. Bond in about five minutes, and told him what I had seen - Just before Lawrance said he had been shifting the ropes, he offered me and Lewis a penny between us to run into Wilstod-street, to touch the first coach in the rank, and bring him back the number, but we stood round the corner of Seymour-street, and watched - we came back, told him we had been, and there was no coach there; he walked up and down a little, then gave us a penny, and said,"Go away, because here is our master, and he don't like to see any boys here;" we then went round the corner, watched, and saw him give the glass to Berry.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q.How far were you from the van? A.Just across the road; the van was heavily laden-Berry was on the side nearest to us, and Lawrance on the other side; I could see it was a lookingglass, for it made a shadow against the gas-light - I had seen Berry before, but did not know him; he was close to us - I never said it was a picture; I went round the van, and saw what Lawrance did - we looked under the van; Berry came round, said he could not find it, and made some motion - we were round the corner when we saw Lawrance give it to Berry; they were both on one side then - the van was not between us and the prisoners.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Where do you come from? A. Charlotte-street, Somers'-town - I am out of employ; I lived with Mr. Grange, and was turned away - Lewis lives with his father, who keeps a horse and cart; Lawrance told us to go about our business, but we went round the corner when he said that - the carman was in the public-house, talking to Mr. Bond, when I told him.

WILLIAM LEWIS
. I am fourteen years old; I live in Drummond-square, with my parents - they kept a coalshed and green-grocer's formerly, but now keep a horse and cart; I was with Wood, about three o'clock - the goods were stolen about eight or nine, in Drummond-street - I saw Lawrance get on the van, and shift the glass out of the body of the carriage, to the side of the van; he then came down, and said he was only fastening the ropes- Berry was just at the side of him; Lawrence said,"Which of you will run fastest to Wilsted-street, and touch a coach?" he spoke to me, Wood, and another boy; we ran round the corner, and watched them - we came back, said we had touched a coach, and asked them for a penny, which he said he would give us; he said, "Go away a bit, and I will give it you directly, but our master is behind us;" he came up afterwards, gave us the penny, and said, "Now go away, I'll take care of the van;" we went round the van, saw him get into it, and give the glass to Berry, who went away with it - I told Bond and the carman of it directly; they were both together - I could see the glass glittering about, as the gas was lighted.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you directly said to the other boy, "Here is the looking-glass?" A. Yes: and he said "Let us go and tell Bond, and the man"- the carman had told us to mind the van, and feed the horses, and said he would give us 1d.; when Lawrance took the glass, and gave it to Berry, I was at the side of the van, about half a yard off - he got on the wheel, got the glass off, and gave it to Berry, who was just by, waiting to take it; we saw him go away with it - when I saw Lawrance first take the glass, I was on the pavement, near the van; I did not see Wood peep under the van-I have not talked to him about this: there might he twenty people about - I went and told Bond; I did not call out.
Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q.Perhaps there were twenty people looking on at the time? A. We were round the corner, watching them, and saw them take the glass; we saw the shadow of it.

ROBERT LEVEY
. I live in Little Drummond-street- the George public-house is in Great Drummond-street I am an engraver. On Tuesday, the 2nd of August, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I had occasion to wait at the George for a friend, who was talking to a person he had met; during that time Lawrance was holding the horse of a cart, containing ginger-beer - I saw him climb up behind the wheel of the van, put his hand into the the body of a chariot, and take something out, which I suppose was too heavy for him; he immediately put it down - he then got a looking-glass out of the chariot, and placed it by the side of the wheel; he then took it up, and put it on the other side of the van, within his reach - Berry came out of the public-house, looked me in the face, and went to the corner of Seymour-street; he then returned into the public-house; he came out in a very few minutes - I saw these two boys standing at the corner of Seymour-street; Berry passed me two or three times -he then went round the van, he could not find the glass, and said to Lawrance, "Where is it?" Lawrance said, "If you can't find it, I will;" he then went, reached it down from the van, and gave it into Berry's possession - Berry went off down Seymour-street with it; I immediately informed the carman - I saw Berry at three o'clock next day, and gave him into custody; he had a different coat on, but I knew his face.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How often had you seen him before? A. Never - I suspected them when I saw the glass move, which was about ten minutes before it was taken, but I did not know where to find the carman till he came out of the public-house; I went down the gateway, and found him and Bond, and told him - I cannot swear it was a looking-glass they took away - I have not said so.

ROBERT WOOLLEY
. I am a Policeman. I received Lawrance in custody, from Bond, and asked him what had become of the looking-glass; he said he knew nothing of it - next day, between three and four o'clock, I was with Levey, looking for Berry, and took him - I asked Levey if he was sure that was the man who took the glass; he said Yes, he was positive-Berry made no answer, but went quietly; he told me, in our way to the office, that he had been drinking at a public-house on Tuesday afternoon.
Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Did not Lawrance say he had the greatest difficulty to keep off a parcel of boys from the van? A. Not a word of the sort.
COURT. Q. Was the carman's name on the van? A. Yes.
Berry received a good coaracter.

BERRY -
GUILTY . Aged 28.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Months .

LAWRANCE -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1857.
ANN KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
Dennis Harley
.

CATHERINE HARLEY
. I am the wife of
Dennis Harley
, a shoemaker - we live at a cellar in Monmouth-street
. On the 6th of September. about five o'clock in the evening, the prisoner passed - I saw her stoop, take these shoes up, and go away; I followed, and asked her for them - the woman said she had given them to another woman, who ran away with them; I have not found them - I had seen her myself give them to another woman.

ANN TOOLEY
. I live in Monmouth-street. I saw the prisoner stoop down, take these shoes, and run across the street, with them under her arm - another woman came up, took them out of her hand, and ran away.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined One Month .

1858.
THOMAS KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 1 frock, value 1s. 6d.; 1 waistcoat, value 3d.; 1 jacket, value 3d.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 1s.; 5 yards of plaid, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., and 1 hair front, value 3d. , the goods of
William Cottrell
.

WILLIAM COTTRELL. I am a news-vender , and live in Martin-street, City-road
, in the back parlour. On the 25th of August I saw the prisoner, (who was a stranger.) in the passage, with these things loose under his arm - he dropped the handkerchief; I followed, and asked him what he had there - he said he did not know, and let them fall; they had hung over a chair in my room - the door was not locked.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Where were you? A. I had gone down in the kitchen for about two minutes, and as I came up I saw him - I had left the door open - there was hardly time for him to take them.

CHARLES WALLER
. I am a Policeman. I was called in, and took the prisoner; the things laid at his feet - he said great distress made him do it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received and excellent character.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1859.
WILLIAM KEASLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 coat, value 20s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 12s.; 1 waistcoat, value 4s., and 1 pair of shoes, value 4s. , the goods of
John Hunt
.

JOHN HUNT. I live in White Hart-yard, Drury-lane, and bawk provisions about. On the 5th of September, about half-past four o'clock in the afternoon, I left my house - I had been with some friends, and got tipsy; coming home my wife began to blow me up, and I ran away from her - I do not know where I went, and I found myself in Falcon-court, Fleet-street, about half-past five in the morning - I was stripped naked, all but my stockings and shirt; I lost 7s. 9d. in money.

RICHARD BRODRICK
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner into custody about twenty minutes to two o'clock in the morning, in Vere-street, Clare-market, with a bundle under his arm - I asked what he had; he said a pair of trousers and shoes, which I found in the bundle; he had got the coat on his back, and the waistcoat in his own coat pocket - he did not say how he came by it; the prosecutor saw the clothes when he was sober, and identified them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the man before - I was returning from Greenwich, and saw these things by the Olympic Theatre.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Two Months .

1860.
HARRIET JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 shawl, value 4s. , the goods of
John Griffiths
.

THOMAS PEWTNER
. I am servant of
John Griffiths
, a pawnbroker , of Ossulton-street, Somers'-town
. This shawl hung on a line close by the counter - I saw it safe about three o'clock, and missed it between five and six; the prisoner was then in the shop - I went round the counter, and charged her with it; Lloyd, the officer, who was in the next shop, came in, and took her - she denied it; it was not found about her then - there was another woman with her.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner in charge; a female in the house searched her, but did not find the shawl; I took her to Hatton-garden - she was remanded, and the gaoler took her to the lock-up place; she denied it strongly - she and the other woman were searched; the other was examined on a separate charge.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
I am an officer. I took the prisoner to the lock-up place; a girl ran into the yard,and hallooed out "Harriet, what have you gat?" she said,"Remanded, but come in, I want to speak to you;" I let her go into the yard - the prisoner immediately put her hand up her clothes, pulled a shawl out, and gave it to the girl, who put it up her own clothes, but I took it from her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met two young girls, who asked me to go and pawn a pair of shoes; the shawl was missed, but I was searched, and had not got it.

GUILTY . - Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1861.
JOHN JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Garnish
, from the person of
Sarah Garnish
.

MARY GARNISH
. I am the wife of
Thomas Garnishwe
live in West-street, Soho; he is a painter and glazier . My daughter, Sarah, is only three years old; she was taken out by Mary Ball, with a coral necklace on, about half-past eleven o'clock - she was brought home about one without it; we found it at Bow-street - the prisoner is a stranger.

MARY ANN BALL
. I am ten years old. On the 17th of July I took out the prosecutrix's child; it had hold of my hand, and just before we came to Denmark-street
, the prisoner came and took the necklace off; I cried Stop thief! and ran up the street - he turned towards Churchpassage, and then the Policeman took him; I lost sight of him for about a minute, while he turned the corner, but am sure of his person - there were two others with him, who ran another away.

THOMAS CANNON
. I am a Policeman, I heard a cry of Stop thief! and saw Ball pursue the prisoner up Denmark-street; I kept him in sight - he turned round Lloyd's-court, and there I saw him throw something into an area; I ran, and secured him - Lish stopped to pick up what was in the area; the necklace was produced, and Bill claimed it.

CHARLES LISH
. I am a Policeman. I heard the girl cry Stop thief! and saw the prisoner throw the necklace down the area; I got it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was in Crown-street, and saw three children walking together - two young men passed them at the same time as I; there was a cry of Stop thief! a young man ran by me; I ran after him the same as the rest.

THOMAS CANNON
. There was nobody between the girl and the prisoner.
CHARLES LISH. Nobody else was running in that direction.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Life .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1862.
WILLIAM JAMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 2 pairs of shoes, value 18s. , the goods of
William Marsh
.

JOHN BOTSFORD
. I am master of the Infant-school, Baldwin's-gardens
. On the 13th of August I saw the prisoner coming from Mr. Marsh's house opposite, with something under his apron; I informed Mr. Marsh, who I had seen go into a neighbour's house a minute before.

WILLIAM MARSH
. I keep a shoemaker's shop, in Baldwin's-gardens. Eastford gave me information; I saw the prisoner about twenty yards off - he dropped something, and when I came up he said, "There are your shoes, I hope you will not prosecute me;" I took them up, and took him to the office.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am an officer. I asked the prisoner why he took the shoes; he said it was wholly through distress.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1863.
ELIZA JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 watch, value 20s., the goods of
Robert Snell
, from his person .

ROBERT SNELL. I live in Red Lion-street, Holborn. On the 18th of August, about one o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner about Holborn-bars
; she followed me from there to the end of Bedford-row
, and immediately after she left me, I missed my watch - she had been talking to me, but I went no where with her; I am certain she is the woman - I had spent the evening with a relation in the City.

ROBERT WOOD. I am an officer of St. Martin, Lndgate.
