On the 18th of August, about three o'clock in the morning, the prisoner was brought into my custody on another charge, and the watch was found on her; I asked who it belonged to; she said herself; that she had had it about three years and a-half, and it had belonged to her brother, who was dead.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put it in a written Defence, stating that a young man who had gone with her into a stable, had left his watch with her till the morning.

ROBERT SNELL
. Upon my oath, I went to no stable with her, nor did I give her the watch for any purpose.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Life .

1864.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 sovereign, 9 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Willson
, from his person .

JOHN WILLSON. I am a hair-dresser , and live at South Ockenden, Essex. On the 29th of August I came from Purfleet, in a steam-boat; the prisoner was on board with another man and woman - after we landed we went to the Black Horse, near Tower-Hill
; the prisoner proposed to play a game; thimbles were placed on the table; I changed half a sovereign there - I then had a sovereign and 9s. 6d.; I left the room to go into the yard, and as I came back, I met the prisoner and the other man - the other man seized my throat - the prisoner put his hand into my waistcoat pocket, and the other hand in my trousers pocket, and they took from me all my money and a key; two soldiers came in, and the prisoner was secured - the other man ran away; I missed the sovereign from my waistcoat pocket, and the 9s. 6d. from my trousers.

Prisoner. Q. Do you remember ringing the bell for the waiter asking him to fetch a constable, and charging me with stealing half a sovereign? A. After taking a pint of ale, I was dozing, and found the prisoner about my person, but not, at the moment, recollecting changing the half-sovereign, I said he had taken it - they talked of sending for a constable, not me.

WILLIAM BARLOW
. I am a private in the ColdstreamGuards. I was at the Black Horse, and saw Willson come through the tap-room - the prisoner and another followed him - I saw the prisoner meet Willson coming in at the door, the other man got in the rear, but he was in front of him; I saw him put his hand into his trousers pocket - I saw some silver in the prisoner's hand; he dropped it into his own pocket, as he went through the taproom, and said it was all right; they both went through the tap-room into the street - the prosecutor called out that he was robbed; I ran after the prisoner - both ran up the street as hard as they could - the prisoner finding me gain on him, made a kind of a halt; I collared him, and I gave him in charge.

WILLIAM BALL
. I belong to the Guards. I saw the prosecutor come from the tap-room, and go into the back yard - the prosecutor and another man came through the tap-room, and said, "Come, friend, let us have another pot;" he said, "No, I'll not be in your company any longer;" the other man threw 6d. on the table, and said,"Never mind, I'll pay for a pot, I don't want you to pay at all; Willson wanted to go, but the prisoner caught him round the waist, and the other put his hand into his pocket - I afterwards followed them out, and saw them secured.
Prisoner. Q. Had the other man hold of him while I was robbing him? A. Yes.

GEORGE WILLIAM MORGAN
. I received the prisoner in charge; I found one half-sovereign in his waistcoat pocket, and 2s. 6d. and a key in his trousers pocket - the prosecutor claimed the key as belonging to a padlock.
JOHN WILLSON. That is my key.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor called for a glass of ale; I stopped there till he charged me with robbing him - he sent the waiter for a constable, then called him back again, and said the money was all right - he was intoxicated; I went after him to put my hat on, and sat him on the seat - as I went out, I heard somebody call Stop thief! and turned round.

GUILTY . Aged 35 -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1865.
SARAH JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Philip Hitchings
, from his person .

PHILIP HITCHINGS. On Saturday night, between ten and eleven o'clock, I lost a silk handkerchief in Newportmarket
, and found it at Bow-street; I knew nothing of the prisoner till I found her at the office.

JOHN GROOM
. I live in Chapel-street, Long-acre. On the 9th of July, between ten and eleven o'clock at night, I was in Newport-market, and saw the prisoner attempt a number of pockets; the prosecutor and his wife were looking at a butter-shop - she put her hand into his pocket, and took out a silk handkerchief; I went up and asked his address; when I had secured her I lost him - I afterwards got him to attend at the office; I am positive I saw the prisoner take the silk handkerchief from his pocket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I picked it up.

GUILTY . Aged 66. -
Confined Eighteen Months .

1866.
BENJAMIN HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 watch, value 3s. , the goods
William Lee
.

ROBERT HACKETT
. I am a chimney-sweeper, and live at Newport-Pagnell - the prisoner was in my service. On the 18th of August, William Lee, who is under-butler to Mr. Hoare, gave me a silver watch to take to Newport-Pagnell, to get repaired; I did so - I gave it to the prisoner to take it to Mr. Cole's, the watchmaker - he afterwards came and asked me to lend him 6d. to get his shoes repaired - I lent him 2s. 6d., and saw no more of him till the 28th of August, when he was brought to me at Newport-Pagnell; I believe he had been looking for me - I asked him where the watch was; he said he had pawned it at Mr. Griffiths', Somer's-town, that Rye had the duplicate, and he would show me where it was - I came to town with him; he went to Rye in Bridgewater-street, Somers'-town, and got the duplicate.

JOHN RYE
. I am superintendent of the paupers at St. Pancras. I have know the prisoner two years; he came to me on or about the 22nd of August, and offered me the duplicate, and I gave him 1s. for it.

THOMAS PEWTNER
. I am shopman to Mr. Griffiths. I have a silver watch, pawned on the 20th of August, by a man, in the name of Bourne, it was not the prisoner; I delivered the duplicate produced to the person who pawned it.

JOSEPH BARRETT
. I am a serjeant of Police. On the 31st of August the prisoner was brought to the watchhouse; he said his master sent him to the watchmaker's with the watch, and that he afterwards obtained it from the watchmaker, and hired a man to pawn it at Griffiths'.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor was drinking at a public-house at Newport-Pagnell, and, pulling out the watch, said he would not sell it for seven guineas - and then said, "I shall make my servant a present of it," and he gave it me - I did not much like the place - I came to town, and pawned it; I returned into the country, and heard there was a reward offered for me - I then told him where the watch was pawned.

ROBERT HACKETT
. I never gave it to him, and was not intoxicated at all - Lee would lose his place if he came here - he lives in the country.
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1867.
WILLIAM HART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 reticule, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 purse, value 1s.; 4 half-crowns, and 8 shillings, the property of
Jane Anne Greenshields
, from her person .

RICHARD HAWKES
. I am a Policeman. On the 8th of September I was on duty at Charing-cross
, and saw the prisoner in company with three others; I saw the prosecutrix pass - the prisoner turned back after her; I saw him draw a knife from his pocket, open it, and put it before her - he then turned round towards me, and I collared him, with this reticule in his hand; the lady turned round, and he dropped it - it contained 18s., a purse, and a handkerchief.

JANE ANNE GREENSHIELDS
. I live in Berwick-street, Soho. On the 8th of September I was at Charing-cross, and lost my reticule - and on turning round, I saw it in the Policeman's hands; I felt it go from my arm, but did not see the prisoner.

Prisoner' Defence. I was passing through Charingcross, and there was a bar, which caused me to stop - I saw something shine on the ground, and went on five or ten yards; I then turned back, stooped down behind this lady, and the witness caught hold of me; he said,"Are you a Jew?" I said, "Why do you ask that?" he said, "Because I want to be revenged on a Jew - a Jew has done me some injury, and you are just the man I want."

RICHARD HAWKES
. I said no such thing - there was an attempt at rescue; two gentlemen came up, or he would have got away.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Life .

1868.
THOMAS HOLLINGBURY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 handkerchief, value, 4s., and 1 snuff-box, value 2s., the goods of
George Fitch
, from his person .

GEORGE FITCH
. I live in Piccadilly. On the 8th of September, in the afternoon, I was in Parliament-street
, and was spoken to by Sheppard, a Policeman - I missed from my coat pocket my handkerchief and snuff-box; my pocket was cut.

WILLIAM SHEPPARD
. Between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, of the 8th of September, I was in Parliament-street; there was a crowd collected at the Coronation - I saw the prisoner feel the pockets of several gentleman; I then saw him go to Mr. Fitch - he seemed very busy with his hands for about five minutes; I then put my hand on his shoulder, and his hand came from the prosecutor's pocket - I asked Mr. Fitch if he had lost any thing; he said he had; I found the snuff-box in the prisoner's trousers pocket, and the handkerchief dropped behind him.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not see me pick it up and put it into my pocket? I said, "If there has been a robbery the man has gone along;" directly he moved I saw the box on the ground - you said, "Have you got any thing?" and I gave it you from my pocket; I knew nothing of the handkerchief. Witness. I saw his hand very busy about Fitch's pocket; he never stooped, and could not have picked it up - he was exactly behind Fitch.

JURY to
GEORGE FITCH
. Q.Did the prisoner give up the box, or did the officer take it from his pocket? A. The officer took it from his pocket.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1869.
ELIZA GILHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 medal, value 1/2d., and 19s., the property of
James Shilton
, from his person .

JAMES SHILTON
. I belong to a brig, which laid in Bellwharf tier. On the 30th of August I was at the Paviors' Arms public-house. I changed a sovereign, and laid out 9d.; I then had 19s. 3d., which I put into my pocket, with a medal of the late Duke of York - I saw the prisoner at the house, and gave her something to drink; I had a bad bowel complaint, and asked her to show me a bed - she took me to a house, and I laid down with my waistcoat on; I vomited, and then went to sleep - I awoke about half-past three o'clock, and found my pockets entirely emptied; I was alone in the room - I went and described her at the Police-office.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. How much did you have at the house? A. A pint of beer, and half a pint of gin; I did not drink it all - I did not notice how many girls were there; I treated nobody but the prisoner - I merely went to out of the room - I did not send her out for gin, nor give her any money at all.

PATRICK DUFFY
. I am a Policeman. On the evening of the 31st of August, I found Shilton at the door of a noted brothel, in Isaacs-buldings, Bluegate-fields
; in consequence of what he told me I apprehanded the prisoner, about five o'clock in the morning, at a coffee-shop; she asked me if the man had got up from the bed - I said Yes, and asked her for his money; she said she had none belonging to him; I searched her, and found 8s. and the Duke of York's medal on her - I took her to the house, and directly Shilton saw her identified her; she then said, all the money he had was 5s. 9d., and she could not have robbed him of 19s. - that he gave her the medal and 5s. 9d.
Cross-examined. Q.Was he not very much intoxicated? A. Not at all; the first thing the prisoner said to me was," Is the man got out of bed."
(Medal produced and sworn to.)

Priosner's Defence. What he says is false; if he changed a sovereign it was before I was in his company- when I went in he sat there drinking; he asked me and ten other females to drink - he then asked me to show him a bed, which he gave 1s. 6d. for; he gave me 5s. 9d.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1870.
THOMAS GATES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 2 skates, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Mosely
.

THOMAS BOYCE. I am a constable of Hampsted district. On the evening of the 6th of August I saw the prisoner in company with another boy go into Mosely's shop- the other boy took down a cage, which had white mice in it, and the prisoner took down a pair of skates - I pursued him, and took him to the watch-house; I found the skates on him.
Prisoner. The prosecutor took the value of the property, and here is the paper he signed for it.

THOMAS MOSELY
. I have not been paid for them - I know nothing of this paper, and never saw it before; I did not sign this paper - I know nobody who lives in Tothill-street; as far as I am concerned this paper is a forgery altogether; the prisoner's friends came and offered me money to keep from here, but I refused it.

JOSEPH GATES
. I am the prisoner's brother.
Thomas Mosely
signed that paper, and took 2s. from me, being the full value of the property; he told me if I would give him 5s. to pay his expences to save him coming here, he would accept of it - he took 2s., and we spent 3s. in drink; I, him, and another friend.
THOMAS MOSELY. I never drank with this man in my life, or spent 3s. in his compary, nor received 2s. from him.

JOSEPH GATES
. My friends are all gone home, or I could bring them up - they saw us drinking together,down by the Sessions'-house, I do not know the sign -Mr. Lewis, the prosecutor, and Mr. and Mrs. Mason were there.

FREDERICK HAYES
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Chapel-street, Somers'-town. The prosecutor told me he had taken 2s. of this man - I did not write this paper; I saw it at the Northampton Arms, Pentonville - the prosecutor was there, drinking with Mr. Meares and two young men; Meares in a bird fancier, at Pentonville - I saw the paper in Lewis' hands; Lewis wrote the body of it, and Mosely put his name to it, but not in my presence.

Q. Look at this paper, is not the whole of it in one handwriting? A. I should not think the name was written by the same person - I was not present when it was written at all; the prosecutor told me he had received the 2s., and did not want to hurt the man.

JOSEPH GATES
. We were drinking at the Northampton Arms, as well as at Clerkenwell - we met at the Sessions'-house, and drank; we finished at the Northampton Arms.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1871.
JANE GLOVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 watch, value 3l., and 1 seal, value 2l., the goods of
John Clagg Kay
, from his person .

JOHN CLAGG KAY. I live in Gower-place, Eustonsquare, and am a medical-student . On the night of the 7th of September, I met the prisoner in company with another woman in the Strand, they went with me to a public-house and had something to drink; soon after I left the house and missed my watch - I was not aware that the prisoner had followed me out; when I missed it I charged her with stealing it - she ran away from me; I saw her throw the watch down in the street - I picked it up, and afterwards stopped her in a street which she turned down, and kept her till the Policeman took her.

Cross-examined by MR. SMITH. Q. What time did you first meet her? A. Between eleven and twelve o'clock -I called in Soho-square; I had been to Westminster Abbey; it was between three and four, that I was in Soho-square, I drank a pint of ale there; I did not dine at all - I had a pint of ale near the Abbey; I stopped several hours at Soho-square, playing at bagatelle - I was not at all inclined to be intoxicated before I went into the publichouse with her; I had two or three pots of ale there; I was not tipsy when I came out, but I was inclining that way; there were two coal-heavers in the house, and they took part of the ale with me - I was talking to them and the girls.

Q.Is it likely you would have stopped in such company, if you had not been drunk? A. Very likely; it is just according to the humour I am in - I frequently associate with coal-heavers and women of the town, scores of times - she threw the watch down the moment I charged her with it; I was able to run - I did not fall till I ran against a stone.
COURT. Q.Where are you a student of medicine? A. At the London University; I have been often at publichouses with women of the town and coal-heavers.

JOHN BURKETT
. I am a Police-constable. On the 8th of September, about twelve or one o'clock at night, Mr. Kay gave the prisoner into my charge near the Adelphi - he produced a watch, which he charged her with having stolen - she denied it; the watch-glass was broken - the prosecutor was not in liquor, he knew what he was about; he might be getting a little hearty.
Cross-examined. Q.When do you call a man drunk? A. When he reels about and cannot walk straight.
NOT GUILTY .

1872.
MICHAEL GRADEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 2 handkerchiefs, value 7s., and two 5l. Bank notes , the property of
David Noon
.

DAVID NOON
. I belong to the 7th regiment of Foot Guards . On the 30th of July I was quartered at the Castle, Bull's Head-court, Strand
, and enlisted the prisoner by the name of Dennis Doyle, to serve in the 89th regiment; he slept in the same room with me that night - two young men, companions of his, had also enlisted; I had two 5l. Bank notes in my box; I awoke about six o'clock in the morning, and missed the prisoner - I went to my box, and missed the notes and two silk handkerchiefs; I afterwards found him in custody; the other two did not sleep there - nobody came into the room from the time I went to bed till I missed my notes.

THOMAS WORTHING
. I am a watchman, and live in Lumley-court, Strand. I was at the Castle on Saturday night, the 30th of July, and saw the prosecutor enlist the prisoner; I was the prisoner about five o'clock next morning, at the top of Bull's Head-court - the joined three other persons, and went away along Maiden-lane.
Prisoner. Q. I never saw that man in my life? Witness. I am sure he is the man.

MARY ANN BLUNDELL
. I saw the prisoner at the Castle on the 30th of July and recollect Noon being there; the prisoner slept that night with Noon - I am certain he is the man; my husband keeps the Castle - there was no other spare bed.

BARTHOLOMEW STEYNING
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner at the Vine, public-house, Tooley-street, Borough; he denied the charge.

Prisoner's Defence. I never was in the house that night - the gentleman went up to a woman, and offered her a sovereign to come down and prove that I changed one of the notes in Seven-dials; her name is Ann Coutts.

DAVID NOON
. I gave him nothing but 1s. when he enlisted; he was to receive 7s. 6d. of the bounty when he passed, 2s. 6d. before the Magistrate, and 50s. when he joined the regiment - the girl he names is the person he keeps; the serjeant offered her a sovereign to find out where he had ben spending the money.
Prisoner. He told the Magistrate he was intoxicated.

DAVID NOON. I did not state so; there were people in the tap-room, but I came out of the tap-room - the prisoner wrote his name and direction on paper; he took that with the money - a man has four clear days after her enlists, but he must pay 21s. to get off.

GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 19.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1873.
ROBERT SCOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 watch, value 50s., and 1 gold key, value 2s. , the goods of
Andrew Phillips
; to which he pleaded GUILTY. -
Judgment Respited
.

1874.
JOHN BEDDUS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 tray, value 4s.; 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 sovereign, and 3s. 6d. in copper , the property of
William Newton
, his master; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY . -
Confined Six Months .

1875.
GEORGE BARHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 2 bottles, value 6d.; 1 quart of brandy, value 3s.; 1 quart of wine, value 3s., and 60 penny-pieces , the property of
Henry Brett
, his master.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

HENRY BRETT
. I am a wine and brandy-merchant , and live in Drury-lane - the prisoner was my cellarman . On the evening of the 24th of August, in consequence of a communication from Kirby, I went in pursuit of the prisoner, and caught him in Whitechapel-road; a 5s. paper of copper was found on him, which I can speak to - it was tied in part of a newspaper, and I had the other parts of the same paper, which exactly corresponded, and which likewise contained penny-pieces; it was part of the Morning Advertiser, of the 4th of August.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q.When had he left your house? A.About half-past eleven o'clock at night.

ANN KIRBY
. I am the niece of the prosecutor, and live in his house. On the evening of the 24th of August, we had seven 5s. papers of copper in his bed-room, tied up in newspapers - I went into the room, and saw them all safe at nine o'clock; my uncle was then at home - he went out just afterwards, and the prisoner left about half-past eleven; he had no business in that room, but could get there- as soon as he was gone I went into the room, and missed one paper; my uncle came home soon afterwards, and I informed him - he went after the prisoner; I have since seen the paper of copper found on him - it is in the same paper, tied in the same way, and to the best of my belief, is the paper which was missing.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you placed it in the bedroom? A. No.

WILLIAM WHITAKER
. I live in Drury-lane. I produce a perfect copy of the Morning Advertiser, of the 4th of August; I have examined these parts - they exactly match, and they are all of the paper of the 4th of August.

JOHN PERKINS
. I am a Policeman. I went in pursuit of the prisoner with the prosecutor, we overtook him in Whitechapel-road, and found on him a 5s. paper of copper, tied up in this newspaper - the paper broke, but I have preserved it, and produce it; I went to the prisoner's lodging, No. 20, Alfred-street, White Horse-lane, Stepney, and found there, a bottle of wine, a bottle of brandy, and some other bottles, with Mr. Brett's seal on them - before we went befor the Magistrate, I said to the prisoner, "Mr. Brett has lost several papers of coppers;" he said he had never meddled with any before, and he did not know what induced him to do it then, except that he had been drinking.

MR. BARRY to MR. BRETT. Q. Had you not given or sold spirits and wine to the prisoner? A. I certainly had both given and sold him some about Christmas, in consequence of his wife being confined, but I am quite confident I never gave him this brandy.
COURT. Q. How long had he been with you? A.About two years; I always considered him a very good character.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Three Months .

1876.
THOMAS GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 jacket, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Frenchum
.

THOMAS FRENCHUM. I am a labourer , and live at Ponder's-end, near Enfield, Middlesex. I was cutting wheat in a field on the 2nd of August, and saw the prisoner there, in company with some other men - my jacket was in the field, and a knife was in the pocket; I missed it.

JAMES KING. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Edmonton. This jacket was pawned with me on the 2nd of August, about twelve o'clock, by the prisoner, in the name of
Joseph Moore
, of Hoddesdon.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Three Months .

1877.
JOSEPH ATKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 saw, value 3s. , the goods of
Robert Darley
.

ROBERT DARLEY. I am a carpenter , and live at Hoxton. I left a saw on my work-bench, in Salisbury-street
, on Saturday the 20th of August, and when I returned at two o'clock it was gone.

WILLIAM EGLINTON
. I saw the prisoner at my house on the 20th of August, where Darley has a work-shop - the prisoner asked me if I had any work for him; this was about a quarter after one o'clock.

ROBERT PIERCEY
. I am in the employ of a pawnbroker, in Tabernacle-row. I have a saw, pawned by the prisoner, about two o'clock on the 20th of August.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went in, and said I had no money - Eglinton told me to go and pawn this saw, which I did - I was waiting for him, and saw the prosecutor, who accused me of stealing the saw; I denied it - he said I had better own to it, and he would forgive me; I then gave him the duplicate, and he gave charge of me.

THOMAS DORLEY
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner - he owned pawning the saw.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

1878.
SAMUEL AUSTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 pewter-pot, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Michael Erwin
.

The prosecutor's name being
Thomas Michael Erwin
, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1879.
THOMAS DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 7s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 3s., and 2 waistcoats, value 4s. , the goods of
Henry Hart Hart
.

HENRY HART HART. I keep a sale-shop in Monmouth-street. The prisoner lodged in my house - I was at Mr. Goodman's. in Holywell-street, on the 6th of July, and saw a coat there, which I recognized as mine.

ABRAHAM GOODMAN
. I keep a shop in Holywell-street. The prisoner sold me this coat on the 6th of July, for 10s. 6d., and told me his brother had bought it in Monmouth-street - that it was much too large for him - that he went to exchange it, and they wanted so much more money he would not give it; he gave his address, "
John Newman
. Wardour-street.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did he not give you that as his brother's address? A. Yes; he did not state that he was going to France.
HENRY HART HART. I had the prisoner taken - he said he knew nothing about it; the officer searched him, and found the duplicates - he then said he did it from distress, and hoped I would forgive him.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am an officer. I found these four duplicates on the prisoner - I heard him state what Mr. Hart has mentioned.

GEORGE KING
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of trousers and two waistcoats - the trousers and one waistcoat were pawned by a man, and one waistcoat, for 1s. 6d. was pawned by a woman; the duplicates the officer found were given for them.
MR. HART. I know these things are all mine.

Cross-examined. Q. Are they not what you deal in? A. Yes; Coben serves in my shop - I have another shop about twenty houses off, where
Moses Solomon
serves- they keep to their own shops; the prisoner said he knew nothing about Mr. Goodman, or the coat - I am sure he did not say he knew nothing about the purchase of it.

HENRY COHEN
. I am shopman to Mr. Hart. and reside at the house at which the prisoner lodges. This coat was in the shop, and had not been sold.

Cross-examined. Q.It might not have been sold by you, but whether Solomon had been there, and sold it, you cannot tell? A. I had it in my hand the day before the prisoner was taken; this has a private-mark on the collar.

BENJAMIN TIMMS
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce a pair of breeches, but do not know who pawned them - this is the duplicate I gave.

Prisoner's Defence. My brother was going to France; I recommended him to a shop, where he bought several articles, but as he had more luggage than he could carry he gave me the coat to sell - he said he had been to where he bought it, and they would not allow him any thing like the money he gave; it had been bought four weeks previous to my being taken.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Six Months .

1880.
JOHN MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on 10th of September , 4 sheets, value 10s. , the goods of
Richard James
.

RICHARD JAMES. I keep the Coach and Horses publichouse, at Tottenham
. The prisoner and another man came there on the night of the 9th of September, and slept at the house.

ELIZABETH GREEN
. I am servant to the prosecutor. - I saw the prisoner coming down with a bundle, and while I went to tell my master, this bundle was thrown on the stairs, but I do not know whether it was by the prisoner or the other man.
NOT GUILTY .

1881.
MARY GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 pair of tongs, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Lewis
.

THOMAS LEWIS
. I keep the Nag's Head, in Whitechapel
. On the 5th of August, between twelve and one o'clock, I was called into the lobby, and saw the prisoner with something under her clothes - I sent for the officer - it proved to be this pair of tongs.

WILLIAM GARRETT
. I am an officer. I found these tongs under the prisoner;s clothes - she said she was in distress, and appeared to be so.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1882.
ROBERT HILLYER
,
JOSEPH BRACE
, and
EMANUEL BRACE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 4 bushels of flour, value 2l. , the goods of
Joseph Johnson
.

The prosecutor not being able to identify the flour, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

1883.
JAMES HALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 24 yards of printed cotton, value 20s., and 4 pairs of stockings, value 6s. , the goods of
Henry Trendall
, his master.

JAMES PEACOCK
. I live in Shoredith, and am a headborough - the prisoner was servant to Mr. Trendall. On the 23rd of July I met the prisoner in Shoreditch; he gave me this parcel - it is directed "Mr. Hall, passenger to Reading, Sunday, July 24;" I had some suspicion, and gave information to the prosecutor.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Were you employed by the prosecutor to carry parcels? A. Yes, occasionally; I was not intimate with the prisoner - I made a box for him, for which he pair me, and he lent me 2s. about a month ago, since I had this parcel from him; the prosecutor had not forbidden me to come to his house -I have carried parcels for him for years.

HENRY TRENDALL
. I am a linen-draper , in Shoreditch; the prisoner was in my service rather more than twelve months. On the 22nd of July, I took in a letter by the Twopenny-post, and handed it to him; he read it, and said he must go out of town, on account of the illness of his sister - I think he said to Reading, in Berkshire. On the day following, I went to Peacock's house - this parcel was there - I opened it, and these articles were in it; I can swear to the print, from its matching, where it is cut, with the piece left; the prisoner has taken goods, and charged himself with them, but I had told him not to do so.

Cross-examined. Q.But he has charged himself with goods? A. Yes, he had done it more than once; I have employed Peacock as a porter, and about the shop, but he had not so much access to it as the prisoner -I had told the prisoner not to encourage Peacock there, on account of an opposite gin-shop - the prisoner remained in my house an hour of two after I discovered these goods.

WILLIAM COX
. I took the prisoner on the 2nd of August; he cried, and said he was very sorry he should be guilty of robbing his master, and begged his master to forgive him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he would have paid him for them? A. No.

Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Trendall allowed me to have goods, and post them to myself; he never to me expressed any disapprobation of my conduct - I could not agree with Mrs. Trendall, and she used to make differences between my master and me; when we were called up to sacred devotion, she desired the servant to put pins in the sofa, to injure my person; and, on another occasion, to get cowage for the same purpose; my master found this out, and went up to speak to my mistress about it - knowing she was my enemy, I ran out of the place; I afterwards surrendered, and when I returned to my master, he said to me, "James, if I don't prosecute you, how can you get your living?" I said, I had an uncle who would take me; he then consulted his wife, and I was taken.

MR. TRENDALL. I did consult my wife, undoubtedly; I never heard of pins being put in the sofa, or of the cowage, nor do I think it likely my wife would have desired it to have been done. My wife had gone to Margate, and on her return, the prisoner spoke in a very improper manner to her, and from that time, I believe, she had a sort of prejudice against him - I had no suspicion of him before this.

Cross-examined. Q. Had he any opportunity of posting these things in the book? A. Yes; after I had received the information, I went up stairs, and was there for ten minutes, and he might have booked these articles; I owe him his quarter's salary, 7l. 10s.

COURT. Q. Had you gone up stairs to speak to Mrs. Trendall just before he went away? A. Yes, on account of the information I had received; he could only imagine that I was speaking about this information.

WILLIAM COX
re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner give himself up to you? A. I was waiting - he went and spoke to Peacock - I said, "Is not your name Hall?" and he said Yes.

JAMES PEACOCK
. He said he would give himself up, and his mind would be easy.
Prisoner. Q.Since I have been confined here, did not my prosecutor send me 20s., and did not you keep 2s. of them? A. I borrrowed 2s. as a loan.
COURT. Q. How came you to take the 2s.? A. He gave them into my hand, and said, "If there were 10s. you should have it."
Prisoner. Q. You gave me 18s., and a piece of paper, stating that you had borrowed 2s.? A. No, I put the whole 20s. into your hand, and said, "If you can lend me 2s., I will thank you," and you did.
NOT GUILTY .

1884.
JAMES GEORGE KING
and
JOSEPH KING
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of May , 1 beer-machine, value 16l.; 3 tables, value 3l.; 1 stove, value 5l.; 8 chairs, value 1l.; 2 fenders, value 10s.; 5 jugs, value 3s.; 1 saucepan, value 2s.; 4 brushes, value 1s.; 2 spitoons, value 1s.; 2 buckets, value 4s.; 4 yards of oil-cloth, value 4s.; 10 china plates, value 2s.; 5 dishes, value 5d., and 1 set of fire-irons, value 2s. , the goods of
Benjamin Watkins
.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

BENJAMIN WATKINS. I kept a beer-shop at Deptford. About Christmas last I became acquainted with
James George King
, who was then a Policeman, and used my house - I had a sick brother from Wales; he died at my house - J. G. King had asked if I knew of a small house at Deptford, as his wife was ill in town, and he wished to bring her there; I was going to Wales, and took a house in King-street to put my furniture in, and gave J. G. King the use of two rooms, to look after my furniture and take care of my wife - I locked my property up in other rooms; I then went to Wales; I gave Goodman King(not the prisoners) the key of my apartment; I returned about the end of February or March, but, being ill, did not go to Deptford for three weeks - I saw J. G. King before the Magistrate; he was not then in the Police -I found my house in King-street in possession of a stranger, and all my property gone; I asked J. G. King, before the Magistrate, what had become of my property; he said he knew nothing of it, but that his brother was at Royston - in August I went to a house in Ironmonger-row, and found J. G. King there, and in the back-parlour a piece of oil-cloth and some crockery of mine - I gave him in charge; I found my beer-machine in May last at Phillips' in Chiswell-street, and found my property at different places.

J. G. King. Q. Did not you place the whole of your affairs in the hands of Goodman King? A. And your's also - he did not have the pumps of the engine - I sold him goods to the amount of 9l. 13s., to provide my wife with things during my absence: it was for none of these things he was to advance that, but she never had a farthing - I did not let the house to Goodman King - I gave him the key; you were to move on the night I went to Wales, (looking at a letter) this is my writing - I only sent for 5l., and never received a farthing.

The letter being read, among other things, stated-DEAR SIR, - I am without a penny; I have sold my umbrella to get a bed and some bread; I have only had sixpenny worth of bread, and four pints of beer since Monday - please to draw 15l. on some broker; I will sell all belonging to me as soon as I come to London, which I hope will be in a week, &c.
Addressed to Mr. King, King-street, Deptford Broadway.

WILLIAM COCKMAN. I live in Hackney-road. I took some goods to Deptford for J. G. King, and brought some back; it was about the 24th of January, I think - there was a beer-engine and other things; he helped me to remove them; Goodman King was there, and said they were his; there were quart-pots with Watkins' name upon them; they were found at my house - I lent Goodman King 3l. on them; Goodman King said the machine was his own invention.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1885.
SARAH CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , 1 pair of sheets, value 2l.; 3 table-cloths, value 22s.; 1 night-gown, value 3s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 3s.; 1 shirt, value 10s.; 1 cravat, value 2s., and 3 towels, value 1s., the goods of
Wesley Doyle
, Esq. ; 4 knives, value 1s.; 7 forks, value 1s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 20s.; 1 table-cloth, value 4s.; 1 portmanteau, value 4s.; 2 tea-pots, value 1s.; 1 quilt, value 3s.; 2 pairs of shoes, value 2s.; 1 basin, value 1s., and 1 piece of green baize, value 2s. , the goods of
Sarah Esther Ricketts
, her mistress.

SARAH
ESTHER RICKETTS
. The prisoner came to assist her niece, who was my servant, about a fortnight before the Coronation. On the 11th of September my daughter was going to the larder, and saw a band-box of linen, belonging to Captain Doyle, on the stairs; I brought itdown, and said to the prisoner, "Is this your's?" she said, "It is;" Captain Doyle directly said it was his, and an officer was called in.

SARAH ESTHER RICKETTS
. I am the prosecutrix's daughter. I saw the things on the stairs; I heard Captain Doyle say the articles were his - I turned up the bed, and some her things were found; her niece wished her to come to our house; the prisoner said if my mother offered her any wages she should be offended - my mother said she should not think of her being there without being paid; she was called cook.
CAPTAIN WESLEY DOYLE. I lodge at this house, in Southampton-row. These articles, which were found in the box, are mine.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and went with a boy to her lodgings - I found there a bundle, containing this bed-quilt and a duplicate of a pair of sheets; I found a few bits of gold on the prisoner.

ROBERT BERSENT
. I live in King's Head-court. The prisoner took my parlour about six weeks before the officer came with my apprentice, whom I had sent to the prisoner; I saw the articles found, which her niece had brought in a basket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. On the Sunday night I was sent for some rum - when I came back, my niece asked where Mrs. Ricketts was; I said, "In the bed-room, looking over the linen."

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1886.
FRANCIS TAVERNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 hand-saw, value 3s. , the goods of
George Porter
; and that he had before been convicted of felony.

GEORGE PORTER
. I am a journeyman carpenter . I lost my saw from a house near the Royal Oak, at Bromley
, Middlesex, while I was at breakfast - the door had been secured by a prop against it inside; there could be no admittance but at the sash - I had been about five minutes in at breakfast, when a young man said he saw a man going out of the house, who came and inquired where we were -I went out, and took the prisoner about a quarter of a mile from there with my saw; I told him to give up the saw quietly, but he struck me, and was very violent - this is it.

JAMES FITZPATRICK
. I took the prisoner about eight years back, for stealing two saws and a rule - I had a certificate of his conviction, but have not brought it.
GUILTY of stealing only. Aged 46.
Transported for Seven Years .

1887.
HENRY MACKELLOW
was indicted for
embezzlement .

GEORGE HARRIS
. I am a baker , and live in Berkeley-street, Clerkenwell. The prisoner had been in my employ sixteen months, and had to receive money - when he books his bread he gives me the account of the money he has received; he gave his account two or three times a week; he ought to have done it every day, but sometimes he was out.

MARY MILLER
. I dealt with the prosecutor for bread. Some time in June I paid the prisoner 1l., but he has made a memorandum of it and put it down the 13th of May - here is the bill in his writing; I have known him two years, and dealt with him when he was a master.

CATHERINE KOHNLA
. I live in Orchard-street. I paid the prisoner 2s. 101/2d. for his master the beginning of August, on a Wednesday or Thursday.

RICHARD HARRIS
. The prisoner never accounted to me for these sums in any way - I did not know they had been paid till after I had discharged him; I then went to him, and told him he was charged with embezzling my money; he said I was liar - he was confused; I gave charge of him- the officer afterwards brought me a bill of sale, saying he would pay by instalments.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Did not he give you notice to quit? A.No, Sir; I discharged him for spoiling the bread - I had lent him some money, and took 1s. or 2s. a week of him, as he could spare it; the security he offered was not for that money - he said it was for the money he had wronged me of; I charged him with embezzling 6l. -I know this bill; (looking at one) it is a bill of last January - my books are not confused; I am the only person to whom the prisoner accounted for money which he received - the prisoner left a sovereign with my wife and one with her mother, but I do not call that accounting to them; I have never said I would give 500l. to send him abroad.
The prisoner received a good character, and a master promised to employ him.
GUILTY . Aged 47.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

1888.
ANN WILLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 3 spoons, value 1l. 15s. , the goods of
Thomas Harmston
.

EMMA HARMSTON
. I am the daughter of
Thomas Harmston
, a grocer , of George-street, Portman-square - I have known the prisoner two or three years. On the 25th of August, about twelve o'clock, she came to borrow three table-spoons - I lent them to her; she said we were to have them back by three o'clock; that she had the care of a house in King-street, and the family were coming in.

WILLIAM FOWLE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three spoons, pawned by the prisoner about twelve o'clock on the 25th of August.

EDWARD BURRIDGE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - she said her mistress had sent the spoons to pawn; I said I would go to her mistress, and she said her mistress told her not to say where she lived.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 38.

1889.
ANN WILLS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 1 spoon, value 2s. , the goods of
Silas Boreham
.

SILAS BOREHAM
. I live in South-street, Manchester-square, and am a butcher - the prisoner was in the habit of keeping houses for gentlemen. On the 25th of August she came to me, and said Mrs. Allen had got a few friends at No. 45, Manchester-street, and asked me to lend her a table-spoon - I said I had no table-spoon, I had an odd teaspoon, which she might have; she took it, and said she would return it in the evening - it was then about half-past eleven o'clock.

WILLIAM FOWLE
. This spoon was pawned with the others.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. They were not pawned with an intent to defraud.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years for each offence.
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1900.
GEORGE WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 book, value 6s. , the goods of
Edward Portwine
.

EDWARD PORTWINE
. I live in Carthusian-street, Charterhouse-square
. I was standing in my shop, on the 29th of August, in the evening, talking to a girl; I heard something go from the window - I went out, and saw the prisoner going away; I called to him, and he dropped this book - it is mine.

THOMAS DAVEY
. I am an officer. I received him in charge.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1901.
THOMAS WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 cooper's adze, value 3s. , the goods of
James Garrett
.

JAMES GARRETT
. I am a cooper . I lost this adze from No. 4 shed, in the West India-docks
, where I worked, on the 31st of August; the prisoner is a journeyman there - I had not lent it to him.

THOMAS WILKINSON
. I work in the docks. I went into No. 4 warehouse, about eleven o'clock in the morning, and saw the prisoner shaving the handle of an adze- when he saw me be laid it down; I took it up, and asked whose it was - he said one he had brought in to put a new handle to; I knew the prosecutor had lost one, and told him.

BENJAMIN DAVIS
. I am employed in No. 4 warehouse. Wilkinson told me to look at this adze; I saw J.G. marked on it - I went to No. 8, and asked the prosecutor if he should know the adze again - he said Yes; I told him to come up at beer time, and I would find it for him.

HENRY SHIP
. I am an officer. Garrett came to me with the adze; I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it at No. 4, and it had no handle; I took it out and put a handle - I did not mean to take it out, but to work with it till it was owned.
NOT GUILTY .

1902.
WILLIAM WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , 1 veil, value 5s.; 1 crape handkerchief, value 2s., and 3 yards of net, value 1s. , the goods of
Ann Harrison
.

ANN HARRISON
. I am unfortunate, but work at the dress-making when I can get it, I met the prisoner, on the 3rd of July, in Regent-street, between twelve and one o'clock at night; I had never seen him before - he asked where I was going - I said home; I then lived in Phoenixcourt, Long-acre
- he went home with me, gave me half a crown or 3s., and we went to bed; I fell asleep, and awoke about three o'clock, he was then gone - I missed a veil, a crape handkerchief, three yards of net, and the duplicate of a gold pin; the veil had been on a bonnet in a chair, the net on a table, and the duplicate in a small chest - I met the prisoner, on the Saturday following, in Cranbourne-alley; I asked him for my things - he said he was very sorry he had done so, he had had them, but had not got them then - I gave him into custody.

WILLIAM NIGHTINGALE
. The prosecutrix charged the prisoner with robbing her, and I took him in Lisle-street; he said he had the things, and pawned them for 1s. - I said, "A man of your years I should have thought would have known better;" he said "I ought to have done so."

JOHN TYLER
. The prisoner was a shopmate of mine; when he was in custody a letter came to me, and I visited him in Newgate, as a brother-in-law - I said, "Don't deceive me, I know where the handkerchief is - tell me where the other things are;" he said, "Tyler, I will not deceive you, if you go to such a house,
Susan Jones
will give you the other things;" I went and got them - I sent to the prosecutrix to say I knew where the things were, and I would produce them at the trial; I was taking some work home, the Policeman took me, and I gave them the things.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went home with her; we went to bed - recollecting I had business to do in the morning, I left her, took my hat, and went home - when I got home I found the articles in my hat; I was very much intoxicated.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1903.
THOMAS MOYLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 10 sovereigns , the monies of
Samuel Walker
.

SAMUEL WALKER
. I am a publican , at Bromley, Middlesex. On the 27th of August, the prisoner owed me 27s.; he produced a cheque to me, and said, "Is that of any use?" I said "Yes, it is a cheque of Mr. Hale's for 14l. 12s.;" he said, "Take your reckoning, and give me change;" I gave him eleven sovereigns, three half sovereigns, and 15s. - I said "Here is 13l. 5s., and your bill is 27s.; the cheque is 14l. 12s." - he said very well, it would save his master going to town; he stood talking some time, then went away, and next day I found the cheque was only for 4l. 12s. - I found the prisoner at Poplar, and told him of my mistake; he said he was no scholar, and had put the money into his pocket without counting it.
NOT GUILTY .

1904.
WILLIAM WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 2 planes, value 2s. 6d.; 1 stock, value 6s.; 2 augurs, value 2s.; 1 oil-stone, value 2s.; 2 chisels, value 1s.; 2 spoke-shaves, value 2s., and 1 knife, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Collins
.

ROBERT COLLINS
. I am a wheelwright . I lost this property from the parlour of the Sluice-house, at Hornsey
- I left them there at eleven o'clock on Saturday night, and between five and six on Monday morning, the Policeman came, and I missed the tools; I had seen the prisoner, but not on that day.

JAMES FOX
. I am a Policeman. I met the prisoner near Ball's-pond, about five o'clock on Sunday morning; I asked what he had got - he said carpenter's tools, and he was going to do a job; I questioned him further - then he said he had been doing a job on Saturday, at Hornseywood, had got tipsy at night, and he did not like to go home on Sunday without the tools; I took him to the station, and found these tools had been taken out of the parlour window at the Sluice-house - the window was not broken; it seemed not to have been fastened down.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was bathing in the New River, two men asked me to carry these tools, and said they would meet me at seven o'clock, and if the Policeman met me I was to tell him I had been working at Hornsey-wood, where they had been working; I did not know they were stolen.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Months .

1905.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 shilling and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Cane
, from his person .

JOHN CANE
. I am master of a poor-house . I was opposite the Horse Guards, standing on the pavement, at the time of the Coronation; the Policeman came to me, and said, "Do you know you are robbed?" I said No - he said, "Look at your pocket;" I looked - my pocket was turned inside out, and one shilling and one sixpence, which was all I had in it, was gone - the prisoner was close to me; the officer had hold of him.
Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Was there not a great crowd? A. Very little - it was just as the King was returning; I thought if I was robbed, I would not lose all my money, so I divided it.

ROBERT ROBERTSON
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty about a quarter before four o'clock, as the King was returning - I saw the prisoner busy behind the prosecutor's back; I watched him, and saw the four finger and thumb of his right hand take the 1s. 6d. out of the pocket, which was turned inside out - he put the money into his left hand; I seized his left hand with the money in it - he struggled to get away, and in the struggle tore his coat: I did not lose hold of him - he threw the 1s. 6d. on the pavement; I took it up, and this is it.
Prisoner's Defence. I am positive the officer must be mistaken - I heard some money fall, and he accused me of stealing it.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1906.
SUSANNA WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , 1 coat, value 10s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 20s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Shaw
.

THOMAS SHAW
. I live at the Lord John Russel, in the City-road
. I lost two pairs of trousers from the back kitchen; I had seen them safe about a fortnight before the 13th of July - I know nothing of the prisoner.

THOMAS WILLIAM BLEWITT
. I live with Mr. Matthews, a pawnbroker. I have a coat and waistcoat, pawned by the prisoner, on the 13th of July.

PATRICK DAILEY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner about a fortnight after the robbery.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she was an unfortunate girl, and the coat was given her to pledge by a man who had been in her company.
NOT GUILTY .

1907.
JUSTINA SUMNER WILKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 3 blankets, value 10s., and 1 flat-iron, value 6d. , the goods of
John Griffin
.

JOHN GRIFFIN
. I live at the George and Dragon, in Leather-lane
. The prisoner and her husband had a furnished lodging at my house for eighteen months, and she was entrusted to clean the room and make the beds for the other lodgers. On the 27th of July I missed these articles.

JOHN PEARCE
. I am a pawnbroker, in Baldwin's-gardens. I have three blankets and a flat-iron, pawned by the prisoner, in April, May, and July.

WILLIAM BENTON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - she very readily gave me the duplicates from her bosom.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received an excellent character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.

1908.
CHARLES WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 4 shillings , the monies of
John Hooper
.

JOHN HOOPER
. I am an agent for the sale of gastubes . On the 8th of September I was between the end of the Strand
and the Admiralty
; I found the prisoner's hand in my trousers pocket - I took hold of the hand, held it fast in my pocket, and called for the Police, but none appeared; Mr. Smart came up, and assisted me in taking his hand out of my pocket, which had the four shillings in it; I had one sovereign and 9s. in my pocket - four shillings came out in his hand, and he dropped them on the ground.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Nothing was taken out of your pocket by the prisoner? A.His hand was in my pocket, and when we pulled it out the four shillings came out in it.

ADAM SMART
. I heard Mr. Hooper call for the Police- there was a very great crowd - I went up, and saw the prisoner's hand in his pocket; I took him by the collar, and said, "Let go your hold;" he would not, and I pulled his hand out of the pocket, and four shillings fell on the ground.
Cross-examined. Q. Then you made him take the money, whether he would or not? A. I made him take his hand out; I would have forgiven him, but a soldier took him to the station.
GUILTY . Aged 58.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Transported for Seven Years .

1909.
JOSEPH UNWIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 cap, value 7s. 6d. , the goods of
Mary Ann Pain
.

HENRY LEE
. I am a Policeman. I was at Ratcliffhighway, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening of the 7th of September - I saw the prisoner, and watched him to the end of my beat; I then saw him putting something into his pocket - I asked what he had there; he said a cap which he had bought at Poplar, and he had got the money by selling fish - I made inquiries, and found Mrs. Pain; the shopman saw this cap, and identified it.

CHARLES PIGOTT
. I am in the employ of Mary Ann Pain. This cap is her property; I remember seeing it in he shop, but cannot exactly say when - we did not miss ittill I went with the officer, and recognized it; I am quite sure it had not been sold that day or the day before.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1910.
JAMES BLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 coat, value 18d. , the goods of
William Curtis
.

WILLIAM CURTIS
. I am a hackney-coachman . On the 31st of August my coach was on the stand at Whitechapel
; I left it for about five minutes, about a quarter before ten o'clock at night, and when I returned my box-coat was gone from the seat - I went to the station-house, and saw it; the prisoner was in custody.

HENRY COTTON
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty, and saw the prisoner going down Wentworth-street, about two or three hundred yards from the coach-stand, carrying this coat; I asked him where he got it - he said a man had given him 2d. to carry it down the street; I asked him what man, and he said he did not know where to find him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Confined Three Months .

1911.
MARY SMITH
,
JOSEPH BURLEY
,
JAMES SMART
, and
CHARLES WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 watch, value 4l.; 2 seals, value 10s.; 1 chain, value 6d., and 1 watch-key, value 2d., the goods of
Thomas Sawyer
, from his person .

THOMAS SAWYER
. I am a revenue-officer . On the 18th of July I had been at the Pitt's Head, Bath-street, Bethnal-green
; I went at half-past four o'clock in the afternoon - there was a meeting of the weavers' society; I had not been playing at skittles; about twelve o'clock at night, as I was walking up to the skittle-ground door to come out. I saw the prisoner Williams' head above all the rest; I noticed him - when I came up, he was standing with his back against one side of the door-way; he took a step, and came in front of me, as close as he could to me - and at that moment I felt my watch going out of my pocket; I wanted to get my hands down, but I could not, as some other parties confined them: there were several persons about, but I cannot tell how many - I collared Williams and said he had got my watch, I was immediately hustled by some persons who were about; they shoved me away from him, and he immediately went off and I saw no more of him - I cannot say I noticed either of the other prisoners.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You do not mean to say, that this meeting of the trade lasted till twelve o'clock at night? A. They had a dinner there; several of them were gone, but not all - there had been dancing; I had not danced; there was 18d. to pay for a ticket for two persons to go into the skittle ground - I had dined there, I had not seen Williams in the skittle ground; there might be half a dozen or more persons about - no woman asked me what I wanted with her husband; I was as sober as I am now; I will not swear I was not any the worse for liquor - I might be a little, but no great deal, I swear I was sober.

JOHN THOMAS
. I am a Policeman. On the 19th of July I was in Ratcliff-Highway, at seven o'clock in the evening: I saw Smith, Burley, and Smart - Smith was five or six yards before the others, and she appeared to be quarrelling; I noticed them, and passed on till I came to King David's-lane, then returned, and saw them still in the highway; I saw Burley deliver something into Smith's hand - she raised her hand up, and I saw it was a watch and appendages - she went on to Mr. Hemming's shop, went in there, and stopped about two minutes - I went on to New Gravel-lane, and saw two officers - I told them my suspicious, and showed them Burley and Smart, who were standing in an uninhabited house, next door to the shop where Smith was; Smith came out of there, and went into a Jew's shop - he is a sort of general dealer; she came out in about half a minute - my brother officer said, "Where's the watch?" - I said, "Can't you see it is concealed under her apron, in her right hand" - we followed them all till they came to Bluegate-fields; Smart then parted from them, and was going up Bluegate-fields - one of my brother officers took him, and the other took Smith.

JOHN HENNAN
. I am an officer. I secured Clark; I said, "I want you" - he said, "What for?" - I said,"Two of your party are stopped for stealing a watch, and I think you know something about it" - he said, "I know nothing of it, I have only been with them half an hour;" Smith said at the watch-house that she had had the watch of a young man, named Lacy, whom she had been living with for eight days - I fetched Lacy, and he denied having had a watch for some years.

HENRY LEE
. I am an officer. I have heard what the two last witnesses have said - it is correct; I took Smith; I asked what she was going to do with the watch which I found on her - she said a sailor, named Stacy, or Lacy, gave it her; I fetched him, and he denied it.
Smith. I said Burley gave it to me.

THOMAS SAWYER
, JUN. I am the prosecutor's son, and was with him - I was coming out with him, and saw Williams standing at the door - when my father got up to him, I heard him say he had lost his watch - I did not see either of the other prisoners there.

JOHN CHUMLEY
. I am a labouring man. I was there, and saw Burley inside the skittle-ground - Williams was outside; about twelve o'clock I heard that Sawyer had lost his watch - I did not see Smart nor Smith.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.Were you acting as waiter there? A. Yes; the prosecutor was there from four o'clock till twelve - he was nearly outside of the door when we heard of the loss of his watch.

WILLIAM BARRETT
. I am a weaver, and was in the skittle-ground. I did not hear the alarm of the watch being lost, but Burley came to my house next morning, and said that he had a watch hidden under the skittleground tiles; he asked me if I would go and get it for him - I told him No.
Burley. Q. You state that I came to your house the next morning? A. Yes, you did, between eight and nine o'clock; I was in the ground, but I did not see this done.
Burley's Defence. I was at the Pitt's Head with five respectable married people, and stopped there till twelve o'clock at night; I was not absent from them one minute during the evening.

MARIA MORRISON
. I have known Burley for fifteen months. I was at the skittle-ground that evening with him; I went about eight o'clock - my husband was there- Burley lives in our house; we were altogether during the time I was there, and we left altogether between twelve and one; I heard it rumoured there was a watch lost - I know Burley was there after that; I cannot say that he was not at the door when this took place.

ELIZABETH ROBERTS
. I have known Burley two years- he is a cabinet-maker. I went with him to the skittleground, and came home with him; I had my eyes upon him all the time he was there - I cannot tell at what time the prosecutor lost his watch; Burley might have gone to the door.

BURLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

SMITH -
NOT GUILTY .

SMART -
NOT GUILTY .

WILLIAMS -
NOT GUILTY .

1912.
GEORGE ADDLETON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 1 purse, value 2d., 6 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Timothy Hutchinson
, from his person .

TIMOTHY HUTCHINSON
. I am a ship-chandler . On the 13th of September I was going to see Westminster Abbey; the Policeman touched me, and told me I was robbed - I then found my left-hand trousers pocket turned out and my purse gone; it contained six half-crowns and six shillings.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was there not a great crowd about? A. Yes; my attention was chiefly devoted to my wife and daughters.

HENRY WOODROFF
. I am a Police-officer. I was on duty, and saw the prisoner put his left arm round the prosecutor's hip; as soon as he turned from him I seized his hand, and saw him drop this purse from his hand.

Prisoner. I got into the crowd, and saw the purse on the ground. Witness. A. person might have picked up the purse, but that was not done in my sight; the prisoner was in company with others, I believe, but I did not see him speak to any body - I did not see him do any thing more than withdraw his hand from this gentleman's hip, and then drop the purse.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Three Months .
OLD COURT. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1913.
ISAAC THOMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Louis Balestice
, from his person ; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY . -
Transported for Life .

1914.
ALICE MARGARETIA FELIER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 bonnet, value 1s.; 1 frock, value 1s.; 2 petticoats, value 1s. 6d., and 1 shirt, value 9d. , the goods of
David Adams Cadogan
.

ELIZA CADOGAN
. I am the daughter of
David Adams Cadogan
, a tailor - we live in Wardour-street, Soho. On the 21st of August I was in Oxford-street
, with my cousin, who is eleven years old, and my brother, who is eleven weeks old - I gave the child to my cousin to carry; I walked rather behind - the prisoner was walking behind- she went up in front, and said to my cousin, "What a nice little child;" she then went up, and said, "Give me the child, for you will hurt yourself - I must carry it, and if it cries I must give it the breast;" she took it up to a door-way, lifted up her gown, and pretended to give it the breast; I then went up, and said it was my little brother, and it was my mother's child - people came round, and she said the mother of the child was dead, and it was given to her to carry, and she had a right to it - she began to cry, because I said it was my mother's - two women came up, and she began to walk away; the Policeman came up, and took her - the child was dressed - I was behind, but she did not know I had any thing to do with it.

EDWARD DODSWORTH
. I am a draper. I was in Oxford street on the 25th of August, and saw the prisoner take the child out of the little girl's hand - the girl began to cry, and said that woman had got her child; I went up, and said, "Give that child to the girl" - she said,"I will not, it is my child, and I am going to give it the breast" - she pulled her gown aside, and pretended to give it the breast: a gentleman came up, and said, "That's not her child, an old faggot, she has no milk," and with difficulty the child was got from her - the Policeman came up, and took her.

CHRISTOPHER BERGER
. I am a Policeman. I received her in charge.
Prisoner. I never took any child, or ever wanted it.

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1915.
JOSEPH FREDERICK SYMONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 2 gowns, value 5s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 remnant of printed cotton, value 8d., and 1 pair of stockings, value 4d. , the goods of
Mary Wallace
.

MARY WALLACE
. I am single . On the 5th of August, between five and six o'clock in the morning. I went into a coffee-shop in Shoreditch
- I had a bundle containing these articles; I get my living in service, but was out of place - I was going to my brother's at Edmonton, and stopped there to get some breakfast - the prisoner came in just after me; he was quite a stranger - I called for a cup of coffee; he sat down by me, and called for a cup of coffee; nobody else sat on that side of the room; he did not speak to me - I fell into a dose for a few minutes, and felt something drawn from behind me; I was very near the door - I turned round, and the bundle was gone, and the prisoner also; it must have been taken at that moment; I described him to an officer; and in about a week I saw James with my gown on; the prisoner was apprehended on the 9th of September - I knew him directly - he had got a mark on the left side of his cheek- I positively swear to him.

Prisoner. Q. Do you recollect between two and three o'clock in the morning sitting upon a step in Holywell-lane, and the Policeman persuading you to go home? A. That does not matter; I know I was out - I did not go to the coffee-shop with any man.

Q.Did not my mother meet you in Shoreditch, and you said you had no place to sleep, and she took you home to sleep there? A. Yes, that was after the robbery, and was a planned thing - I did not see the prisoner in the house; a young woman came after me, and said,"You have not got say home, you may as well come and sleep with me?" and I did so, for my father turned me out of doors for losing my things; he thought I had pawned them for drink, but now he knows the whole truth - I have been quite destitute by losing my things, and had but a meal a day; I did not see the prisoner at his mother's house.

GEORGE AVERY
. I am a Police-constable. I received information, and apprehended
Rebecca Russell
, who had the gown; I was looking for the prisoner for five weeks, and went to his lodging, but could not find him - I was in the habit of seeing him daily before.

REBECCA RUSSELL
.
Mary Jones
came to our house, and said she had a gown to sell, which would suit me; my mother gave her 1s. for it.

ELIZABETH RUSSELL
. I bought the gown of
Mary Jones
for my daughter; she sells things in the streets.

MARY JONES
. My husband travels the country - I have known the prisoner about nine years. I bought this gown of the prisoner opposite Shoreditch church, for 9d, about five weeks before he was taken up.

Prisoner. Q. Do you recollect two or three people being round, and I told you I had just found it? A. I did not hear him say so; he asked me next day to buy a duplicate for a pair of shoes, and a gown, pawned for 5s. - he did not say who pawned them.

WILLIAM CRAIGHILL
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in the Hackney-road. I have a gown, a pair of shoes, and a piece of cotton, pawned by a woman, in the name of
Ann Saunders
, on the 5th of August, for 5s.

WILLIAM BARROW
. I am a Policeman. On the 5th of August, in the morning, the prosecutrix gave me information of the robbery; she described the prisoner by a mark on his left cheek, and gave a very clear account- I knew him before; I looked every where for him, and on the 9th of September I apprehended him at a publichouse in Clerkenwell - I said, "I want you, Symons;" he said, "What for?" I said, "For those two gowns, a pair of stockings, shoes, and a piece of print, from a young woman, in a coffee-shop;" he said, "Oh, I'll soon settle that" - I took him to the office; the girl identified him the moment she saw him - my brother officers had been looking for him night and day, but he changed his lodging.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The morning I sold the gown to the witness I had occasion to go down a court, and saw that old gown on a dunghill, and inside it was the ticket of another gown; two or three people said, "It will suit Jones;" they called her, and asked what she would give for it - she gave me 8d.; I can prove I was never away from home - the witness has been and slept in the same place as I was since.

JOHN SYMONS
. I heard the Policeman was after my brother, and went to my mother's four days after the robbery; I there saw the prosecutrix, and asked her if she knew the young man who had robbed her - she said distinctly, "No, I do not;" she had met my mother, and stated to her that she was without a lodging - my mother took her in, and she stopped all night; my brother came in at ten o'clock, and he sat up in the room all night, not liking to go to bed - in the morning the prosecutrix had her breakfast at the same time with him; I told my mother it was strange she should come there, as she said he had robbed her - he did not leave home for three weeks after the robbery.

COURT. Q. You knew the Police were after your brother? A. Yes, and so did he; I cannot account for his keeping away - I blame him very much; I do not live at home with my mother, but he slept at home - he says so, but I do not know where he was in the day time; I have not spoken to the prosecutrix but once - I heard something about a dunghill about a week after.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1916.
ANN FOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 18 yards of ribbon, value 4s. , the goods of
George Evans
.

RICHARD HUGHES
. I am in the employ of George Evans, in Tottenham-court-road
. On the 5th of July the prisoner came in, and bought three-quarters of a yard of ribbon, which came to 21/4d.; while I was cutting it I saw her take a piece out of the basket, and put it under her shawl - she went out, after paying for what she bought; I told my master of it, and then went and overtook her about twenty yards off, and brought her back; she was taken up stairs - master asked if she had any property about her; she denied it - this eighteen yards of ribbon was found under her shawl.

THOMAS SUMPTER
. I took the prisoner in charge, and found thirteen duplicates for trifling things on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw it on the floor, and picked it up.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1917.
WILLIAM EVERITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , one half-crown, and 1 shilling , the monies of
James Squire
, his master.

WILLIAM SMELLIE
. I am brother-in-law of
James Squire
, a pork-butcher , of Tottenham-court-road. My sister gave me information; the prisoner had been in their service about twelve weeks, and on the 1st of September I called him into the parlour, and told him his master was very dissatisfied with his conduct; and asked him to account for some meat which we had found concealed - I did not threaten or promise him at all; I asked him what money he had about him; he said 16s. 6d. - I asked him to show it me, which he did; there were two half-crowns among it - I sent for Cowley; when he came I showed him the whole money - he picked out a half-crown and a shilling, in the prisoner's presence, and said they had been in his possession that morning - I then gave the prisoner in charge; the rest of the money was identified at the office.

WILLIAM COWLEY
. On the 31st of August, Mrs. Squire sent to me, and gave me two half-crowns and one shilling and sixpence; I marked them all, and sent my sister next morning with a half-crown and a shilling to purchase some meat, about a quarter before eight o'clock, and about eight, I sent her daughter with the other halfcrown and sixpence - I was sent for at eleven that morning; Smellie produced a quantity of money from the prisoner's pocket, among which I identified the half-crown and a shilling which I had marked - Squire has four or five servants - I said the money was marked; the prisoner said he had not seen me that morning, which was true.

MARY YOUSTON
. I am Cowley's sister. On the morning of the 1st of September I went to Squires' shop, and bought some pork, for which I paid the prisoner the halfcrown and shilling; I received it of my brother - I saw the same money before the Magistrate, marked in the same way.

JOHN FINLEY
. I am a Policeman. On the 1st of September, about one o'clock, the prisoner was given into my charge for stealing money out of a till - I produce the half-crown and shilling.

WILLIAM COWLEY
. This half-crown and shilling I marked, at seven o'clock on the evening of the 31st; here is the same mark on another half-crown.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in the habit of serving in the shop early in the morning; a girl came and I served her; there was no key to lock the till, and I put the money into my pocket, while I went to the back premises for some liver, and forgot to take it out again.

MARY YOUSTON
. I am quite sure he put the money into the till.
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Four Months .

1918.
RICHARD CRIBB
and
ELIZABETH WARNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 2 pillows, value 8s.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 1 pail, value 1s., and 1 candlestick, value 6d. , the goods of
Daniel Parker
.

JANE PARKER
. I am the wife of
Daniel Parker
, and live in Laystall-street
. The prisoners lodged with me above twelve months as man and wife, at 4s. 6d. per week; they never owed a week's rent - the man is a picture-frame maker ; the man left the room, sent the rent, and to say he was not coming home, that he would not live with the woman any more, and that part of the goods were gone - this was on Saturday, the 3rd of September, I then went up into the room, and these things were gone; Warner had not left.

JOHN SPENCER
. I am servant to Mr. Brown, a pawnbroker, in Gray's Inn road. I have two pillows, pawned on the 4th and 7th of March, and a sheet on the 21st of January, for 1s. each - they were pawned by a man in the name of
James Warner
, No. 20, Laystall-street - the person who took them in has left.

WILLIAM COX
. I am a dealer in marine-stores, and live in Little Gray's Inn-lane. I bought a pillow-case, a candlestick, and pail of Warner, on the 1st and 2nd of September, and the 23rd of August - she was alone.

THOMAS DANEY
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoners in custody - Cribb produced the duplicates to me, and said voluntarily that he had pawned the two pillows and sheet in Gray's Inn-lane.

JOHN SPENCER
. These are the duplicates from my master's shop.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Cripp's Defence. The things were sold without my knowledge or consent - I slept at my employer's for nine weeks, while the family was at Brighton; during that time she took the things out, and pawned them - I sent our foreman to pay the rent, and to say I should not live with her any longer.

WARNER -
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Fourteen Days .

CRIBB -
NOT GUILTY .

1919.
CHARLES DOYLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 1 steel-roller, value 2l. 10s. , the goods of
Noah Rous
.

NOAH ROUS
. I am a smith . On the 22nd of August, between ten and eleven o'clock at night, my premises were shut up - this steel roller was there on the bench in the shop; when I came down, about six o'clock in the morning it was gone; it must have been taken before the shop was open - it must have been opened by a false-key; there was no violence used - I found it at Marlborough-street on the 29th, and am quite certain of it.

GEORGE MYERS
. I live in High-street, Bloomsbury, and am an iron-merchant. On the 24th of August, between four and five o'clock, the prisoner came into the shop - I asked what he wanted; he took this roller from under his apron - I examined it, found it belonged to some machine, and asked where he got it; he said he found it among some rubbish - I asked what kind of rubbish; he said shavings - I asked what employ he was in; he said he was out of place, that he had no parents, and was living with his aunt - he gave the name of
John Jones
, No. 33, John's-court, John-street, Haymarket; I asked if he knew it was stolen - he gave me no answer; I told him there had been a person to inquire after it - he said, "Has he?" I said I should detain it, and send a man with him to see if his address was correct, but before I could get round the counter, he ran out - I lost him, and did not see him again till the 29th, when he was apprehended; nobody ever came for it.

ROBERT HUSON. I am an officer. The prisoner was given into my charge on the 29th, by another officer, who took him - I inquired, and found the direction he gave was false.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down stairs one morning, to get some pieces of wood from some carpenter's rubbish, and among the shavings, under some large pieces of timber, I found this roller.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1920.
GEORGE DOVEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 sack, value 2s., and 4 iron weights, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Joseph James Lake
.

JOSEPH JAMES LAKE
. I live in Drummond-crescent, St. Pancras
, and sell vegetables in the street .
