On the 6th of September these weights were in my cart, which stood opposite my premises in a yard; when I got up at six o'clock in the morning they were gone - the gate of the yard had been broken off its hinges before; I found the prisoner in custody with them the same day - he is a stranger.

Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q. Your house looks into the yard? A. Yes - the gate was down which made the yard open; the sack was at the back of the cart, and the weights under my goods - nobody had any business in the yard; there is a piece of waste ground near there.

JAMES POSFORD
. I am a Policeman. On the 6th of September, at five o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner coming down Little Drummond-street, about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's yard, with this sack rolled up under his arm - I asked if he had any thing there; he said, "You see what it is as well as I do;" I asked if he had any thing else there - he said No, but I found the four weights in the sack; he immediately knocked at his own door, which he was close by - somebody opened it; he immediately plunged in, but I went in and secured him - he made great resistance.
Cross-examined. Q. He told you he had found them? A. Yes - he did not say where; he was not going towards the prosecutor's house.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming towards this man's place - the Policeman asked what I had got; I said a sack and four weights which I had picked up in the field.

GUILTY . - Aged 22.
Confined Six Weeks .

1921.
MARY CHILD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 1 bonnet, value 1s. 6d.; 1 apron, value 2d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1d., and 12 pence , the property of
Thomas Evelyn
.

JANE EVELYN
. I am the wife of
Thomas Evelyn
, of Lower Chapman-street, Commercial-road
; my husband is at sea , and I sell nuts about. I was coming home about eleven o'clock, on the 23rd of August; the prisoner said she was without a lodging, and did not know where to go; I took her home with me - she went to bed in my room - I awoke about four o'clock, and missed her and all my things; I went with a Policeman, and found her drinking at the White Hart about five o'clock; she had my bonnet on, and all my things - the money was not found on her.

JAMES SMITH
. I am a Policeman. I found the prisoner with the bonnet, apron, and handkerchief on - she said she merely did it in a joke, and denied having had the money.
Prisoner's Defence. I was drinking with her on Monday, and pawned my clothes for drink, and on Tuesday she got this up against me.

JAMES SMITH
. When I took her, she had nothing but a gown and black petticoat.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 33 -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1922.
EDWARD CRANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 carpenter's plough, value 5s.; 1 bit, value 6d, and 1 stock, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Rhodes
; and 1 saw, value 5s. , the goods of
William Worledge
.

THOMAS RHODES
. I am a carpenter . On the 12th of July, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I went with Worledge to get some beer - we left our tools in a new building at Stepney
, and left the prisoner there; we returned in about ten minutes, found the door shut, and the things gone - nobody could come there without his knowledge - he was still there - we had shut our tools up in the house we worked in - we found them in pawn in about half an hour, in the Commercial-road; from what the pawnbroker said, we went over to the prisoner, and I said"You have been pawning my tools, give me the duplicate;" he denied having the duplicate, or knowing any thing of the tools - he went into one of the houses to get his coat to go away - I detained him, and when the constable took him, he took the duplicates from his pocket, and threw them on the ground - the bit, which I had left in my stock, we found in his pocket.

WILLIAM WORLEDGE
. I was at work at these buildings, and left with Rhodes; I lost my saw, which I found at the pawnbroker's.

WILLIAM EDWARD RUMSEY
. I am a pawnbroker, in the Commercial-road. On the 11th of July I took in a plough; and on the 12th, a tenant-saw and a stock - they were all pawned by the prisoner; he pawned the last thing about an hour before he was taken.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JAMES ANDREWS
. I am an officer. I found this bit in the prisoner's pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 40 -
Confined Six Months .

1923.
DANIEL COWLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Daniel Kinsey
, from his person .

DANIEL KINSEY
. I am a saddler , and live in Regent-street. On Sunday, the 3rd of July, I was at the Parkgate, on Constitution-hill
, and felt something at my coat pocket - I saw the prisoner putting my handkerchief up under his coat behind; part of it hung down - he seemed to be alone; I collared him, and gave him in charge.

WILLIAM SHEPHERD
. I am a Policeman. I was in the Green-park; the people were following the soldiers from the Palace - I saw the prisoner in the crowd; Kinsey gave him in charge with this handkerchief, and I found another between his skin and his shirt; he is in the Park almos every morning.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Life .

1924.
JOSEPH CROFT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September
, 1 spoon, value 10s. , the goods of
Frank Godman Capel
; and
JAMES FLEMING , alias CONNELY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen .

SARAH GALE
. I am cook to Frank Godman Capel, of Nottingham-street, Marylebone
. The prisoner Croft was in the habit of coming to the house, to go on errands, but was not regularly employed. On the 23rd of August, about one o'clock in the day, I had this spoon in use in the kitchen; I saw Croft standing by the kitchen door, about six o'clock, and about nine I missed the spoon - I found it at the office next morning.

JOSEPH PIKE
. I am a stone-mason, and my sister is housekeeper to Mr. Capel. Having been informed that Croft had made a confession, I went to him, and asked where the spoon was - I did not make him any threat or promise; he told me that a boy, named
James Connely
, was offering it for sale for him, at the corner of Peter-street, and the boy had told him the party had detained the spoon - I went to Peter-street; no spoon had been offered there - I went with Croft to Stingo-lane; he gave me a description, by which I found Fleming.

BENJAMIN ETCHELLS
. I am a Policeman. Pike applied to me, and I took Croft, who gave the account Pike has stated; he said Connely told him to bring him any thing that was silver, and he could sell it for him; I wentto Edwards'-place, Seymour-place, where Fleming lived, and Clark brought Fleming to me, with the spoon in his hand.

CHARLES CLARK
. I am a Policeman. I heard Croft's description of the boy; I was going up Crawford-street, and saw Fleming running as hard as he could, with another person; I took him, and found the silver table-spoon in his left hand, which I saw him take from his pocket, wrapped in a green cloth - I took it from him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Croft's Defence. I was putting some shavings away in the cellar, and found this spoon - I cleaned it, and asked this boy to mind it for me till morning, when I meant to return it.

Fleming's Defence. He came to me, and said he had found the spoon in the vault - he did not know whether it was silver, but if it was he would take it back in the morning, and asked me to mind it for him, as he did not want his father and mother to know it; in the morning the Policeman came and made a noise about it - I came out, and ran across Crawford-street; the Policeman came up, and I gave it to him.

CROFT -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.

FLEMING -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1925.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
embezzlement .

CHRISTOPHER ALDERSON ALDERSON
. I principally reside in Yorkshire. - I have a farm at Hendon
. In April 1829, I took the prisoner into my employ as bailiff , as my principal manager - I was not aware that he was acting incorrect, till about a month previous to my last return to town, which was in June, having had information from Mr. Wells; I produced his book before the Justice - the prisoner said he wanted to make up the book; the Justice ordered it to be delivered up to him, which was done - I have since received that book from Chadwick, and now produce it; there is no account in it of 2l. 15s. received for hay, on the 2nd of September 1830, nor of 5l. 8s., on the 5th of October - the book is partly in the prisoner's hand-writing, and partly in Chadwick's; the prisoner never accounted to me for either of these sums.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. You trusted the entire management of the farm to him? A. Yes, he did not buy and sell at his discretion - he has perhaps bought corn, which he got from a person I sent hay to; he frequently sold hay without consulting me - he took it to market, and when he wanted corn for the horses, he got it from the person I sent hay to; I charged him before the Magistrate with not accounting to me for what he had sold, and I produced the receipts for these two particular sums the Magistrate dismissed him, and ordered the book to be given him to see if there were any errors; it was returned to me in about a week - it contains an account of goods sold to persons for me, and at the end is a general statement of his account; that has been made since he was before the Magistrate - I had a previous account, in which he marked some errors; here is one of 3l. which is now added - the account is headed "Cash received;" he charges himself with gross sums, without naming persons, and makes a total of 731l. 1s. 8d. - he then strikes a balance, making 9l. 5s. due to me; the two sums in question amount to between 8l. and 9l.

Q. How can you prove these sums are not in the account he renders? A. These sums are taken from accounts in the book; and they are not named in those accounts - he once mentioned an error of 3l. to me.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you gone through them to see if you have received the sum of 2l. 17s. or 5l. 8s.? A. He never gave me either; his duty was always to hand over the money to me, not to lay it out - it is the information I received from Mr. Wells which makes me prosecute him; neither of these sums are mentioned in his account, which embraces the time before and after October.

GEORGE WELLS
. I am a hay-salesman, and live at Hendon. I was in the habit of selling hay for the prosecutor, which was brought by the prisoner for that purpose: on the 2nd of September, 1830, I sold for the prosecutor, by the prisoner's directions, a load of hay for 3l.; my commission was 5s., and I gave the balance to the prisoner - on the 5th of October I sold a load for 3l.; and on the 25th of September, one for 2l. 18s.; making together 5l. 18s.; my commission was 10s., and I paid him 5l. 8s. at once; we generally settled once a week - I was before the Magistrate at Hendon; these two sums were mentioned there - the prisoner was dismissed to make up his books; he called on me three or four days after, and saw this account; the said he had not had the load of hay on the 2nd of September - he marked it, and said I ought not to put that down; I said I paid for it - he made a mark against the 28th of September and the 5th of October, and said I was not to put them down, but to make a fresh bill, for he had not got them in his account - I am quite sure I paid both these sums to him.

Cross-examined. Did he not tell you there must be some mistake, for he had never, on those days, received those sums? A. Yes; I said "Here is my book, and I cannot alter it" - he insisted that his account was right.
Q. Here is, in his book, "25th of September, 2l. 13s., and the 7th of October, 2l. 15s." - that makes 5l. 8s.? A. It does, but I have not seen his book; I am quite sure I paid the 5l. 8s. in one sum.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. On the 2nd of September you paid him 2l. 15s.? A. I do not say I paid it on that day, but in the course of a few days; he had had a week given him to make up his books - he has written "left out," against these sums, which means I was to leave them out in the account: there were sales on the 25th of September and the 7th of October - besides these items, there were two distinct sales, which had nothing to do with this sum of 5l. 8s. - I have gone through every item of his book, and these two sums are left out.

Prisoner's Defence. I was only brought here on Saturday; I never received 5l. 8s. from him at one time in my life - I used to receive the money by instalments, and have rendered a true account, and after my book was delivered into their hands they altered it; there are four loads of hay I never received any thing for.
NOT GUILTY .

1926.
MARGARET REEVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 gown, value 2s. , the goods of
Henry Dyner
.

EMMA BROOKS
. I am servant to
Henry Dyner
, of Great-Earl-street
. I was in his shop on the 18th of August, in the afternoon; he sells ready-made clothes - the prisoner came in with another woman - they asked for two aprons; they tied them on; I said the price was sixpence each; they said they were going for some money, and wished me to trust them till they returned - I refused; they took them off, and returned them; this gown laid on a table, about a yard from the counter: they left the shop; the other woman took the gown and gave it to the prisoner, saying, "Take this, we will have something;" the prisoner walked out with it; they had not asked the price; I did not leave the shop, as there was nobody there - Mr. Dyner came in in about half an hour; I described them to him; he went to the top of the street - I saw the other woman in custody that afternoon, and the prisoner was taken next day - the other woman was discharged, and the prisoner would not have been committed, but she put up her fist, and cut my mouth open.
Prisoner. Q. Did not a woman come to the door, and give you half a crown for a gown? A. Yes - that was a gown outside the door; the other woman stopped behind, and abused me in the shop.

WILLIAM NORMAN
. I was a Policeman. I heard of this on the 19th of August, and took the prisoner that day in Seven-dials; I told her it was for stealing a gown - she said, "The gown be d-d, it was ginned," and she scratched my face very violently - when before the Magistrate she knocked Brooks down.

Prisoner's Defence. This girl lived with my sister four years ago, and robbed her; I met her one day, and gave her in charge: on the day in question she called me in, and asked me to buy an apron - we had some words, and I left; it is an old spite which she has against me.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1927.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 28 yards of cotton, value 14s. , the goods of
Samuel Smyth Forsaith
.

SAMUEL SMYTH FORSAITH
. I am a linen-draper , and live in Whitechapel-road
. On the 14th of September this cotton hung outside the door, on a rod, and was pinned - an alarm was given; I saw it was gone, and in about a quarter of an hour the prisoner was brought to the shop, and a person brought in the print.

GEORGE MOIR
. I am a shopman to Mr. Forsaith. I heard the alarm, went out, and saw the prisoner about twenty yards off with the print under his arm - two or three persons raised a cry of Stop thief! he saw me pursuing, then dropped the print, and ran; a young man stopped him - I am certain he is the person.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going home, and never saw the print till I was taken to the shop.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1928.
WILLIAM LADD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 coat, value 12s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 6s., the goods of
Joseph Collins
, from the person of
John Bruce
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1929.
HENRY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 2 handkerchiefs, value 8s. , the goods of
Isaac Welchman
.

JAMES VALLOTON. I am shopman to Isaac Welchman, a linen-draper , of Holborn-hill
. On the afternoon of the 29th of August the prisoner came and asked to look at some black silk handkerchiefs, which were shown to him; he spread them on the counter, took from under them two handkerchiefs, and put them into his left-hand pocket - I seized him; he pulled them out of his pocket, and threw them behind him - he begged we would do nothing to him, and said these were hard times.

BENJAMIN CATMULL
. I am a constable, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Two Months .

1930.
WILLIAM BARROWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 handkerchiefs, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Worters
.

THOMAS WORTERS
. I am a pawnbroker , in Phoenix-street, Somers'-town
. On the afternoon of the 12th of September a young woman gave me information; my shopman ran out, and brought back the prisoner - I asked him what property he had about him; he said none - I sent for an officer, and he was searched; I saw him shuffling about, and this handkerchief was found at his feet; it had been hanging inside of the door, fastened with a string - the prisoner had been there to redeem a waistcoat.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q.Had you known him before? A. I had seen him once or twice - one part of it was across his feet, about three yards from the door, where it had been; there were three persons in the shop - he had been in the shop an hour and a half before, and I consider he loosened the string, so that a slight pull would get it down; he ran about fifty yards.

WILLIAM RICHES
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner - I did not see any thing on the floor when I began to search, but I soon saw this handkerchief on the floor; I took him to the station - he said he wanted a black silk handkerchief, and he had just taken hold of this and it fell into his hat.
Prisoner's Defence. I wanted to buy a handkerchief; I looked at this, and it fell down - I hung it over the door, and went away; when I came back it was found behind the door.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1931.
WILLIAM BROCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1s., and 1 watch-key, value 2d. , the goods of
John Parrison
.

JOHN PARRISON
. I lodge with the prisoner's mother. I missed my watch on the 19th of August, from a nail in the window - I received a letter by the post, with the duplicates in it.

JAMES HENRY WILLIAMSON
. My father is a pawnbroker, in Brick-lane, Spitalfields. This watch was pawned by the prisoner on the 19th of August, in the name of
William Brock
.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

1932.
JOHN BUCKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 basket, value 2s.; 9 live tame rabbits, price 9s.; 5 live tame fowls, price 7s. 6d., and 1 live tame duck, price 1s. 6d. , the property of
William Cockerton
; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM COOKERTON
. I came from Suffolk to London on the 30th of July with a basket of rabbits and fowls, but I do not know the number; I believe there was a duck in the basket - they belonged to
George Bread
- I should think they were worth a sovereign; when I got to Whitechapel church
I heard a cry of Stop thief! I got down, looked at the hind part of my waggon, and missed the basket.

JOHN SEFFORD
. I am a Police-officer. On Saturday morning, the 30th of July, I was in Whitechapel; the prisoner left a cart, then came to me, and said, "What do you think of these waggoners? they would not give me a ride to Spitalfields:" I said I would not be under an obligation to them - he then asked if I had seen two men with baskets - I said No; he then crossed over the road - I stood at a door, and watched him - I saw him go to this waggon, take the basket, and run round a corner; I pursued, he dropped the basket: I pursued to Colchester-street, and found him squatting down behind an old boiler - I sprang my rattle, and another officer came, one went round one way, and the other the other; we took the prisoner - he then pretended to be very drunk, and suffered himself to be dragged out; I then took up this basket.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take the basket? A. Yes; I had seen you watching the carts the morning before.

WILLIAM ARGENT
. I took the prisoner last December; I saw him tried here, but I have not a certificate of his conviction.
GUILTY of stealing only. Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1933.
JOHN MONK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 chaise, value 20l., and 2 spring blinds, value 1l. , the goods of
William Scurry
.
MR. HEATON conducted the prosecution.

MARY SCURRY
. I am the wife of
William Scurry
- he lives in Hunter-street, Brunswick-square
. On the 27th of August my child's chaise was in the parlour, and the blinds laid in the room - I missed them between one and two o'clock; I saw the prisoner about two in Brunswick-square - the chaise is worth 20l., and the blinds 1l.; the pannel of our front kitchen door had been taken out, and in the prisoner's pocket we found a key, which fitted the lock of the area gate.

JAMES COOPER
. I was visiting at the prosecutor's. I received information, went out at the street door, and saw the prisoner dragging this chaise, seventy or eighty yards from the house; he attempted to make his escape, but another person came up, and he was taken - we found on him three skeletons, and four other keys, a screw-driver, and two knives.

JOHN CLINTON
. I assisted in taking the prisoner - this key found on him fitted the area gate; I saw the prisoner scuffling with Cooper, and secured him - the kitchen door had been entered.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I have a wife and four small children - I did it from want.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1934.
JOHN MASON
and
RICHARD SHAW
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, 1 penny, and 6 farthings, the monies of
James Faley
, from his person .

WILLIAM SEABROOK
. I am a farmer, and live at Abbots Langley, in Herts. I was in Covent-garden
on the 16th of July, and saw the prisoners follow a person, who gave his name
James Faley
- he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1935.
WILLIAM BARBER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 pair of boots, value 4s. , the goods of
Benjamin Lambert
.

EDWARD AUSTIN
. I am servant to Mr. Benjamin Lambert, of Old-street-road
. On a Wednesday in September the prisoner came to his shop, and asked the price of some blacking - I said 4d. a bottle; I saw him take a pair of boots off a nail at the end of the counter, and put them into his hat - he then asked me if we had any cheaper blacking: I said No; he walked out - I ran to the door, and called my master, who was down stairs - the prisoner was taken to Worship-street.

JOHN MORLEY
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner, and found the boots in his hat, on Wednesday the 7th of September.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A boy took the boots off a nail, I ran and took them from him, and they took me; I said,"Here are the boots, but I did not steal them."
One witness gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1936.
GEORGE BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William Gwyther
, from his person .

WILLIAM GWYTHER
. On the 8th of September I was in Parliament-street
, between ten and eleven o'clock, waiting for the procession; I did not feel this handkerchief taken - but it was held up, and I claimed it.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You did not see it taken? A. No.

JAMES WILD
. I am an officer. I was on duty on the day of the Coronation, and saw the prisoner with another man, attempting to pick several pockets, and at last he took this handkerchief from the prosecutor - he put it under his waistcoat; I told the prosecutor of it.

Cross-examined Q. Had you known him before? A. I cannot say I had; he did not come to me, produce the handkerchief, and say he had found it; I said it was a bad job for him - he never said a word; I was in plain clothes.
The prisoner received a good character, and a witness promised to take him into his employment.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1937.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 watch, value 2l., and 1 watch-key, value 7s. , the goods of
Henry Osborne
.

HENRY OSBORNE
. I am a stage-coachman , and live at Hammersmith
. I gave my watch to Mr. Madley, the landlord of the house, where I lodge; I afterwards traced it to Mr. Sheppard's - the prisoner lodged in the same house with me.

THOMAS MADLEY
. The prosecutor gave me the watch; I put it into the bar - I locked it up at night, and my wife unlocked the bar; the next morning, when I came down, the watch was gone.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q.When did you lock it up? A. On Friday night, the 12th - the bar was found safe in the morning - the watch was not missed till the prosecutor came for it - the prisoner had been there, and appeared drunk.

JOSEPH SHEPPARD
. I am a publican at Hammersmith. On Saturday morning, the 13th, the prisoner came to my house, he had some drink, and offered this watch for sale for 25s; I bought it of him for 1l.

Cross-examined. Q. How much did you require him to spend in drink? A. They had 15s. worth - there were twelve or fifteen people in the tap-room; my house is the sign of the Friend at Hand - the prisoner was not drunk in my house.(Property produced, and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, Stating that he had purchased the watch of a man whom he formerly lodged with.

GUILTY . Aged 30 -
Confined Four Months .

1938.
JAMES COOPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 3 coral cameo heads, value 15s. , the goods of
Samuel Sparrow
and another.

GEORGE COUCH
. I am a lapidary, and live on Clerkenwell-green. The prisoner came and offered me three coral cameo heads; I bought them of him for 3s. - I thought he must have got them in some dishonest way, and recognised him to be the errand-boy of Mr. Sparrow.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner.

JOHN BRUNT
. I am in the employ of Mr.
Samuel Sparrow
and
Edward Hawes
. The prisoner had been four months in their service, and left on the 5th of September, the day he sold these heads; I can swear these are my master's property - they are worth about 15s.
Prisoner's Defence. My work was to sweep the counting-house - I found these heads, and put them into my pocket.

JOHN BRUNT
. I do not think they could be on the floor, but such a thing might happen; I believe it is his first offence - his parents are very honest people.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Confined One Month .

1939.
HENRY CHILVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 3 planes, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Chilver
.
THOMAS CHILVER. I am the prisoner's father; I am a journeyman wheelwright - I missed these planes.

JAMES WALLIS
. I am servant to a pawnbroker. I have three planes, but I cannot say who pawned them.
THOMAS CHILVER. These are my planes; I have another son who has absconded.
NOT GUILTY .

1940.
JAMES CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 2 woollen shirts, value 5s., and 1 pair of drawers, value 1s., the goods of
William Thornton
, in a certain vessel in the port of London , &c.; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JAMES FOSTER
. I am mate of a brig, which was laying in the Export-dock, Poplar
. On the 10th of September, the prisoner came on board and asked me for a job to paint; I did not know him before, but I set him to paint - there was no one on board but myself; I went below and heard him go to the fore part of the ship, where
William Thornton
's chest was - I went up, and found the prisoner with his trousers loose and his shoes off; I asked what he was doing there, he said shaking the dirt off his clothes - I said it was a curious place to do that; he stopped a little time, and asked if he was to go to painting again - I then looked at a pair of trousers, which I saw him throw aside, and I saw they were Thornton's; I then went to look for the prisoner, and he was gone on shore - he looked very bulky, and I sent a boy to watch him.

JOHN FERGUSON
. I belong to the ship; I was on shore - I heard a noise, and saw the prisoner go to the end of the logs and undo his trousers; I heard something fall down - it was a piece of iron, and two shirts were stowed under the iron.

JOHN LAMMEN
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner,(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I hope you will consider that I underwent the punishment of my former conviction; I am quite innocent of this - I went below because it rained.

JOHN GEORGE
. I am an officer. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, on the 9th of December, and I am sure he is the person (read.)

GUILTY .
Transported for Life .

1941.
ELIZABETH DEELEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 pair of shears, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Deeley
.

THOMAS DEELEY. I am a tool-maker , and my father lives with me; the prisoner is his second wife - she leaves the house almost every week. On the 5th of September she went away, and we missed a pair of shears and all her clothes; she was out about six days - I had spoken to a Policeman before she returned.

EDWARD DAVIS
. I live with a pawnbroker. I have a pair of shears, pawned by the prisoner, on the 5th of September; I gave her this duplicate.

JOSEPH MARTIN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - I found on her eight duplicates; one for these shears, and the other for her own property.
Prisoner's Defence. I went with my husband to purchase these shears for my son-in-law; he said they were too large, and I gave him my scissors inexchange for them - I did not pawn them.
NOT GUILTY .

1942.
JOHN GRIFFITHS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

JOHN GUNNELL
. I am a Police-officer. On the 12th of September I was in Pall-mall
, about four o'clock in theafternoon, I saw the prisoner attempt several gentlemen's pockets, and at last I saw him draw this handkerchief; with his left-hand from a gentleman's right-hand pocket, and put it into his left-hand trousers pocket - I spoke to the gentleman, and asked if he had lost his handkerchief - he said he had; I told him to follow me - I took the prisoner out of the crowd, but lost the gentleman.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at the water side till halfpast six o'clock, when a waterman landed two gentlemen and a lady; he made the boat fast - I went into it, and under the seat I found this handkerchief; on the day I was taken I got into a crowd - thinking I should have my hat knocked off, I took my handkerchief out of it, and put it into my pocket; the officer came and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1943.
GEORGE GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of May , 20 taps, value 3l. , the goods of
William Bailey
and another, his masters.
MR. BALL conducted the prosecution.

SAMUEL ETCHES
. I am foreman to William and Daniel Bailey, ironmongers , Holborn - the prisoner was their servant , and was discharged in April. I went to Mr. Tulk, and found twenty taps of my employer's property - we never sell them.

SILAS TULK
. I am a tool-dealer, and live in Vine-street, Hatton-garden. The prisoner came into my service about April - I purchased a duplicate of him, for these twenty taps, pawned for 7s.; I showed them to Mr. Bailey's foreman.

Cross-examined. Q. Have they not Mr. Bailey's name on them? A. Yes, but it is so small I cannot see it without glasses; I am not a dealer in marine stores - I was charged in the other Court with receiving stolen goods, but was honourably acquitted.

JOSEPH HALL
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. The prisoner has pawned several things at our shop, but I know nothing about these taps.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into partnership with Mr. Tulk, and he deceived me entirely - I found he bought stolen property; I spoke to a gentleman, who took me away from there - Tulk was so spiteful that he said he would soon get me out of there, and he told of this.
NOT GUILTY .

1944.
GEORGE GREEN
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of November , 4 screw-plates, value 4l.; 23 taps, value 3l.; 1 wrench, value 5s.; 1 drill-stock, value 30s.; 1 saw, value 2s.; 1 vice, value 10s., and 2 punches, value 2s. , the goods of
William Bailey
and another, his masters.
MR. BALL conducted the prosecution.

SAMUEL ETCHES
. I am foreman to the prosecutors. I went to Mr. Button's, and found this drill-stock, and these other articles, which are my masters' - most of them have my masters' names on them.

JOSEPH HALL
. I am shopman to Mr. Button, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned these articles with me - he has been in the habit of pawning for the last twelve months.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you quite sure he pawned them? A. I am.

DAVID LYNCH
. I am an officer. I went to where the prisoner was working, and found these two steel punches.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. When Tulk and I were together, we employed two men, and when we could not pay them we took the things out of the shop, and sold or pawned them - some of my tools were mixed with his; I did not know that these were stolen - he has often pawned things, but he went in his dirty clothes, and they did not know him.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Confined Nine Months .

1945.
JOHN GRAVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 14 planes, value 7s.; 1 square, value 6d., and 1 saw, value 2s. , the goods of
John Kine
, the younger.

JOHN KINE
, JUN. I live in York-row, Paddington
. -The prisoner lodged in my house, and was a carpenter - he had been twelve months with me, and went away two days before he was apprehended, which was on the 25th of July, when he came back to my house - I had missed the tools; he produced the duplicate, and said he meant to have brought them back, but he had before denied having taken them.

GEORGE THOMPSON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a saw, a square, and seven planes, pawned by the prisoner, at different times.
Prisoner's Defence. When I went to lodge with him he said if I wanted any things I was to use them.

HENRY MATTHEW BAYFIELD
. I am a pawnbroker, and have ten planes - I do not know who pawned them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character, and a witness engaged to employ him.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Confined Seven Days .

1946.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Charles Domin
, from his person .

CHARLES DOMIN
. I was in Charterhouse-lane
on the 13th of September, about five o'clock in the afternoon, and all at once I felt the skirt of my coat move - I felt, and my handkerchief was gone; I saw the prisoner moving from me - I ran, and called Stop thief! till he was stopped - he pulled my handkerchief out, and gave it to the Policeman - this is it.

JAMES WILD
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner attempt the prosecutor's pocket for some time; a child was then nearly run over, which took my attention - I then saw the prisoner running, pursued by the prosecutor - I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1947.
MARY ANN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 2 coats, value 10s. , the goods of
Charles Clarke
.

CHARLES CLARKE
. I am a hackney-coachman . On the 12th of September, at eleven o'clock at night, I left my coach in Howland-mews
, while I was attending to my horses; I had left two close body coats on the splinter-bar - I went into the stable for a moment, and when I came out the coats were gone; I went up the mews, and aboutforty yards off I saw the prisoner with them - an officer had stopped her.

DAVID COLLINS
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner come out of the mews, with these two coats - she began to run, and I took her back.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went down the mews with a young woman, as I was locked out; this bundle was laying by the side of a carriage - I said, "I will take this horse-cloth, (which I thought it was) lay down on a step, and then the Policeman will take me to the watch-house."

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Three Months .

1948.
THOMAS KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing' on the 11th of September , 2 horse-shoes, value 1s.; 1 curry-comb, value 6d., and 1 brush, value 2s. , the goods of
Joseph Palmer
, his master.

JOSEPH PALMER
. I am a farrier - the prisoner worked occasionally for me. On the 11th of September I had information, and followed him - this curry-comb and brush were buttoned up in his jacket.

WILLIAM MALINGS
. I work for the prosecutor. I went into his shop on the Sunday, and found the prisoner with a pair of horse-shoes buttoned up in his waistcoat - I said, "What are you going to do with them?" he said, "I don't know" - he had no business in the shop that day.

CHARLES McCARTHY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - I found on him this property, and some horsenails.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take the shoes out of the shop.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

1949.
JOSEPH MAWSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 1 sieve, value 1s. 6d., and 3 pecks of apples, value 6s. , the goods of
William Smith
and another.

HENRY COLLINS
. Mr. Smith keeps a shop in Coventgarden
. On the 13th of September he sent me out, and I saw the prisoner going away with a half-sieve of apples - I told my master, who called to him; he said he had left another man to pay for them; he had got about fifty yards off - he had not asked the price.

THOMAS POWELL
. I am an officer of the market. I took the prisoner.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I have one partner. Collins gave an alarm, and I missed a sieve of apples; I saw the prisoner sitting on the sieve under the Piazzas - I called to him; he said he had left another man to pay for them - I was about to give charge of him, when a man stepped up and said, "Here is half-a-crown in part payment;" they had not been off the porter's head two minutes - they were not unpacked, nor fit for sale.
Prisoner. I had dealt with Mr. Essex, Mr. Smith's partner, for them.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Confined Three Months .

1950.
ELIZABETH MOSELEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 1 table-cloth, value 9d.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 6d.; 1 flat-iron, value 4d.; 1 blanket, value 9d.; 1 bolster, value 2s., and 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Rebecca Robinson
.

REBECCA ROBINSON
. I am a widow , and live in Palmer-street, Shadwell
. On the 18th of June I let the prisoner my back-parlour, furnished, for 4s. a week - she paid one week; I go out nursing, and had been out two months; I returned on the 22nd of August, went to her room with an officer, and missed all the furniture but the bed.

WILLIAM SCOTT
. I am an officer. I went with the prosecutrix, and took the prisoner; she said I should find the duplicates in Philip-street - I did so.

DANIEL KENNEDY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, two pillow-cases, and two other articles; three of them pawned in the name of Chant - I cannot say by whom.

JOSEPH MICKLEFIELD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have an iron, a sheet, a bolster, and a blanket - these are the duplicates of them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. My husband came home from sea - the prosecutor came into the room; he said he was sorry he could not get any half-pay for me, as it was so short a voyage; she told him not to make himself uneasy about that, as I might have anything I wanted - I pawned some things, but I got work, and redeemed some again.
REBECCA ROBINSON. I told her husband not to make himself uneasy about the rent; but I never allowed her to pawn the things.
GUILTY . Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Four Months .

1951.
EDWARD PAYNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 1 kettle, value 2s. , the goods of
James Davey
.

JAMES DAVEY. I live in Whitecross-street
. On the 17th of March, I had this kettle to repair; it was taken from my celler-window.

EDWARD HANDS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 22nd of March; the prosecutor said he had lost a tea-kettle, and found the person who had bought it. I locked the prisoner up, and the next day he made his escape - I did not catch him till Monday week last.

BRIDGET HOWLEY
. I bought this tea-kettle of the prisoner for 1s. - the prosecutor came, and I said I had bought it a good bargain of his brother, which I took the prisoner to be.
Prisoner. Q.Were there not two more lads with em? A. There were two outside.

PATRICK CORCORAN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning from the doctor's, and saw two lads with the kettle; they asked if I could tell them where to sell it; I went to the witness; some person there said I had stolen it; she said, "It don't much matter if it don't leak; I will give you 1s. for it."

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1952.
PHILIP DEEKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 20 combs, value 3s.; 20 brushes, value 5s.; 5 pairs of curling-irons, value 1s. 6d.; 6 razors, value 3s.; 2 pairs of tweezers, value 1s.; I screw-driver, value 2d.; 3 hones, value 2s.; 3 razor-strops, value 1s. 6d.;5 bottles of perfumes, value 1s. 6d.; 2 boxes of tooth powder, value 6d.; 2 bottles of blacking, value 6d.; 1 candlestick, value 6d., and 1 suit of clothes, value 30s. , the goods of
William Deeks
, his master.
WILLIAM DEEKS. I am the prisoner's uncle; he has been four years apprentice to me, and left me abruptly, on the 22nd of August; I missed this property when an officer called.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I am an officer. I received information, went to the prosecutor, on the 22nd of August, and asked if he was aware that his apprentice was robbing him; he said No - I took him with me to a house near Carnaby-market; we found the prisoner there- his uncle collared him; he said his boxes were below, and he gave us the keys of them - this property was found in them.

THOMAS LUCAS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a suit of clothes, pawned in the name of John Lowe, not by the prisoner.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. He said he sent a lad to pawn these clothes, and they were going to Brighton together - I have known the other some time; he is a bad one, and I believe persuaded the prisoner to do this.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1953.
ANN WEATHERALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 9 shifts, value 90s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 child's coat, value 4s.; 1 yard of linen, value 3s., and 1 shawl, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward West
, her master.

FRANCIS SHERLEY
. I am servant to a pawnbroker. I produce the articles stated in the indictment, which were pawned by the prisoner.

EDWARD WEST
. I am master of St. Anne's workhouse, Westminster
. The prisoner was a pauper in the house; I had employed her as a servant for three years - these are my property; the prisoner had access to them.
Prisoner. I am sorry for my crime.
GUILTY . Aged 57.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Six Months .

1954.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 30 yards of towelling , the goods of
George Clarke
.

GEORGE CLARKE
. I keep a linen-draper's shop , in Oxford-street
. On the 15th of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, a woman told me something was gone from the door - I looked, and missed a parcel; I went out, and took the prisoner four doors off, turning a corner - he had this bundle of towelling, which is mine; he said he picked it up.
Cross-examined by MR. BALL. Q.Was it outside your shop? A. Yes; he was not running; I have heard he was in distress.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had found the property.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined Three Months .

1955.
JOHN WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 waistcoat, value 4s., and 1 brooch, value 1s. , the goods of
Thomas Garner
.

THOMAS GARNER. I am groom to the secretary to the Portuguese Embassy, in Park-crescent
. The prisoner was in the same service, and slept on the same floor; on Saturday week I missed this brooch from my writing - desk in the servant's hall, and this waistcoat from my trunk, which was locked, but the key was in it - the prisoner kept his linen in the table drawer; I inquired of the prisoner about these articles, and he saw me and the under-butler take every thing out of the room to find them - I then looked into the prisoner's drawer and found seventeen duplicates.

THOMAS LUCAS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a waistcoat, a watch-guard and a brooch; I know the guard and brooch were pawned by a man in livery; the waistcoat is in the name of John White.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q.Are the duplicates of these articles here? A. Yes, the guard and brooch are in the name of Robinson.

THOMAS GARNER
. This brooch and waistcoat are mine.

Cross-examined. Q.Is there not another Portuguess or Spanish family in the house? A. Yes, there are three men servants - the steward will not allow persons to visit the servants; the drawer in which the duplicates were found was not locked.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I am an officer. I went to the house, and saw the prisoner - I saw the duplicates taken from the drawer; the prosecutor selected two of them - the prisoner said, "You were in great haste, I intended to return them, but I was in distress."

GUILTY Aged 22. -
Confined Three Months .

1956.
MARY WOODHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 16s., the monies of
Thomas Spearing
, from his person .

THOMAS SPEARING
. I am a haberdasher . On the 12th of September I had dined in the City
, and got rather fresh, but knew I was going the right way to Hammersmith
, where I live - I met the prisoner as I was going into the Park; I felt a pressure, and my property was gone - I said, "You have robbed me, young woman, if you will give me back my money, you may go about your business;" she said she was innocent - I said, "You know better, I felt you take it;" the Policeman was just by - he took her, and found 16s. in her hand; I had had 18s. in my pocket, but two were left.

JOSEPH HANSON. I was on duty between eleven and twelve o'clock on Sunday morning, and heard words between the prisoner and prosecutor; I got within three paces of them, and concealed myself behind a tree - I heard the prosecutor say, "You have robbed me of all I have got; if you will return the money, I will let you go;" I went up, and said, "What has she robbed you of?" he said 16s. or 18s. - I took her to a gas-lamp, and said, "What have you in your hand?" she said her own money - I opened it, and found 16s. 1d. in it; she said at the watch-house that a captain had given her 14s. -1s. 1d. was her own; the other 1s. she could not account for.
Prisoner. Q. The prosecutor said I robbed him of two sovereigns? A.No, he said he had two sovereigns in his pocket, and so he had.
Prisoner's Defence. He was very tipay.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
